reviews.review: Wow!. We visited here after Sagrada Familia and it was totally worth it. A beautiful former hospital is in wonderful condition. Designed by Montaner it is very peaceful to wander the beautiful grounds and enjoy the amazing architecture.

A very interesting place and well worth a visit. This is an amazing place and a must see. It is a fascinating piece of social and architectural history. It is not as busy as other tourist atractions and you do not have to queue or book in advance.

Sant Pau. We walked to Sant Pau from Sagrada Familia, chatting and eating gelato. Sant Pau was built as a hospital comprised of multiple specialty pavilions. The campus is beautifully landscaped. The exteriors and interiors of the buildings were beautiful. Because 2 of us are nurses, seeing the operating room with its two story double glazed windows was breathtaking. We walked ourselves through the site, without joining the guided tours. The guided tours are offered on different days for different languages.

Magnificent. Beautiful complex of art nouveau buildings: it was a hospital where each separate construction was a ward of a new "modern" hospital. The foundation is in the process of restoring them. Visible inside are the main pavilion (noteworthy), the triage area (where they kept the patients as soon as they arrived) and one ward. Aside from the main pavilion, meant to impress visitors of the time, most of the beauty is in the exterior of the building and in how they relate to each other.

Mindblowing hospital. Extremely beautiful and highly impressive hospital space inspired by art nouveau. Unfortunately, buildings are empty or closed, so you can enjoy only the architecture and some interiors, but their beauty makes the visit totally worth it. Despite we can only imagine how it looked when the hospital was there (several photos are also available), I sincerely hope that in the future a medicine museum will be arranged in this space.

Peaceful visit. My husband had found a flat to rent on the same street, we stumbled across this after walking up a pedestrian friendly street. We waited until the end of our trip to visit (stayed in Barcelona before and after cruise) and it was a great way to spend a lazy afternoon. We ate a late lunch first in the café that is in the front courtyard (really good food) - and paid the 10 euro (kids were free!) - we all wandered around in slightly different directions - the buildings are absolutely gorgeous - only a couple are open with info about what the hospital was like - the main building and the tunnels were my favorite. There are a couple of buildings that some charity organizations are using (i.e. a branch of the World Health Organization).....the flowers and greenery are lush and so well taken care of. Everyone enjoyed the visit - but the two of us that are healthcare workers were especially fascinated.....there were only a few other people touring at the same time which was a really nice change of pace!

Amzing hospital. As someone in the medical profession, I thought it was a beautiful hospital. I loved the courtyard and the modern architectures. So peaceful, calm, and beautiful. The garden and the tiles alining many of the walls within the buildings were stunning. It was worth the visit to compare the architecture to that of the more gothic architecture in barcelona.

Completely unexpected treasure in the centre of Barcelona. Absolutely loved this attraction - it was breathtaking to see the work that went into the buildings & such a high standard that was achieved- absolutely gorgeous & well worth taking the time to visit

Amazing modernist sight. An amazing stop to see another modernist side of Barcelona. This former hospital is a short walk from laSagrada familia, though much less visited. It's a short walk (15 minutes) so it's a great opportunity to see both sights.

A must see for anyone who loves Art Nouveau. We visited this amazing Art Nouveau site a few days ago. The size of the old hospital is staggering, although only a few of the buildings are open to visit. The exteriors have undergone a complete restoration and work is now ongoing in some of the pavilion interiors. Although visitors can tour the site independently, we joined a guided tour and felt the small extra charge for this was well worth it. Our guide was very informative and we felt we gained a much better appreciation of the history than we otherwise would have. I'm sure before long this will be up there with Gaudi's masterpieces as a must see attraction in Barcelona.

Near Sagrada Familia, Neat Buildings. So the boys were tuckered out from everywhere I dragged them, so my daughter and I had a fieldtrip day. You can take the train there. Don't be confused there is a modern hospital near it. This used to be an old hospital. I can't get over the buildings. I would not have minded staying here. I would love to see it being better utilized. Such character. Barcelona is filled with such beautiful architecture. It is not crowded compared to some of the other places at all. We walked to Sagrada Familia and rode the train back from there. Visited August 2015

Hidden Gem that is Amazing. We found this most amazing complex by chance, It is the old hospital that has been lovingly restored to its original glory, only a few of the buildings are open for you to go in to, however a lot of the beauty is from the outside.Sant Pau, is Europe's largest Art Nouveau Site and is one of the crowning achievements of the architect Lluís Domènech, very similar to Gaudi.This is a must visit

Beautiful Modernista architecture. This is an old hospital featuring beautiful Modernista architecture. If you're into Modernista architecture, it is well worth a visit! It is very beautiful, you get to explore the inside of some of the buildings as well. We took the Metro to get here, as there is a stop that is not too far of a walk from here.
Fairy buildings. The place has been recently opened to public and it looks outstanding. It is really beautiful, worth visiting it.

A hidden gem - visit this while EVERYBODY else is queuing at Sagrada Familia. Unlike a lot of tourist traps in BCN this is a peaceful, laid-back place to visit with simply incredible architecture set in beautiful grounds. For an unguided tour, entry is 10 euro and includes a small but useful guidebook. The complex is immaculate, almost as if it was brand new, but it's steeped in history. The visit takes you through part of the tunnel complex, into the operating theatre, into one of the infirmaries and finally the administrative building - it's a shame more of the buildings weren't accessible, but the ones that were open were a good mix, and I suspect with so much symmetry in the design of the complex it would have only have been more of the same.The buildings are beautiful, and although a cursory visit could probably last an hour, I got lost with the detail and was there for several hours taking pictures of masonry, mosaics, statues, domed tiled roofs and spectacular interior details.Although I can't take anything away from the Gaudi masterpieces in Barcelona, San Pau offers a complete change of pace and is absolutely stunning, particularly for 10 euros.

Sant Pau. its ok impressive rooms,but only about three building to look around, its 10 euro each so not a great amount of money, but more places to see that are free with more to see.may be when the rest is open it will be a good couple of hours visit, as it is it only took us about 30 min.

A gem. Recently renovated to the highest standard, a complex of gorgeous buildings! Excellent photographic history of the hospital and the area where it was built, the pride the city took in contributing to having a world class hospital is evident everywhere. Magical place.
Peaceful. Peaceful park with great architecture and mosaics on the various buildings. Worth the detour before or after the sangrada familia basilica.

Another Muntaner gem. If you have visited Palau de la Musica this old hospital is a must-see place. It is so beautiful that it takes your breath away. It would be nice if more of the buildings were open to the public. One great experience is the tunnel where a kind of slide show resembles the traffic in the tunnel many years ago. Kind of scary :-)

An eye-opener!. Tucked in a little corner (but actually not too far from Sangrada Familia) is Sant Pau Recinte Modernista. Beautiful architecture with a rich history, including how medicine was practised in the past, makes this an eye-opening tour. The area however is rather small and you can probably finish the tour within a hour, because many buildings are still in use by organisations (e.g. WHO) and out-of-bounds to visitors. Lines are usually short so you can get your tickets on the spot, unless it's a weekend or holiday then it will be faster online.

Good hidden spot. Nice hidden treasure, not to many visitors have discoverd this lovely grounds, although sometimes there are groups, but compare to other tourist attractions this one is an hidden gem. Must visit for architecture and history of this property

An art nuveau gem!. Having seen Montaner's work in Palau Musica, I wanted to visit his second important work in Barcelona. Coming through the beautiful entrance of Sant Pau, I certainly wasn't prepared for what was in front of me! It was not one or two beautiful buildings, but a dozen of stunningly beautiful art nuveau buildings, which formed something like the oasis in the heart of the city. One can almost feel like in a fairytale, walking through the peaceful gardens from one building to the other. Standing there in the mid of that beauty, one cannot even imagine that this was a hospital once. That must have been the most beautiful one in the world! And most importantly - there weren't any queues, not even many visitors (it was around noon, working day), so I highly recommend this visit to everyone who loves art and architecture, and would like to spend some quiet quality time in a crowded city like Barcelona is.

Do not miss this site. Palau de la Musica and St Pau hospital are the two great works of Lluis Domenech i Montaner, who is as great as Gaudi, but not that well known. The hospital offers a great tour of what it could have been like, to be at the hospital a 100 years ago, but due to all the colours, the lovely garden and great architecture, you almost feel as it it would have been nice to be a patient here. A must visit - a 5-10 minute walk (or 1 metro station) form La Sagrada Familia. Do not miss it!
Attended a wedding here. AMAZING!. Beautiful venue for a wedding which was a private event after it closed to the public just before 7 p.m. Stunning architecture and flow of the buildings.

Stunning. Beautiful, stunning colors, wonderful sculpture, architecture, mosaics, gargoyles, you name it. Entrance is not inexpensive (10 euros) but we'll worth it. Very close to Sagrada Familia but otherwise a bit off the beaten path. Try Il Forno for outstanding Italian patisserie nearby.

Beautiful Catalan Architecture. This was my 3rd trip to BCN and my first time to visit this as they only opened the site about 2/3 years ago. It was a good way to spend the afternoon. Loved the architectural details of the hospital. If I'd have to spend my last days, I wouldn't mind being surrounded by such beautiful architecture.

Great tour around a beautiful Modernista hospital complex. We have been to other Domenech y Montaner sites in Barca in past years, notably the wonderful Palau Musica Catalana, and the Casa Lleo Morena, and this seemed like a great place to visit - we were not disappointed. A large hospital site, where you area allowed access to four buildings - the central administration block, the operating theatre building (recently opened), one of the ward buildings, and an admissions pavilion that serves as a temporary exhibition hall. All, especially the Admin block, are Modernista jewels.We took an English Language guided tour - a little extra but well worth the money, as the guide gave a lot of insights into the history of the building - the benefactor who started it, how the different wards were used (including the underground tunnels), how it is being renovated since becoming a UNESCO heritage site, and how the different pavilions are used now and how it links to the new (2009) hospital built behind. After the tour, you are free to walk around some more. Easy to get to on the metro (Sant Pau is one stop after Sagrada Familia). We ate at the 1902 Cafe for lunch - nice but rather pricey. All in all - well worth seeing a whole Modernista complex, one can only admire both the vision and the attention to detail in the interiors. I feel that the Gaudi buildings get all the footfall (and deservedly), but the Domench y Montaner buildings are equally fabulous.

Worth the visit when in Barcelona. This is a great complement for the visit to Sagrada Familia as it is close to it. I would recommend stralling around the gardens and paying attention to the buildings. The interesting thing is that the cost of the whole complex at that time was around 18,000 euro. The correct name for the space is "Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau", not as stated in the name of the place.
Beautiful building. Old hospital converted into a museum with a very pleasant terrace to drink or eat something. In summer at sunset there are outdoor concerts.

one of the most interesting visits I ever had. Even for people outside the medical profession, this place is amazing. Since not too many tourists discovered it (yet) you can enjoy the solitude and admire the architecture and the vision of the founders.
Wonderful oasis in Barcelona. Wonderful modernista hospital buildings from early 20th century. Found this more interesting than Gaudi houses.

Top 10 - don't miss. Stunning - art deco collection of 9/10 buildings built as a hospital in 1902 and now preserved. You can go in few of the buildings - about 10 other visitors, very helpful guides and photo exhibits to explain the amazing importance of this building. All the crowds are down the road at the Sagrada Familia - which you can see from here.Just one absolutely not to miss - and it's something in Barcelona that is Not Gaudi

Amazing (and only looked from the outside). I have to admit that, because of lack of time, I didn't go inside but only took photos from the outside and a little from the inside where it was visible from the street.It was a very beautiful sight. Judging only from the outside the whole space is worthwhile the visit.As it's at the center of Barcelona, one must take a look at least from the outside.

Absolutely stunning. Loved this place, so beautiful. Stunning ceilings, Windows and decor. Some of the old wards are still being renovated but you can enter a couple. The photo exhibition gives a clear idea of what it must have been like working and staying at the hospital.The grounds have been very well landscaped too - a tranquil oasis of calm before hitting the madness of the Sagrada.

An Architectural Gem. A former hospital, the buildings at Sant Pau Recinte Modernista are terrific examples of Art Nouveau. They are so stunning that you will wish it was still a hospital just so you could get sick and stay there! It’s located about 4 blocks from Sagrada Familia, so it is a good antidote from the crowds you’ll encounter there.
Beautiful place. This is a really beautiful building from Gaudi. It used to be an hospital. It is close to Sagrada familia, ticket is much cheaper.

Magnificent. This building, which is now a museum, was used as a hospital till 2009. This was the highlight of the trip for me. There was a very good guided tour and, unlike some other attractions, it was not overcrowded. Each building is decorated with domes and mosaics and they are positioned around a central courtyard with gardens. Truly espousing the philosophy that healing needs the right mind space.

The Hidden Treasure of Barcelona. This stunning Art Deco complex is rarely spoken of, left out from most guide books and is only really visible when you get up close. And boy is it a stunning place!Essentially you have a vast complex of buildings that was once a hospital. This may not seem very special, but once you see the exterior, you'll understand why this complex is a must-visit - it's truly spectacular, and almost Gaudi-esque.The visit isn't too expensive, and should fill about 45 mins or an hour. You'll see some beautiful architecture and it's still a newly-renovated attraction, so the crowds aren't flooding in quite yet. Go go go!

A Hospital like no other. This is relatively new visitor attraction. The manager of our apartment recommended it over La Sagrada Familia. (You need to see both but Sant Pau Recinte Modernista is worth paying an entrance fee for - 10 Euros).You can find out more of the history online.It's a truly beautiful oasis of tranquility in a very busy city. Photography enthusiasts will love it for the intricacy of its architecture and design.After your visit it's an easy stroll down the road to La Sagrada Familia.

Shocking. I was not expecting much as we were going to Sant Pau Recinte Modernista ... just a remodeled hospital. To my surprise as we walked in it was an 11 building hospital complex. The design of these buildings were astonishing and the gardens that surrounds them are breathtaking. The inside was not that remarquable other than the main building. We had access to 4 buildings in all. The first sunday of every month at 12h30, the entrance is free so if you happen to be there on that day ... enjoy this beauty at no cost.

just from outside!!!!!!!!. please do not make the mistake to pay 10 euros and loose your time to see the empty rooms of an ex-hospital!!!!from outside is really what it worths!the people are crazy!they ask 10 euros for nothing????

Worth a visit. It's probably very easy to overlook this with the Gaudi works taking centrestage in the city, but glad we managed to pop by after visiting Sagrada Familia. Pretty amazing to see this level of detail and opulence for what was a hospital. Best part is that it's still relatively new (refurbishment wasn't fully completed as well) so it's not overrun by tour groups yet.Would recommend the guided tour (in the absence of audioguides) to understand the history of the building better.
Sant Pau. This place is absolutely beautiful! Unfortunately some parts were closed off so I wasn't able to access them. But definitely not bad for 7 euros. :)

Beautiful, not too expensive . A really beautiful set of buildings, so interesting to see how the hospital used to be run and how forward thinking it was. Not all the buildings were open but enough to see to occupy you for a couple of hours and take some beautiful pictures, would definitely be better in good weather. Lovely cafe as well where you can sit in the sun and watch the day go by!
Impressive. Very interesting place, beautiful and very different, definitely worth visiting, can easily compete with famous Gaudi attractions

Outstanding. We were staying in a Airbnb apt and one of the many leaflets was this site. We had never heard of it and decided to visit. The buildings are amazing with a projection of patients in the tunnel which showed how patients were taken between the buildings. The architecture is wonderful with the lovely mosaics in the wards well worth the trip.

What a surprise. This is a former hospital, not too far away from the Sagrada Familia. It has about a dozen modernist-style buildings, all very beautiful inside and out, in a park-like setting, designed with the idea that patients would heal better if they were surround by architectural and natural beauty. What a great concept! The Recinte has been open for, I think, only about 5 years or so, and they are still doing much restoration to the buildings, so only a few are open, which is a shame, but it's well worth the trip. There is a subway station just two blocks away (one stop up from Sagrada Familia on the blue line), so even though it's not near the city center, it's very easy to get to.

Kinda pricey for such limited access. Worth a quick visit especially for architecture buffs.. I love mosaic art and colored ceramic roof tiles, so I was surprised when this visit left me feeling blah. Yes, this old hospital does have a nicely planned campus of a dozen beautiful Art Nouveau buildings, but only four are accessible and only one (the main administration building) has a noteworthy interior; the other three are rundown or bland. So you're really just looking at the outside of a cluster of buildings for a 10 Euro fee (add 6 Euro more if you opt for the guided tour which I'm glad I skipped). It's not that the quick visit isn't worthwhile , it's just limited and overpriced.

Modernist, public architecture at its inspirational best!. The other reviews have said it all. Just find time in your schedule to go and visit, you will not be disappointed! We did not book and decided to visit on our last day, as our bags were packed and we had a few hours to spare before we needed to go to the airport. WE ARE SO PLEASED WE VISITED!!

Architectural Gem. So lovely and peaceful. Incredibly beautiful buildings, UNESCO world heritage sight, easy to reach, reasonable cost and no queues! Designed by Montaner, the same architect as the Palau de Musica Catalana and teacher of Gaudi. Difficult to believe that these beautiful buildings were designed as a hospital and continued being used as a hospital until 2009. Don't miss it.

非常好的经验. Best day ever, we love everything there, the wash room is amazing, feel very different.
非常有意思的一次旅行 带着孩子一起的 不要错过
医院基本加拍照片 一个小时可以逛完 不要错过进口的厕所 很有现代感 很大

Unbelievable architecture, mosaics, landscaping - don't miss!. The former Sant Pau hospital was a highlight of our trip. Everywhere you look, there is beauty to behold. What foresight to design a hospital that is not only dedicated to medicine, but to a serene setting that will help patients heal faster in mind and body. This was a city in the city and was used as a hospital until just recently (2009, I believe). Very easy to walk around and no crowds. Don't miss this one.

Not by Gaudi... even more impressive work. This former hospital of Barcelona was shut down and completely restored and reopened only in 2014.... and is a pure open-air feat for the eyes. About 12 buildings can be viewed along the accessible main square of the complex... and three in which you can enter. a guided visit is recommended, as you have access to a lot of information about the place and how it used to be ran as an hospital... on top of having access to restricted areas general public can't.It's an easy and beautiful 15 minute walk from Sagrada familia.Expect to spend 2:00 hours in this place (incl. the guided tour).

Gaudi's competitor. We hadn't heard about this complex prior to coming to Barcelona but it was recommended to us by our apartment host. We are very glad we went. We took the free English tour and would highly recommend that you time your visit to take advantage of one of these tours. Our guide was engaging and very informative.

Wonderful. Amazing history and wealth of art noveau architecture. NOt everything open but what is accessible is a rare treat. Not crowded either which makes a change. Guides are very helpful so make use of this service.to maximise your visit.

A feast for your eyes. I have been reading the not so good reviews for this place and yes most of the buildings are off limits. I think it is still worth the effort to go though, the detailed work on the buildings is breath taking and to think that it was once a working hospital. So many good photo opportunities and a lovely place to relax for a couple of hours. It is 10 euros to enter and as far as I am concerned it is well worth it as it must cost so much to preserve these wonderful buildings. There is a café there too!

If you're interested in architecture, this is great!. Booked on line for a guided tour in English and it was well worth it to understand the story behind this complex of buildings, which were built with great attention to detail as a charity hospital for the poor of Barcelona and included gardens as part of the healing environment.
A Treasure to Find. This hospital turned UNESCO Heritage Site is worth a visit! Take a guided tour for more details and comparison pictures. A beautiful and interesting experience of Modernism.

Unexpected peace. Sant pau is not a popular place in Barcelona (Maybe this is why it is peaceful and you do not wait in long ques) we visited here bacause of the pictures. It has beautiful ceiling art. Very peaceful, its garden is full of lavender. The history of the hospital is remarkable. There is an exhibition about an experiment about life and death. Do not miss it.

This used to be a hospital! Wow!. This used to be a hospital? Is what I kept asking myself. At the end of Avenida de Gaudi is this UNESCO World Heritage site and it's not surprising. It's so well planned that one of the many beautiful rooms has a direct view of the cathedral too... The exterior and interiors are so beautiful and unlike other places in Barcelona, it's not too crowded with tourists so you can really enjoy it and take postcard perfect pictures. Some parts are still under restoration but much of it is complete and well worth going!
Beautiful and peaceful. It was a peaceful and uncrowded place to visit with plenty of places to sit outside. Fantastic architecture and a really amazing place to see.

Beautiful architecture, bad value for money. The first impression was "Wow!". The architecture is breathtaking and the story behind the old hospital is really interesting. We entered the complex through an underground tunnel and as we came upstairs into the inner courtyard we were impressed. And only a few moments later we got really disappointed 'cause there wasn't much more to see than the facade of the buildings. And we paid 10 Euro for that. You can visit a temporary exhibition, one large sick chamber, the entrance hall and a room on the first floor of the main building. After a few minutes you're done with your visit. That's what I call bad value for money.

Great place, bad museum. I have visited this place in past, while it still was a hospital; and it must be said, that even then (while trying not to disturb the work of the hospital) somehow, the place was easier and more interesting to visit. Yet another place that used to be free and not anymore, Sant Pau Hospital is an amazing example of modernist architecture, and since it's a big complex, it's even more interesting. However, the museum has added the entrance fee without adding any reasonable content.Out of some 8-10 buildings of the museum, only 3 are open for the visitors; only half of the main hall is open, while some more interesting parts of it are used for something else. The remaining two buildings are practically empty from the inside and totally fail to show how the place operated as a hospital - which would be the most interesting part. The only excuse that might be, is if they currently work on the restoration of the remaining buildings, which I'm not sure is the case. On the end of the day - an architectural masterpiece turned into a very weak museum.A big "WOW" to Domènech i Montaner, a big thumbs down to the organizers of the museum, who seemingly couldn't bother less, other that collecting money.

A beautiful place to explore. The only reason I gave it four points is that many areas of the grounds were closed. For a ten€ ticket it's a bit annoying. Otherwise it's quiet, beautiful and interesting

Incredible "City within a City". This was the best place that we visited in the whole of Barcelona. Absolutely fantastic place and so peaceful seeing that it is situated in a large city.The entrance price was only 7 euros each. Much better value than Sagrada Familia at 28 euros each. There isn't a great deal written about it in any guide books because it has only been open a relatively short time. Some of the buildings are still being renovated, but there is plenty to see. Go see...you will not be disappointed !!!

Hidden Gem. Many people go to Barcelona to see the Gaudi wonderful buildings,and rightly so. Along the avenue at the back of the Sagada you will find this delight,hospital built between 1902...1930. The pavilions are Art Nouveau style,coloured tiles,wonderful ceilings and lovely shapes. A reasonable price as well.

One of Barcelona's newest gems. Opened in 2014 Sant Pau Recinte Modernista is a must see destination to add to your Barcelona top ten. It is a walk way from the Sagrada Familia and both are architectural wonders from two incredible architects. The guided tour is a great way to experience Saint Pau and booking online through their website was so easy.

Quiet and calm. This is a 10 minutes walk from la familia and well worth it if you like modernist architecture. There is nothing here to do but look at the buildings and soak up the atmosphere of this former hospital. I was very impressed with how quiet and peaceful this was in the middle of a major city. Some interesting information about how it came to be a hospital originally. Surprisingly there is a full airport style security check as you enter.

The best attraction in Barcelona!. Built by the same architect as the Palau de la Musica Catalana, this hospital is an incredible ensemble of the finest modernista buildings I have ever seen! Every building or pavillion is a work of art, outstanding for it's beauty! When you consider it was built at the beginning of the XXth century, and it was a hospital, it is really unbelievable how modern, funcional and beautiful it was!

Take Time to Explore This Art Nouveau Gem. Just a few blocks from Sagrada Familia is this former hospital, designed by Lluís Domènech i Montaner. The concept of separate hospital buildings is quite interesting. The unique design of the buildings is beautiful. After the crush of visitors at SF, it was nice to practically have this place all to ourselves.

A Real Overlooked Gem. This is a place that I'd gone past so many times on the bus and was saving up for when friends came over to visit. From the outside it looks fairly impressive but once inside the complex it's awsome. It's huge, immaculately renovated and cared for and so, so tranquil. We'd walked up from La Sagrada Familia, which of course, is a wonder, but also swarming with tourists. By contast, Hospital Sant Pau was almost deserted: a real oasis of calm which felt right considering the original purpose of the buildings. Importantly this is a living 'monument" (sorry, can't think of a better word) as it still houses conferences, meetings and medical research facilities.The history of each building is well explained pictorially and textually. The scale of the renovations is impressive, and to see the original photographs of the hospital inmates was beyond touching. Our only very small criticism was that the exhibition of the renovations lacked a mapIt seems that Hospital Sant Pau is a greatly underestimated and overlooked aspect of Barcelona's rich cultural history, but selfishly the lack of crowds added to our enjoyment.

Brilliant. This vast property was constructed around 1900 and is in the art nouveau style.It was constructed as a Hospital and the architecture and colour of the roof tiles and magnificent gardens and courtyard are outstanding.It was last used as a Hospital around 2006 or parts of it were. Absolutely a feast for the eys both outside and definitely inside.
recently redone. it's a must you cannot forget to visit if you travel to Barcelona. Very fine retaured. A monument of the modernism style!

pretty on the outside but not much substance. The main building which one can see and photograph for free is probably the most impressive. I had time to kill and it is only a 10 min walk from Sagrada Familia. I was also interested in how this would work as a hospital. Aside from walking in a tunnel used to transport supplies, there is no evidence of how it would function as a hospital. Only 2 of the buildings were open and once inside, it's a large tiled space. The photo of the way it used to be showed - a large tiled space. If you have time and money to spend, then by all means visit, I didn't find it as amazing as others and wouldn't recommend it to friends.

My favourite thing to see in Barcelona. I was amazed at how cheap it was - €7 for 16-29 year olds. The old hospital itself is a work of art. The buildings and the garden were stunning and there was the right number of posters to read that did not overwhelm us with info. It is a great way to spend time before visiting the Basílica de la Sagrada Família.

Amazing modernista detail. I had no idea of the existence of this place and was blown away by the spectacular ceramic tile work both inside and outside the buildings as well as the layout of this old hospital. This place is beautiful!

Exceptional architecture of an ancient hospital. This Sant Pau was earlier a hospital and built around 1900. The complex of several buidings in the same style can be visisted but not all buidings are accessable. You get a good impression of hospitalisation in the beginning of the 20th century in Spain

My favorite!. This is my absolute favorite thing in Barcelona. I like to think of it as a hidden gem. I had visited several years ago & had this on my list but unfortunately they were still doing the restoration & most of it was tarped off. I still took a few outside pictures & knew I wanted to come back. Fast forward to last year when a friend of mine visited Barcelona. She had posted that she went to the Sagrada Familia & was underwhelmed. I sent here here & she loved it. It was the first thing on my list for my trip this year. It is an easy walk from Sagrada Familia & the red sightseeing bus stops here as well. It is not crowded at all & the admission was quite reasonable. It's amazing to think of this as an actual hospital because it's so beautiful. The grounds are also amazing. I loved reading about the renovations as well. Only 3 buildings were open during my visit with more to come in the future. This is my #1 recommendation in Barcelona & I will definitely be back to see the rest!

Traveling in time. If you visit Barcelona and the Sagrada Familia, you should definitely stop by Sant Pau. It feels a bit like traveling in time. Unfortunately only 3 buildings were open for visits but that was okay. The site itself is already so beautiful.

Absolutely Gorgeous. We enjoyed this site more than the some of the Casa's that charge twice as much. The campus is beautiful with 3 buildings for public entry. A perfect example of Modernista architecture. This should be on everyone's #2 to do list in Barcelona. A 5 minute walk from Sagrada Familia. Beware that one is not allowed to eat in the gardens and we had brought a picnic lunch for exactly that purpose.

Hidden Gem!. We found this place by chance while waiting for entry somewhere else. It was a lucky found as we found the place beautiful and fascinating. The history of the site as a former hospital was really interesting. The design of the place was beautiful and ahead of its time. The renovation has been done really well and the mosaics are amazing to see. The whole place had a really serene atmosphere too. The children were very taken with it too.

Pretty but pointless. I declined pay to enter a building just so I can walk around and take pictures. Now that is not a hospital, what is it? The facade was nice enough for me. Perhaps by this point, I was suffering from Catalan Art Nouveau overload and was a little crabby. They really have to stop calling it Modernism, since the movement it more then 120 years old now.

Stunning renovation. What an amazing renovation of a modernist designed hospital complex. It is a work in progress, but there is much to be currently admired. Peaceful and not far from the crowds at the Sagrada. Very fine cafe on site. Very reasonable entry fee compared to most. Put it on your list when in the city.

Remarkable. Really incredible to explore this site and to experience the amazing undertaking to create a place of beauty and healing. Loved the holograms in the tunnel. The detail in every wall and ceiling is nothing short of awe inspiring.

Best of the Modernista with Almost no one there. Only four blocks up the Avineda de Gaudi from the Sagrada Familia is another modernismo masterpiece by Montinmar (he also designed the Palace of Catalan Music). Taking almost 30 years to build, it included only half of the originally planned 48 buildings. Even this is amazingly beautiful and challenges Gaudi at his best. Even more amazing, given its close proximity to Sagrada Familia, is rhe fact that you can wander its grounds essentially alone while tourist hordes swamp the nearby chuch. If you love Gaudi and Modernismo it is not to missed, I am only sorry it took me 3 trips to Barcelona to discover it.
AMAZING ARCHITECTURE. This hospital complex has amazing architecture. The tour guide on the premises provide interesting information. The restoration is amazing.I would highly recommed a visit.

A Jewel in Barcelona's Crown. This incredible former hospital is a 'City within a City' - a group of stunning Art Nouveau buildings set in their own grounds. They were used until quite recently as a hospital, with different buildings serving different functions. Their history is shown in photographic form, but also you can see the remains of the hospital which have been left very much as they were - for example the 28 bed womens' ward with its amazing decorated ceiling.Restoration has been underway for a number of years, and many of the buildings will be returned to commercial use. But the complex as a whole is a joy to visit, with its paved grounds covered in herbs and orange trees. And each building has its own decorative features.This is a 'must see' in Barcelona and is, as yet, relatively unknown so there aren't the crowds that you find at the other attractions.

Best place in the area, in an incredible setting. The restaurant inside the historic place is surprising; don't miss the counter where they have several types of speciality cheeses and dry meats. The menu is good and the carte excellent. And you can miss visiting the Sant Pau recinte!

Astonishing place the best of modernista architecture of Montaner. This is the highlight, to my humble opinion, of Lluís Domènech i Montaner work I saw, and definately one of the greatest beauty of Barcelona great architecture. It was renovated and worth every penny you pay to see it and enjoy the beauty of human work (I saw it 7 years ago for free and it is even greater now for fee). I can't imagine such beauty in todays work. Don't dare to miss it, and then walk down Gaudi's avenue toward thw Segrada Familia.

Splendid Architecture . The hospital pavilions were meticulously restored and a fine example of modernist architecture in Barcelona! Designed by yet another prominent architect (Domenech), who also designed the famed Palau de la Musica! It is definitely worth a visit and it's (slightly) off the beaten path from the usual Gaudi buildings! Would recommend going in the morning to explore the site.

Beautifully restored, historically exciting. Good experience about architecture, healthcare, art... very interesting. You have the opportunity to learn the history of the hospital that is the history of a very rich period in Barcelona,

ASTONISHING!. If you have even the slightest interest in architecture or building, you must visit this. I can say with full certainty that this place is unique, and beautiful and mind-blowing! I am sure it is not to everyone's taste but the combination of the style with the practicality of the ensemble as a hospital (in the early 20th century) is amazing.

fascinating history and architecture. This is a must see place.Not expensive, beautiful and there were hardly any people.This place was absolutely fascinating.Magnificent buildings with stunning architecture and amazing interior

Beautiful art nouveau hospital that shows how forward thinking Barcelona has always been. This is a beautiful and tranquil space that is well worth a visit for lovers of art nouveau architecture. It is not far from the Sagrada Familia. The ceilings of this former hospital and the layout of the whole complex demonstrate the avant garde city planning that has made Barcelona so special.
Early visits are the best!. Wonderful place, go early in the morning to avoid the larger crowds. Definitely worth a visit! Relaxing spot in the middle of the city.
sunlight hitting the gold tiles is breathtaking. gorgeous gorgeous gorgeous. I only saw it from the outside, so I don't know for inside, but the architecture is stunning from what I saw.
Superb example of modernist architecture. Superb example of modernist architecture, worth the walk from Sagrada Familia to the hospital, and the walk inside the complex.

An oasis of calm.... This was up towards the top of my to do list for Barcelona and I heartily recommend it to anyone and everyone. An oasis of calm after visiting Sagrada Familia which was heaving. Well worth a visit if not only to experience a relatively empty space in Barcelona (ha! I shouldn't be telling anyone about it!!) but also to learn about the history - a former hospital - and to gaze at yet more wonderful art nouveau architecture. Walking distance from the Sagrada so worth putting on your list.

Make this top of your list!. We more or less happened upon this wonderful place by chance when looking for a coffee shop, after we had visited the Sagrada and were so glad that we did! Renovation work at Sant Pau has only relatively recently been completed and it is a wonderful opportunity to enjoy a relaxed visit before the crowds and the queues arrive, which tey undoubtedly will. The outside gives you little indication of the sheer size and beauty that awaits you inside. Absolutely splendid!

A must see!. This place was absolutely fascinating. We ended up visiting just because we were staying nearby and thought it looked neat from the exterior. You can't even see how marvelous it is from the street, though. It's like an oasis in the city. The garden is beautiful, and we loved just being able to sit under the orange trees. The interiors are wonderful, and we loved how you enter through one of the tunnels. It's a very unique hospital that I'm so glad we stumbled upon! Definitely worth the entrance price.

Colorful. The former hospital, designed by Lluis Domenech Montaner between 1901 and 1930, is a magnificent building with stunning architectural solutions and amazing interior. It is a real festival of shapes and colors in a peaceful environment with many hidden corners worth further exploring.

A real interesting place. It will be a mistake to miss this place!
Absolutely underestimated by reviews on TA, I would recommend to pay a visit to this place for both interiors and exteriors.

fascinating history and architecture. This site is fabulous. Definitely take the guided tour because the explanations help a lot to understand the concept of the architect Muntener. Aside from its historical significance it has been turned into a modern living campus for international study.

Incredible Modernista Architecture. Why can't modern day hospitals utilise the philosophy that grounded this facility.? Supposedly being close to nature and able to view beauty would speed healing. Gorgeous mosaics, colorful tiled roofs, planned flower gardens amid fruit trees, bright and airy interiors were integrated into the concept of this series of hospital pavilions. The architectural features beg for photographers to record all aspects, outside and in. Highly recommend spending an afternoon when the lighting is best. Enjoy!

Wonderful Architecture and atmosphere! Pictures don't do it justice!. I had seen some pictures while planning our trip to the city and thought it was worth checking out. When we arrived in the site, € 7 each seemed to be a bit expensive for something we weren’t sure about. So, we went to the gift shop and flipped through a book and were immediately amazed by the pictures. We went in - and not disappointed at all! It is an incredible building that used to be a hospital – we were mesmerized by the details and its grounds. Just a few buildings are restored and open to the public, still, it was well worth the visit. We spent a long time just contemplating the walls, the shapes and colors; such beautiful architecture and peaceful atmosphere! We’re no experts in architecture and were immensely interested; I can imagine an architect would have a blast in this place. Very few tourists were visiting in the summer, so we could realize it is not very popular with the crowds. Shame for them, lucky us! It is a short walk from the station Sant Pau / Dos de Maig. If you’re interested in buildings, taking beautiful pictures and have time to spare, make sure to visit this place.

Excellent tour to see the works of modernist Lluís Domènech i Montaner:. Lluís Domènech i Montaner for many is a superb architect and designer to rival Gaudi. Apart from the Palau de la Musica Catalana this series of buildings once up until recent years a hospital is certainly an impressive example of his style.

Best site in Barcelona!. We stumbled across the Old Hospital while in Barcelona (it is a five minute walk from the Basilica) and it is by far one of the best finds! Not expensive, beautiful and there were hardly any people. During the 2 hours ish we were there, think we only saw about 5 other people. Amazing, beautiful, incredible and would definitely recommend a visit!

A photographer's dream. Incredible experience. We've visited many modernist sites across the city and this was the first time we've been able to come here since it opened to visitors. We purchased the ruta del modernisme book, and it's possible to get an accompanying voucher book, so we had a reduced price entry here.There was a private event on at the same time, which didn't interfere too much with our visit, except we had to exit from a different door. The buildings and gardens you can access are absolutely amazing. Don't hesitate about visiting, just go.The only negative experience was when I went to head out the main door at the end of our visit and a female security guard stepped in my way, vigorously waved her finger in my face and pointed to one of the visitor attendants who spoke english. I responded to the guard in Spanish, asking if I could help her and why she didn't just ask me to go the other way rather than the pointing, I speak Spanish. She shrugged and said "well I didn't know that". I work in a museum and if our guards had her attitude they'd be spoken to. Maybe a little less assumption on their part would be good. Overall some of the staff were the only things to let the visit down. Basics like greeting visitors with a smile when they enter a gallery, avoiding glaring at people, etc were missing and the staff lacked consistency. On the other hand, the reception ticket sales desk were helpful and friendly, as was the final visitor attendant wee saw. A bit of visitor training would be advantageous to their team.If you visit, make sure to have a glass of cava in the bar across from the entrance. It was great to sit outside next to the warm heaters and have a cold drink in December!
Visit modernists. Incredible visit. In less than one hour, you are able to have a taste of the modernists in Barcelona. We are from Barcelona and we enjoyed this visit

Can NEVER image such a beauty in a hospital !!. While the site is still under restoration and renovation, it is such an amazing place, that is located just outside a Metro station. I will never think of any hospital that is so rich in photography opportunity. I am sure glad that I did not miss this place that is so accessible. One can really appreciate the architect of the buildings of this old hospital (sitting just beside a REAL hospital). I can image myself spend another hour or so in this site, especially if more buildings are restored and open to the public. Highly recommended.

Do Not Miss This!. A short walk from Sagrada Familia and absolutely spectacular!
It's apparently not on everyone's tourist list but it should be. Incredible architecture, arts and fascinating history.
And, don't miss the beautiful book store.

Don't Miss This Gem in Barcelona. No one got off the hop on hop off bus when we stopped here, but if you like Art Nouveau, this is a MUST MUST MUST! It's just gorgeous and pretty peaceful since it's not a tourist trap. Some of the most stunning glass work you'll ever see. I highly recommend. It was only like 7 euros.

Enchanting!. I did not expect anything of this visit. I was given free entry tickets and decided to check it out. I was amazed from the start till the end and didn't want to leave. It's true that most buildings are closed, but even from the outside they are beautiful and so detailed. Hopefully they will renovate more of the buildings and allow entry into more parts of the main building. The shop has some nice things for sale. Next to the entrance is a cafe with outdoor seating. Food and drinks were nice and view unbeatable.Must visit!

Greatest Modernista Building in the World!. You can visit this Domenech i Montaner designed building in the Eixample district, and you can combine it with a visit to the nearby Sagrada Familia.I recommend the guided tour in English it's now at 12 and 1 p.m.You get a discount if you are under 29 years old.Me and my wife we did a guided tour of the building(approximately 60 min), it used to be a functional Hospital up until 2012, now they restored the hospital to it's formal glory.It's a feast for the eyes, great pavilions, great mosaics, great inner decoration!It's a must if you're visiting Barcelona!
Wonderful. If you bought tickts for the Sagrada Familia and you have to wait until you can enter, Then i recomend a visit to Sant Pau. It is a 15 min walk but you will be amazed by such beauty.

Relaxing & humanity. It's a great idea creating and developing a masterpiece for the unhealthy people in order to make them feel good even they're not at home. How generous to create an artistic and relaxing place for their well-being. Humanity and Art created especially for this medical center. The world should have more places like this.

A fascinating collection of repurposed historic buildings. The visit is to the overall site. Most of the buildings can't be visited as they are now offices mostly related to international issues. The fascination is the layout of gardens and architecture. Very cheap to visit. You have to go through the main building for the site to be revealed .. a charming surprise. Entry is via one of theunderground tunnels that used to link sections of the hospital it's original purpose. Designed by the same person as the Palau de Musica another gem.

Amazingly beautiful, never seen something like this before. I absolutely recommend this place, a former hospital till the 2010 in Barcelona, now converted into a place for art events and for hosting also dinners/drinks for business companies. We went there as company guest and we had a prive guide who told her a bit of the hospital history and we went a bit around (it is a huge place, like a cittadella ( a city inside the city, with many pavillions and streets). a beautiful Art Nouveau Site at its best.We had dinner (we were in 120 people) in the Administration Pavilion which was breath-taking. We had delicious tapas, and wines and at our arrival some Cava (Champagne). it was like to be in a fairytale place (like the Castel of Beauty and the Beast). Imponent, beautifully done, also a bit misterious. there was the full moon so it was a very special night!!!!!

On old Hospital entirely built with Art Nouveau features. The project is incomplete. You can only visit the central building and two more smaller pavilions. I didn't find it very interesting as I would like to see more of its history and features explained to the visitor. There is a hall that they actually present a movie but unfortunately only in Spanish (or Catalan?)On the smallest pavilion there is also a small exhibition explaining the progress of renovation, quiet interesting.The only thing you can do here is to admire the architecture which is really really beautiful and walk around the nice gardens (also under construction).This place is registered in UNESCO cultural heritage list, I expected more.

A sham. This tour is a sham. Only after paying, and given a useless brochure, does one actually discover most of the structures are under renovation, leaving only 3 to visit. Of these, only the outside grounds and the main building offer any significant access to design and history. Quite paltry viewing for 11 Euros, with no apology from the staff for their failure to mention the renovation when one pays, casually mentioning this reality is shown in the brochure. This should be clearly conveyed ahead of time but isn't. No refunds offered either. Barcelona's avarice for tourist money is almost embarrassing.. Buyer beware, and bring tough skin. Staff is brusque and cowering.

A must-see for architecture lovers. So glad we got here. Although it is not on the typical "must see" list of Barcelona attractions, if you enjoy modernisme, it is an incredible place. Not everything is Gaudi in Barcelona, as much as I love his work (and how much of it there is). Not at all far from Sagrada Familia and directly in line with it. Great views, stunning interiors in the buildings on the campus that are open to the public. The buildings themselves are pretty wonderful, and like Sagrada Familia, it is just calming to be here.

Amazing non-Gaudi architecture. Although I'm now a total Gaudi-phile, I really enjoyed my visit here. I went on a Saturday morning and it was a wonderful oasis of peace and tranquility awayy from the hustle and bustle of Barcelona.Lots to look at and plenty of places to sit and admire the fabulous architecture. I'm beginning to tire of saying this in my Barcelona reviews but 'well worth a visit'!
Totally worth the visit. Even it is not found in most of the travel guides, its visit is totally worth it. Just a few blocks away Sagrada Familia. Its architecture is awesome.

Do not miss this gem of a place. Overshadowed by the Sagrada Familia which is just a short stroll away, this place has a UNESCO world heritage site designation and deserves it. It is a real architectural masterpiece. The restoration is still in progress but it gave me even more appreciation for what is involved in preserving important buildings. It really is exquisite.

simply the best place in Barcelona. the most wonderful architectural spot I've seen in Barcelona and perhaps in my life. breathtaking! I could literally live there. Wonderful staff of the museum and whole organization.

Well worth thevisit. Not one of the sights on the top list onBarcelona, but it should be. This is a beautiful example of modernist a architecture in a hospital, of all places! The tile work is amazing and the gardens are really lovely. It should be on your list of sights to see in beautiful Barcelona.

Yet another MUST SEE in Barcelona :). On our fourth trip to Barcelona we finally managed to visit! This amazing hospital complex is simply beyond anything we were expecting. Sant Pau is a beautiful, very interesting and lovely way to pass a peaceful afternoon in Barcelona.We had free entry to the Hospital because there was a conference going on necessitating the closure of some parts but this did not spoil our visit. The renovation work being carried out is quite remarkable and watching some of the videos in various exhibits showing how the buildings have been renovated is fascinating.This beautiful complex of buildings is most certainly up there with the Sagrada Familia, Casa Mila and Palau de la Musica as a "must visit" on a trip to Barcelona

GO THERE!. A very special place, a hospital built in the early 20th century in the "moderniste" style (Art Nouveau Spanish), has been renovated and returned to its original grandeur. Only recently opened to visitors, not all buildings open to the public. Very interesting and beautiful.

A enjoyable retreat from the tourist hordes. Just a 5-6 block walk from Sagrada Familia, this amazing complex of Modernisme buildings might as well be in the countryside, for how little-visited it is. At least on my late-October visit, after leaving Sagrada Familia (with easily one or two thousand people milling around) the Hospital Sant Pau complex had perhaps 100 people visiting it. A complex of several buildings, all connected by underground tunnels and ground-level paths, it was a working hospital complex for many years (and the site of some form of hospital, since the Middle Ages.) A few of the 8 or 9 buildings are open currently -- the massive Administrative Building, with its astonishing grand staircase and impressive vaulted main room on the second floor, and then 3 other buildings behind it -- which were originally various wards of the hospital, such as Trauma, Obstetrics, etc. The smaller buildings are beautiful in their Modernisme style, with domes, towers and turrets, gargoyles, colorful tile, beautiful sculptural pieces, etc. Ornamentation everywhere, and just a delight to look at! The entire complex is closed off from the city around it -- you must go through the Admission desk to enter the complex, and once you do, it is practically an urban park; peaceful, spacious, and again on my visit, very nearly empty. After the crowds at Sagrada (which of course was amazing to see) and a quick tapas lunch, this was a wonderful, peaceful break for the afternoon. Highly recommended!

Underrated!. The beauty of this exceeds that of my expectations. It is more beautiful than some of the more higher rated places eg gaudi stuff. If you are there on the first day of the month it's free entry!

Beautiful architecture. This is a must on the Modernist architecture route in Barcelona. It is a beautiful example of the style, and is (more or less) open for exploration. It's a really cool site with all kinds of neat rooms and decor. We didn't take a guided tour, but they let us wander through the hospital. Really, really cool stuff. A few of the rooms were being used by various organizations while we were there, but they let us peek through windows. It's worthwhile to go into all of the open buildings, as they are all in different stages of renovation and offer unique design features.

One of the best places in BCN. This place is mindblowing!!! I cannot believe this isnt one of barcelonas main tourist spots... we saw many people take a picture at the main gate and leave... you should definetly go inside.

Modernist architecture at its best. Near the Sagrada Familia is the old Saint Paul's hospital, now a museum. A collection of 9 buildings designed by Montaner, Sant Pau is an architectural treasure. With both art nouveau and moderiste features and details it is certainly worth seeing and saving. In order to preserve this piece of Barcelona's heritage, buldings are being rented out to companies who will carefully renovate and preserve them. One is used as a museum and another as an art gallery for temporary shows. The administrative building remains part of the public trust. The central park is a lovely place to sit in the shade and relax while admiring the detailed ornamentation on each of the buldings. There is a small gift shop and cafes close by to round out the day with an ice cream, pastry or coffee.
Interesting and Beautiful. Well worth seeing, especially if you work in healthcare. Incredible setting for a hospital, so interesting and well worth seeing.

Very little access allowed, over priced and not worth the visit. In walking distance of Sagradi Familiia but not worth paying the entry fee to visit. The external architecture is stunning but there were so few places you were allowed to enter and rude staff telling us where we could not go, yet it isn't that clear if places are out of bounds. Security getting in is like going rough the airport security in you go through scanners, have to empty contents of handbags in some cases and all bags go through security scanners too and staff and not friendly! A cleaner told us off for entering a room which was suppose to be open to the public until 6:30pm but she was cleaning for end of day at 4:30pm! A security guard said you can not go upstairs but our guidebook said we could! The only buildings open besides part of main building was the toilet block, and two old hospital wards, one with curtains still in situe but nothing else in room, and another with photographs from Japan which had nothing to do with the place! We wanted to take photos at the front of main building but a model was having photos taken and the area was restricted so in all there was very little to look at and its expensive to get in to see nothing!

Absolutely spectacular. Called "A city within a city" this hospital built in 1920s operated until 2009 and is now being renovated as a tourist sight. The exterior architecture is amazing(along the lines of Gaudi).Just 3 buildings are renovated to date but they are working on more. Just walking the campus is worth the trip. Not far from La Segrada Familia.

Well worth the visit. The grounds, buildings, and interiors are simply stunning. More buildings and areas are being refurbished and opened, so expect some construction noise in some areas.Guidebooks may say you have to take a guided tour, but that is outdated. You are free to wander the grounds as you like.It is about 2 blocks from the St. Pau metro station, and there is a cab stand directly across from the main gate. (As you are exiting, it is to your right near the newspaper stand)

Wow Wow Wow not expected. The lady on reception at our apartment told us we should go to the Saint Paul hospital and look at the gardens. We were expecting an operational hospital not what we found but boy were we happy she sent us there. This is little known and has recently been opened after some restoration work. The former hospital is about 1K from Sagrada Familia and you can see the Basilica from the upstairs of the Administration building. Entry is 8 euros, less if a senior, and once inside you will find a city within the city. There are 8 buildings in the complex, all decorated with amazing external artwork. There are 3 buildings that you can enter including the administration building, don't miss the view from upstairs in both directions from that one.The whole complex with male and female sections, tunnels to access them, the beautiful gardens and the magnificent architecture is not to be missed. We spent over 3 hours there and I took approx. 200 photos.
Wonderful!. Personally, I adored it, the architecture was amazing. It was not as crowded as the other touristic venues.

Beautiful and fascinating.. This former hospital is quite simply stunning in all its features - a testament to the emphasis on the combination of care and architectural context. Parts of the complex were being worked on and closed to the public; still, worth the visit - a revelation!

Truly a hidden treasure. This relatively unknown site is well worth visiting and second only to Sagrada Familia in my opinion. As far as modernist buildings in the city go, it is better and less crowded than La Pedrera. It is not by Gaudi but a last known architect but it's absolutely stunning. The outside is fabulous but be sure and buy the 8 euro ticket to enter the complex. There are no lines at all. The are beautiful gardens inside and a complex of buildings, 3 of which you can enter. The administration building is not to be missed. It is still being restored but should be better promoted -we almost missed going there.
Less known but worth the visit. Really nice visit. Beautiful yard with nice buildings. Not expensive and not so crowded with tourists.

Do just after or before Sagrada Familia- -worth the visit. After having completed a tour of the Sagrada Familia at 12:10, we walked the avenue connecting it to the San Pau for a guided tour of Sant Pau in English at 1:00. We made it in plenty of time and were even able to duck in a cafeteria for a snack on the way. This is the site of an old hospital and was designed by Montraner (same as the Palau de la Musica). In this case I would recommend the guided tour -there were only four of us, it took less than an hour, and the guide took us to a couple of rooms that were roped off from visitors. The ceilings here are amazing. I would highly recommend the visit and it's easy to couple with a visit to the Sagrada Familia. We took a cap from the Gothic Quarter- -it was 9 Euro there and 8 Euro back.

Worthy site. - Was recommended this tourist site by Palau de la Musica tour guide (Montaner designed both the Palau and this hospital)- Not crowded at all since relatively few people know about it (Rick Steves doesn't even mention it in his guide book!)- 10-15 minute walk from Sagrada Familia, or take blue/L5 subway line to Sant Pau/Dos de Maig

Unique and beautiful. It has an oriental air. I hadn't known about it until I saw it, but although it's not that famous as Sagrada and Batlo House, it must deffinetely not be missed when visiting Barcelona!

Magical palace of stained glass, tile, and domes. This place is truly wonderful - Gaudi lovers eat your heart out! The architecture of this lovingly restored set of hospital pavilions from the early 20th century will knock your socks off. Wander through the open ones, visit all the exhibits, and take in the gorgeous display of color, sculpture, and light.

Beautiful architecture. Beautiful architecture and tile work, this is the site of an old hospital. The park like garden offers a quiet retreat from the busy streets, the long corridors remind when they were filled with patient beds, with doctors and nurses bustling around.

A must near Sagrada Familia. An ancient, unfinished hospital complex built in Moderniste style.The buildings are magnificent, the decorations, the colors and the frescoes vibrant and alive.Only a couple of hundred meters from Sagrada Familia and scarcely visited, this is an architectural gem that can be fully appreciated in an hour, an hour and half.
Restored hospital .... in Art Nouveau style, opened since 2014, about 1 km from Sagrada Familia. You can walk through the different restored buildings with magnificent ceramic walls.

A recently opened art nouveau UNESCO world heritage site in central Barcelona. Not so well known yet so fairly quiet. Once the site of an old hospital with 12 pavilions linked by underground and dating back to 1401. Beautiful architecture and tiling. Not to be missed.

Surprise Splendid Barcelona Modernista Complex. ---NB: aka Hospital de la Sta Creu; confused w/ another TripAdvisor site--Easy subway access, now UNESCO World Heritage Site and worthy addn to BCN art/ architecture. This architecturally splendid large site of former hospital complex is a pleasure to view. Underground links are former patient transfer corridors. Walk distance to Sagrada Familia. Go if art/ architectural buff and love Modernista architecture.

Incredible!. We nearly missed this, but on our last day, we thought we'd go have a quick look just to see. It was a hospital, so we figured there would be a nice building. Maybe two.We were completely unprepared for an entire complex of gorgeous buildings. Many are in use, so you can't enter, but you can go in some to see what it might've been like when it was in use (which was apparently quite recently).In the administrative building, one section features holographic doctors and patients, which was amusing.It's not exactly hidden at the opposite end of Avinguda Gaudi from Sagrada Familia, but even on a weekend, it was sparsely attended so it was pleasant to stroll around the grounds admiring the architecture and landscaping, then to take our time marveling at the tile and stained glass everywhere. Like so many of the things we experienced in Barcelona, this exceeded our wildest expectations and we would highly recommend it!

Stunning buildings and excellent tour. I had never heard of this beautiful site but would recommend it to anyone visiting Barcelona. The staff are clearly very passionate about the building and it's history.

Hidden Gem!. This amazing piece of architecture is definitely under advertised. Inexpensive to access and with no queues I would choose this option over many others. I only knew to visit as it was recommended by the hotel owners, and I found its history and the current renovation back to its original structure fascinating.

Often overlooked. I actually thought this was a Gaudi site until I found out it was done by his contemporary, Montaner, who I guess was a competitor. Originally a hospital, it features colorful tiles and vaulted ceilings, like Gaudi's work, and must have been very cheering to the patients. This is a short walk from La Sagrada Familia. One hour guided tours are given a few times a day. They should be booked in advance.

Architectural wonder by Gaudi's teacher. Modernist architectural gem, still to be discovered by the masses, it seems. Features a wealth of architectural detail (amazing tiled walls and ceilings, rich colours,...). Beautifully restored and tastefully 're-adapted' for visitation and present-day use. Stone-throw away from the Sagrada Familia, and definitely worth a little detour at the very least.
A nice surprise, free to visit, work still on-going but worth the time. Former Hospital now undergoing extensive work to bring it back to former beauty, another example of modernism in Barcelona

Unique Expericence Visiting this incredible Modernistic Site...what many might not know.... This beautiful complex, is captivating in how the architect combined beauty with function to help the sick. Starting as a small hospital the former Hospital de la Santa Creu located in the Raval neighborhood needed to be relocated, as it became too small for Barcelona's developing and growing population....So, architect Lluis Domènech built this hospital on his belief that our surroundings and beautiful environment, such as trees, flowers and fresh air were more likely to have a positive impact, and effect by helping people recover from illness more than anything doctors could do in a sterile, functional environment on their own. So he combined beauty, nature with hospital technology and Barcelona ended up with a hospital that was simply magnificent. The sculptures and mosaics, make the buildings even more interesting. The hospital had always been associated with new discoveries in medicine, charities, all things positive. So, in 1978, the Modernista was listed as a Historic Artistic Monument, and in 1997 it became a UNESCO World Heritage site. The building began somewhere around 1905, and finished in 1930. The former hospital complex is now a knowledge campus and the headquarters of several international organizations. What I didn't know until I took the tour, and read up on him is that Domènech joined the School of Architecture first as a lecturer, and later became its director in 1900. During his time there he trained students such as Josep Puig i Cadafalch, and the incredible Antoni Gaudí. Ahh, so Gaudi learned and incorporated some magnificent architecture from Domènech, so it is great that the master, even though his modernist architecture is not off the wall, or unique in the same way as some of Gaudi's works, it is incredibly beautiful and magnificent and needed to be celebrated. Put this on your bucket or to see list when in Barcelona.

Breath taker. This is off the beaten path attraction. Close to the Sagrada Familia but not yet touristy. Great architecture by Montaner. I enjoyed this place better than Parc Guell. The colors are so alive. I will have not matter to be a patient in this hospital.

Very interesting. Once you get in you can visit only 3 buldings in the area where visitors are alllowed. In the main buiding parts of ground floor and first floor. A saloon where they kept the the pacients and a building where received the pacients and quarantined them. Also you can walk in the yard and see the other ones from outside.

A nice suprise. This was well worth the visit. We did a guided tour but I think you could get just as much out of the visit by walking around on your own. Much of the experience is viewing the buildings and interiors and reading the explanations as you tour. There is a very good guide book that comes with the admission. Doing it again I would plan for a self guided tour after a visit to the Sagrada Famalia....it is only a short walk away. Another nice aspect was the lack of crowds.

Quiet Gem. This is one of Barcelona's under-appreciated gems. It was a lovely hospital campus built 100 years ago in a style that mixed neo-gothic with art nouveau and it fell into great disrepair. It is now restored and much of it is open to the public. The architect was Gaudi's teacher and Gaudi makes more sense if you have seen how he grew from this less crazy but still ornamental style. It is fascinating to see what was envisioned as an ideal therapeutic setting 100 years ago, and it is still a quiet oasis in Barcelona with dazzling tile-work and architecture.

Such a beautiful place. Such a beautiful and peaceful place. Stunning in the sun and entry is only cheap plus discount if you are under 29. Amazing architecture and brick work and very interesting when it used to function as a hospital. Like a city inside a city .

Gorgeous mosaics. So interesting that when Barcelona built a public hospital in the early 1900s, they chose to make it beautiful. A few of the original buildings have been restored, and the grounds are lovely. See it now, and return when more restoration is complete and the planned Modernista museum is open.
Magnificent hospital pavillions. This place holds / hosts the hospital where I studied Medicine, fond memories. Magnificent architecture, wise and crazy. Visit it in the Fall, if you can.
A must for architecure lovers. A huge complex designed by Lluis Montaner, several buildings to visit and a beautiful garden/yard. Interresting details such as mosaics, sculptures,roofs,....
What a gem..... What a surprise. Beautiful architecture combined with the fascinating story of its' restoration. Combine this with a trip to Sagrada Familia

Relax and breathe. This is by far most relaxing place in Barcelona. Few tourists were there while i was visiting the site. It is thousant time more beautiful than anything i ve ever seen in Barcelona. It is hidden jewel.
Nice quiet spot. Lovely quiet spot to recover after the crowds at the Sagrada! Beautiful architecture and gardens. Probably not a must see if you don't have my time but well worth a look.

A real surprise!. Having visited Barcelona previously I wanted to see something new, and something away from the usual crowds, and what surprise this was. Only five minutes walk from the Sagrada and yet quiet and peaceful. A stunning collection of buildings.

One of the best new attractions!. You'd think... what's so good about an old hospital... but what you are seeing is not only history, but the meticulous design of this place and the $$$ it costs to build. Built by the rival of Gaudi, Catalan modernist architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. Unlike Gaudi, this guy can build well and on time. I don't want to spoil it for you but don't cheap out and definitely go on the tour. The groups are small enough for questions and the English guide we had explained everything very well. Picture in there are amazing... it wasn't busy so you feel like you can take pictures for yourself and they sure are beautiful. As they are still restoring things, you'll likely see more than I did. So please do share them when you visit.
Don't miss this one.. Don't miss this amazing hospital and gardens. They are near the Sagrada Familia and well worth the visit. It will replenish your weary body and soul.
Sagrada Familia. Inspirational--not to be missed. Absolutely beautiful! Reserve enough time to enjoy this basilica--it is rich in history and art. Worth the extra time to visit the interior.

Beauty for the sick people. A history of a generous society. An emotional visit.. First stop in Barcelona based on the beautiful buildings, the amazing history and the art work inside. Bring camera. Take about 1 hour and is a nice walk from Sagrada Familia.

Very impressive Art Nouveau site. This place is a wonderful masterpiece of the architect Lluis Domenech i Montaner. Still under renovation it is more than worth a visit for people visiting Barcelona and those who are interested in Art Nouveau architecture. The different buildings, the ornaments, the colors and the interiors are splendid and impressive. I would like to see the whole complex when the renovation is finished.

Discovering Luis Domenech y Montaner. I visited the Hospital de San Pau with my father, also if I visited the Hospital alone also last year. It`s always amazing the conception of this hospital, that is rich of beautiful decorations realized by Luis Domenech y Montaner. He was the other great architecht that with Gaudi makes of Barcelona a so beautiful and modern city. There was a peaceful and intelligent competition between the two artists, capturing each other inspirations to make always the best of their best (if posible). In fact, the facade and upper window of the Hospital of St Pau watch the Sagrada Familia, as to créate a corridor between the 2 architectures and as source of relieve for hospitalized patients .

Beautiful buildings, interesting history. I stumbled upon this one by accident, actually - I had just gone to the hospital for an ear infection (I hate being sick overseas!!) and I was walking towards the cathedral when I saw this beautiful set of buildings and wanted to go in and explore. The architecture was really beautiful and it was an interesting history too.
Don't make a special trip.... Well preserved architectural site and beautiful architecture but most of the buildings are closed off and the exhibits aren't very compelling.

WOW! Really worth a visit!. This is an incredible building designed by Lluís Domènech i Montaner (and some bits were completed by his son though these sections of the building do not have UNESCO protection) and was a working hospital until 2009. The hospital has been painstakingly restored and a guided tour was well worth the money. We learnt a great deal about the benefactor Pau Gil, and the clever design by Lluís Domènech i Montaner including underground transportation tunnels that connect all 14 recuperation pavilions, beautiful tiles in the dormitories, and sun rooms for the patients. There is an excellent exhibition in-house about the restoration of the hospital and future plans. Also, parts of Vicky Cristina Barcelona were filmed here and the guides have some stories about this as well. Really recommend this sight, well worth the time.

The surprising building at the Avenida Gaudi End. Our intention was to have a walk waiting the time to enter the Sagrada Familia when we discovered the beautiful Sant Pau. I was impressed by the architectural harmony of the area.

If I was sick back then, that would be the hospital to go to. This was a hospital that was cutting edge for its time. It was sited for contagion containment but build for function and aesthetically captivating. It is now being converted to a museum. The grounds were beautiful, the buildings were bellissimo, and the inside were magnifique! All summarized by bonito! If only all hospitals were this beautiful.
