This is a vast complex that was being restored. What was available for us to see was worth visiting. When it is fully done, it would be worth a third visit to Barcelona just to see it in its full glory. This was an easy to get to destination. We walked there then took a nearby subway to our next point of interest.
Beautiful buildings. Beautiful architecture and interesting history.Photgraher's playground. This hospital was very advanced in the treatment of patients
A great couple of hours. This complex is worth your time. Its really beautiful and fun to explore. Not all the buildings have been restored but, the ones that have are amazing.

Very beautiful. I had a chance to visit this beautiful place and see the concert of Sobrinos (musica catalana), it was a great place for such an event. Everything was organised very well, nice weather and breathtaking views of the buildings were incredible. If you have a chance, go there and see it from inside.

A true gem. Even though it's not such a popular attraction, it's very beautiful and has a unique touch. The hospital complex is partially open for visiting and some parts of it are under reconstruction. It's very close from Sagrada Familia.

Precious!. This place is just a stone's throw from La Sagrada Familia and when we visited on a sunny Saturday afternoon there was hardly no one! The place is precious, beautiful buildings with a fairytale feel. Definitely a lot nicer place to visit that the tourist packed Sagrada Familia. For those who love tranquility and incredible architecture, don't miss this! Entrance fee is 8€ and it is worth it, even though you can only visit 3 of the many pavilions and you are probably done in less than an hour.

An oasis of calm in a busy city. Spent a lovely 2 hours here. Booked for a guided tour which was lovely and spent another hour walking around the grounds. So peaceful away from the crowds at the catherdral.

Very interesting.. I studied at one of the buildings of the once before, Hospital Sant Pau. I did the tour through the touristic buildings and it was very good, with many explanations. There you can really see Modernism from the hand of other architects other than Gaudí.
Lovely visit. Amazing place to visit and surprisingly, very few tourists. We had the best time wandering through the incredible architecture. It is like you've entered another world!

A hidden gem in Barcelona!. Just a stroll away from Sagrada Familia, this place is a must see, especially if you're an architecture lover. Lots of beautiful spots to take pictures & it's not too crowded. I was very happy have found this place.

Beautiful!. Not a lot of people visit this place (since there was almost no one except me and my friend visiting this place at the same time) but this place is a must!!! It had such beautiful building that I could break my ankle and run into the hospitals immediately. It's 10-15min walking from Sagrada Familia, so if you are planning to visit Sagrada Familia, this is an excellent side-dish.

Beautiful art nouveau. This is a complex of hospital buildings in the art nouveau style. It is located a short stroll from Sagrada Familia, but unlike Sagrada it is not crowded. The buildings are mostly empty but you can still see their decorative features and there is a lot of explanation on the history and site restoration. It is well worth a visit. The buildings are quite lovely as are the surrounding gardens.

More than just an old hospital. They've been holding an excellent series of musical event through the summer. There were amazing band playing right in the Recinto in the frame of the beautiful building.

One of the old Hospitals at town. Sant Pau Recinte Modernista is one of the old hospitals at town but still active. Last years several refurbishment had been done and the most pavilions are open again.

Surprisingly not Gaudi. Huge complex of buildings used to be a hospital. Now most buildings are empty with authorities seem to run out of ideas what to do with this biggest in the world modernist district. Some of former wards are filled with temporary exhibitions, while most of them are just closed for visitors. The most attractive parts are outdoors anyway. It doesn't take that long to browse around all of this district, so it is worth a short detour from Sagrada Familia, as it's just up the road. This whole complex is listed on Unesco heritage list.

Brilliant. This wonderful gem of Art Nouveau has been opened to visitors in 2009 because it was still used as an hospital as it was designed for initially. It is a UNESCO world heritage site. Guided tours are great. The main pavilion decor is astonishing (at the time of the construction, even the king was mad at the hospital builders for having built a palace for sick persons looking better than his own!).

Wonder why I didn't go earlier.. This was the fourth time we visited Barcelona. After already have seen every Gaudi-building and some other mondernista buildings, we now made time to visit the hospital. Well, the hosptial surely was a surprise. If you visit Barcelona and want to visit art nouveau places, put this on you top-list next to the Sagrada familia and Casa batllo. You don't need a guide to visit. And, as other reviews also mention, there are not many visitors. I took a lot of foto's without some people on it.
Breathtaking architecture. For those who like modernism, like me, was a breakthrough. A huge complex, several buildings open to the public, an excellent recovery of an exceptional complex.

Hospital de la Sant Pau (old) i Santa Creu (new). You can find this beautiful building when you go behind Sagrada Familia through Avinguda de Gaudí. The new part Santa Creu is not so interesting but the old one Sant Pau is great.

One of BCN's best sites!. One of Barcelona's finest displays of urban planning and moderniste architecture, take the guided tour which offers an insightful look at the city, its growth and development. This is truly spectacular and one of the city's hidden gems. Come before or after Sagrada Familia (it's nearby) and you won't regret it! Book your tour in advance.

Perfect place for photos.. Famous place and has a long history. Also it is still functioning as a hospital and a good attraction. It is also near Sagrada Familia, so you can walk up to this place after your visit in Sagrada Familia.

Why do people not know about this!?. It's soooo pretty! Both inside and out. It's also really empty which makes a very welcome change from places like the Sagrada Familia or Parc Guell. Really nice just to wander about, take some photos, or maybe just sit and relax. I'd imagine it will be even better once all of the restorations are complete and more of the buildings are opened.
More stars needed my favorite attraction. This is a true must see just for the tile work. The scale is enormous. the restoration flawless, the plantings lovely. My absolute favorite.
Nice inside the main building....a bit pricy. Near the sagrada, it was nice. The main building was pretty, but if you are tight on cash just look at it from the outside.

Beautiful. This is one of the Modernist jewels of Barcelona, one of the city's best kept secrets.It has been recently remodelled, completing the transition from a hospital to an office space and venue. The gorgeous interiors of the original building are brought back to life. Several agencies, including some UN's, have their headquarters here.The visit is worth the while, being just a short and pleasant walk from the Sagrada Familia.Bonus points: gorgeous skyline pictures of Barcelona (form the Agbar Tower to the Sagrada Familia and the Vela Hotel, and the sea). Tip: call ahead of time to make sure there are tour sin your language (highly recommended) and that all areas are open to the public (when we visited, there was a conference and we made it on time before the close the main, most beautiful rooms).

Best attraction in Barcelona. I visited Sant Pau on a Monday afternoon after spending the morning at La Sagrada Familia. It was so easy to walk between the two, a straight road that runs diagonally, so very difficult to get lost. We arrived in time for the 1pm English tour and so opted for that rather than a self-guided tour as we knew nothing about the site. The tour had approx. 15 people on it and this meant we also got to visit places in the main building that would have otherwise been unavailable to us. Entry wasn’t cheap but was most definitely worth it; our guide was very knowledgeable and you were given a fairly substantial guide that covered the history of the site. The architecture looked pretty forward thinking for us in 2015, so I can’t imagine what the Barcelona people thought when it was first built. Some of the photos we took here were amazing. The colours are incredible - the yellow tiles on the roof, green tiled walls and pink ceilings inside the buildings. The main thing I noticed (particularly after La Sagrada Familia) was the lack of crowds. You could easily take photos of the site with no one else in shot. It really didn’t feel like you were in the centre of a main city, a little bubble of calm. The site was the best thing we did in Barcelona and I highly recommend!

Art noveau delight!. AWESOME! AWESOME! AWESOME! my husband had done his research and recommended that we go see this - we have been to Barcelona previously but mostly to see Gaudi stuff - so this made a pleasant change!Firstly it was not mobbed with people as much of the rest of Barcelona is (I actually have photos with no-one in them!!!) and this alone made it feel like a rare treat. The place itself is fascinating and utterly beautiful (if you like art noveau). We did the English language tour and whilst it wasn't especially informative we did get to visit places you don't get to with the audio guide alone so that was cool. I would definitely recommend!

An Art Nouveau City within the city of Barcelona. Originally conceived as a hospital in 1587, a Catalan banker allotted part of his legacy in 1896 to the construction of a new hospital. Under the direction of the doyen Catalan Modernisme architecture, the site consists of 6 finished pavillions, each an Art Nouveau gem.with expansive gardens.Today it it has evolved into an international research center & campus for international organizations such as the UN, WHO and cultural center. The innovative construction- underground tunnels,-with holograms of patients wheeled by nurses, link the Pavilions ..each building is wonderfully imbued with Art Nouveau artistic details in the ceramics ,mosaics ,wood,marble,metal work , art glass windows & domes. Walk the tree-lined closed streets leading to the site for boutique shops & cafes. Many bus lines from the center of town connect to the site. A Must-Go for Art Nouveau fans.
Beautiful. amazing, beautiful, a lot the history, we are impress about the technique in the design and colorful
An amazing building!!. we visited this building when it was an open day, great the way they have kept all the original inside.

Beautiful Art Nouveau building with a rich history. This was by far the most beautiful visit during my stay in Barcelona in January 2015. The complex was originally built as a hospital and opened in 1930 as the Hospital de la Santa Creu i Satnt Pau. After extensive renovations the site was reopened as a museum in February 2014. There are now twelve pavilions left of the original "City within a City" of which each originally had it's own medical function. The pavilions are interconnected with each other by underground corridors. The buildings are a beautiful example of the so called Modernisme català or Catalan Modernism movement (approx 1880 - 1911) which made it's own variation of the Art Nouveau / Jugendstil movement in other parts of Europe. Many traces of this movement can be found throughout the city, most notable from Antoni Gaudí The main building has stunning ceramics and beautiful staircases Not to be missed!

A must-see in Barcelona. The former hospital, undertook a detailed renovation and face lift, and recently opened for tourists. Interesting not only for the stunning architectural work but also as an example of revolutionary change in approaching the illness and patient care in Europe of the times. As it is a newly opened site, it has not made its ways in the tourist books so it is saved huge tourists crowds that Barcelona safers from.

The most surprising thing in Barcelona. This was undoubtedly the highlight of my stay in Barcelona. The complex is already beautiful in itself, but it all gets even more surprising when you think it was built (more than 100 years ago) to be a hospital. I would almost be willing to go to hospital when ill if the hospital were like this, ha. The shining sun of midday was extremely hot, but it also gave the whole construction a scintillating and lively atmosphere that exalted its colours and its details at best. Superb guided tour in English, rich in explanations and curiosities. Missing this place if you are in Barcelona would be a crime. ;-)

Beautifull Building. My family and I walked there after visiting La Sagrada Familia.We used the Av. de Gaudi to get there. It's a very nice walk, with shades, almost empty, although there are many restaurants there.The building itself is very nice, but I would not make it a top priority visit site.I did not enter the building, so there's nothing I can write about its inside.

Sant Pau 'Disneyland ' Hospital Barcelona. Feel Good Archtecture - A masterpeace clearly made with love in the past and the present.Craftsmanship of superior quality. Very friendly and helpfull personnel and well kept site from garden to interior. Colourfull and surprinsingly beautiful it has all the looks of a disneyland building on the outside and hundred times more on the inside.Still unknown and unloved by the masses this hospital allows a calm and interesting visit for several hours if you take the time to see the detail and learn the history. Congratulations to all that made it happen in 1905 and today. THE NUMBER 1 PLACE to visit in Barcelona if you ask me.

A marvel, inside and out!!. I initially was only enjoying the outside, and taking pictures of the beautifully sculptured walls and statues, but I ended up engaging in a "game" with 2 pick-pocketers, who I noticed following me from a café up the street. I started like I was going to the restroom, (outside the entrance) they'd begin to follow, then I'd abruptly turn and walk back out, and they'd bump into one another getting out of the way...we did this about 3 times until I asked, "Are we done yet?" And I then proceeded to go inside - you had to pay 8 euros - so they didn't follow - and I was blown away at the works of art everywhere! The mosaic work was stunning! The gargoyles, the statues emoting all types of emotions, the history of the facility, the beautiful "jardins" (gardens, full of sqwaking parakeets) were all amazing! And (you're only allowed into part of the first building, as well as it's second floor), was breathtaking. The art was fantastic, the colors were every bit as vibrant today as they were over 100 years ago...it HAS to be a must see if you're visiting Barcelona - just one of the wonderful places to visit in an AMAZING city!!!

Incredible place full of senses. I never considered this place as a must, until my friend insisted and invited me there. Its extremelly interesting place with the richest historical background.My advices:- its a MUST in your BCN tourist list;- take a guided tour!!! There are plenty of interesting stories around this hospital.

I wish all hospitals could look like this!. A chance to wander around amazing architecture without the crowds.We went around 4pm and were just about the only visitors. It was wonderful to be able to linger and admire the beautiful designs and take lots of photos for inspiration.
A gem!!. We really enjoyed our visit there. It's a paradise for anyone who enjoys architecture. It's a large place, so much to look at, and extremely well-preserved.

HIdden gem in early stages of becoming a museum. This is one of modernist jewels, just recently converted from hospital to something else - museum, conference center, college. Buildings are being repurposed and restored. Not much to see inside, but great complex overall and no crowds. Highly recommended!

Much more than a former hospital - a true Modernist architectural jewel. Why would one want to visit a hospital, right? This is what I thought until a friend convinced me to visit Sant Pau Recinte Modernista. I love Modernisme (Catalan Art Nouveau) and Domenech i Montaner's hospital complex certainly delivered. It is drop-dead gorgeous! Down to the landscaping, even. It is a fantastic example of the harmonious marriage between architectural design and functionality. Don't miss it! You can combine it with a visit to the Sagrada Familia, not far down the road.

A hospital like no other. I can't believe this place was built as a hospital and until fairly recently continued to operate as one. A lovely place to stroll along to after visiting the Sagrada. I have spend 20+ years in health care and have never been inside a hospital like it - will definitely put a smile on your face.

Learnt a few interesting facts. This former hospital is interesting to visit to see how patient treatment was organised. The staff were really friendly and overall helpful. The downside is the price (8 euros), which seems a bit excessive, as most of the architecture is visible from the outside. The upside - not touristy at all!

Really a city within a city, must visit. We got there early and no many visitors yet, the place was so peaceful. Beautiful buildings, lots of history and we were able to sit in the garden, under the shade of a tree, cooling down and just relaxed a bit. Every corner we looked, there is something special, i found this place much more atmospheric than Sagrada Familia.

Over 25 amazing hospital buildings. Saint Pau which is a UNESCO world heritage site. The hospital has undergone an art nouveau restoration and is spectacular both in the day and at night. The buildings have multicolored roof tiles as well as stylized figures at the top of the spires on each building.

Beautiful place, no tourist trap, interesting history. One of the few things in Barcelona without the enormous amount of tourists. Not to expensive and most information in English. Beautiful maquette. Still partly in renovations. You can visit 2 pavilions and the outside courtyard. Nice outside atmosphere.

Very interesting, hospitals should all look like this. If you have time, I would recommend checking out this hospital. It is very inspirational and helped to shape my perspective of life in barcelona in the past when this hospital was in full use. I imagine the mental, emotional, and spiritual healing of he patients was aided strongly by their surroundings in Sant Pau. The only problem I had is that there are so many buildings, sections of buildings, and sections of the underground tunnels that are not accessible currently. I think some of the buildings are still in use, which is understandable, but some of the buildings and sections are cordoned off without explanation. It's worth seeing but hopefully they can open up more of the compound to public use to allow for greater value. Also, there are exits that they just don't let you use for no reason.

Beautiful and serene Modernist masterpiece. GET THERE BEFORE IT BECOMES TOO POPULAR!I predict Sant Pau will soon be overrun by tourists like the Sagrada familia (a stone throw away) is.It is a delight of modernist architecture, the philosophy that went behind its planning was ahead of its time and still is.It's a feast for the eyes and a welcome break in the city as the garden is lovely and you can sit there for a while.It's not all refurbished yet and it's interesting to see some of the 'before' as you realize what a massive job is being undertaken.Just outside there is a bar/restaurant, we only had drinks and it was fine, it's clearly aiming for the 'trendy' category.

Stunningly beautiful place to heal. If only the modern world could value all factors of healing. The architect and leaders of this charity hospital get it right: beauty heals along with the hard work of medical expertise. Immaculate architectural and artisan effort comes to fruition!

beautiful quiet spot. This place is not far from Sagrada Familia and is a lot quieter. The area between the buildings is beautiful and the usher on the grounds was very helpful when I asked her questions about the place. The inside is very bright and you can get a nice photo of the Sagrada Familia in the distance.
This is a place to enjoy at your leisure.. I believe this place is often overlooked but shouldn't be. The architecture is very impressive and the history of the entire complex is rather amazing.

well worth it. this is a huge complex, beautiful, ornate buildings with lots of frescoes and mosaics which you can easily see from outside. short queues to enter. worth a trip - there are toilets and a bar in the complex.
Nice looking old hospital. Nice looking old hospital. Part of hospital is still working hospital. Few buildings was closed for renovation.

Beautiful place, oasis of calm. Away from the throngs at Sagrada Familia this is an oasis of calm and tranquility. A beautiful place, with a fascinating history, strongly recommend this as a place to visit. We didnt feel a need for a tour, the buildings speak for themselves. Inspirational.
Highlight of Barcelona. Definitely off the main tourist track, this place is spectacular. The architecture is astounding - the ceramic work is a veritable feast for the eyes! I loved it.

Absolutely Stunning. Although relatively pricey, you will be stunned by the beauty of the buildings inside here. The history of the building is interesting, and there are a couple of rooms with insightful exhibits. Only the cathedrals of Barcelona can match the sights to be seen here.

Don't miss this quiet gem!. Loved the buildings with lots of architectural details. No need for a guide. The book they provide has sufficient details. The crowds are small as most people don't visit. Don't miss!
Sant Pau. Beautiful restoration, lovely attraction-an hour of quiet beauty in the city- worth a visit- skip the café.

great suggestion. we visited Sagrada de Familia and we were turned off of the super long wait (even though it was expected) and our hotel staff suggested Sant Pau. Great attraction, not crowded, cheap and the train stops right in front of it. This is my second favorite, after Park Guell. You can also download an app so you can listen to it while touring the area. Just bring your own headphones.

Worth a visit but don't take the tour!. The campus of the former hospital is filled with Lluís Domènech i Montaner designed buildings. Visitors can see former hospital wards, the system of underground tunnels, and the administration building. This building has an amazing interior. DO NOT take the tour---there is way too much about the history of the donors and hospital.

Worth a small detour from Sagrada Familia. Very nice place to visit if you like architecture. Was once a hospital, still partially in use but a couple of the old wards can be visited and give a good impression what it was like to be hospitalized 100 years ago. Originally intended for poor people.Some of the rooms can be rented for dinner and festivitiesAbsolutely worth the small walk from Sagrada Familia.

Beautiful.. A great find. We did our research and booked ahead on a tour - ensuring we managed to get a tour in the most appropriate language. The buildings and open spaces are so beautiful and it would have been delightful to be in the hospital there when it was a working hospital. Not far from the Sagrada Familia and well worth the stroll a little further. Also much quieter and no queue when we were there (having booked online). We took the underground - the station is located at the entrance to the new hospital so you have to walk round the block to get to the entrance. Although the tour was good the girl was very quiet and it was sometimes difficult to hear her if you were not right beside her. Go and visit before it becomes ever more popular with the tourists as I expect it will.

A real find and close to Sagrada Familia. Most everyone who goes to Barcelona will visit Sagrada Familia. A lucky few will stroll down the tree lined diagonal street (before or after Sagrada) to see this architectural masterpiece that was until recent years a functioning hospital! It almost makes one wish for illness because the hospital wards are/were beautiful. Compared to the dank and dark mid century hospitals that were built in the US this is leaps and bounds better. It's even preferable to the sort of sleek hotel like vibes you get from more modern hospitals; I have a sense that this place felt alive and beautiful, not like a depressing asylum or a soulless hotel-like modern hospital,Each structure is divided into provision of care for certain types of problems. Alas most are not open to the public but San Rafael and San Jordi are so you can get a sense of what the place was like when it was working. And the structures that are not open to the public are being put to good use for global public health agencies.Setting aside the buildings themselves this place is so peaceful early in the day. We arrived exactly at opening time and really enjoyed the scenery and serenity of the place with very few crowds. Highly recommended!

Modernist architectural masterpiece. This is a worthwhile tour of a beautiful public hospital. Not many of the outer buildings are open to the public, and only some parts of the tunnel network, but it's a fascinating view into state-of-the-art public medicine in the early 20th century.

Beautiful Tranquil Sant Pau. We found this beautiful old hospital by chance after we left the Sagrada Familia . My husband and I love to walk through the back streets to experience the local culture and as luck would have it we came across Sant Pau. The grounds that this old hospital is situated is stunning and the buildings beautiful; a definite air of peace and tranquility there. Not all of them have been renovated but the ones that you are able to see are truly magnificent. There is quite a bit of history behind the hospital which was decommissioned in 1978 and the display is very informative. Feel very lucky to have walked in to Sant Pau by chance. Well worth seeing.

dont miss it.. a very beautiful place.amazing buildings.marvelous architecture.very nice gardens.a film that tell the history of the place.a splendid administraion builging who is like a musium with paintings,sculptures and painted celling.

Beautiful!!. When planning the trip I didn't even notice this and we just happened to bump into it by chance. It was amazing! Absolutely gorgeous buildings and loved the reconstruction of the patio, and the added bonus like the holograms in the tunels!! Also not as expensive as most tourist attractions in Barcelona

AIrport bus - excellent service. Very quick and easy way to get from airport into the city - they run frequently and go right into Playa catalyuna which was perfect for us as we were staying near la rambla. Good value too.

beautiful!. This is a very beautiful UNESCO site, and would recommend for self tour (no need to follow guides). Good to bring a sandwich or an orange and sit in the central space to enjoy the scene with orange trees, lavender amid the blocks of funny and beautiful building. Also one of the sites with most washrooms :)
Simply gorgeous! Shouldn't miss it!. The architecture is astonishing. The gardens are beautiful. It's close to Sagrada Familia but is less crowded. Really worth spending an hour or more here!

Magnificent. We weren't going to bother seeing this disused hospital, but we are very glad we got off the bus! The buildings are exceptional, truly wonderful and have been superbly restored. Well worth a visit.

An overlooked gem?. We discovered this on our City Bus tour. it is well worth a "hop off" and more.Wonderful architecture! It is described as "a city within a city" . Originally a hospital This Arte Nouveau site was declared a World Heritage site in 1997. Six pavilions have been finished and two are currently undergoing restoration. The gardens are lovely, designed by Domenech to create a "cheerful, optimistic atmosphere that would alleviate the pain and suffering of patients and their families and contribute to the patient's recovery". Don't miss the sculptures and the ceramics.

Visit only if you have nothing else to do!. We decided to visit this place as we were in the area, after being to Sagrada Familia and having 2 hours to kill before our pre-booked time for the Parc Guel started. The site is pretty and the buildings are nice - but that was it. There were not many visitors and the ticket was relatively cheap, and I could see why after visiting it for myself...

Don't miss this when you visit the Sagrada Familia.. About a 5-7 minute walk, straight up the lovely Avenue Gaudi, is this hospital created by a contemporary of Gaudi. It looks OK from the front but when you get inside, it blows your mind. The architect believed that color had healing powers, so each building is just beautiful with colorful tiles, and a combination of architectural styles. Truly amazing and a real sleeper in Barcelona.

Catalan Modernisme architecture lovers 7-th heaven. WOW, what absolutely fabulous architecture created by Lluis Domenech i Montaner. This site is not yet in the Rick Steve Spain tour book; but must be entered soon. It is definitely a "don't miss while in Barcelona" site. There are English tours available but we did not take one. It was a former hospital; but is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Good 30 page English pamphlet available as a guide. I'd suggest allowing at least an hour to visit the site which is reachable by bus from Placa de Catalunya. Senior rate 9.80 euro.

Can't believe it was a hospital!. Sant Pau Recinte Modernista is not far from Sagrada Familia. There is a very cosy street (Avinguda de Gaudi) with some nice terraces leading up to it.What suprised me is that this building was a hospital. The Art Noveau is truly magnificent. I was in awe when first coming at the building. Unfortunately when we visited there was apparently a part closed, but we got in at a reduced ticket.You get a very short guidebook when entering explaining what happened here, what happened in the pavilions. As it is not too lenghty, it gives you a good idea what happened. We strolled around in the garden to and tried to imagine how it would be to be staying in this hospital. There are 3 buildings you can visit. The first one is of course the main building. Stroll around, look at the ceilings and see how nice they have renovated this site.The second building you can visit is on your right side when entering the garden, about halfway there. Here you will get a vision of how it was to stay as a patient in the pavilion. The 3rd building was actually super interesting. It as the same side, so left when facing back the main building. It was previous investigation quarter. What is supernice that each chamber, shows a different part of the renovation of this site. There are some super nice time lapse movies. It is here that I learned that they really tried to re-use each material and you can truly see how nice the pavilions (which are not all accessible) are.A must see
Not a hospital!. Thanks God, today you can visit it without the patients who has been hore in hospital. A great modernista place, it is hard to decide which pavilon is the nicest.

An artistic treasure!. Another fabulous Art Nouveau site created by the architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. The history of this complex is worthy reading, originally there were meant to be 48 pavilions, however only 27 were built, 12 by Lluís and the remaining ones by his son Pere, with each one assigned to medical specialities and all linked by underground galleries.The Sculptures around the site are beautiful, from Angels, Dragons and Gargoyles in the form of animals (including a frog!).The colours and vibrancy of the tiles in the Infirmary Pavilion are stunning, very light and airy and I would imagine very therapeutic. (This is still a work in progress) There is a surprise as you walk through the tunnels, the hospital is brought to life in front of your eyes.The information throughout the site is very informative, and explains the types of illnesses were treated and where. There are also great graphics to explain the refurbishment of this site in the exhibition area.Beautiful buildings, full of history and awe inspiring.

beauty in a hospital. Very nicebplace with gorgeous architeture turned into a historical place of catalan modernism. Peaceful gardens between nice buildings. Need a litlle more inner places to be seen.

Hospital visit??. This hospital is now only a tourist destination. Built around 1905 as a modernist architect design. Still in the process of renovation but what there is to see is already an amazing sight to visit. Great mosaic inside and out with frescos adorning the buildings. Yes worth the walk from Sagrada Familia.

Another one of Barcelona's must sees. It's hard to believe that this place was actually a hospital a while back. It was intentionally build to help recreation and it certainly does the job. Quiet, peaceful, and beautiful!

Its nice and efforts are good.. No point in visiting. You can enter 2 buildings at a cost which was way over priced. Got nothing from it apart from sitting on a bench in the sunshine which I could have done fro free down the road.......no need to go at all-just thought we were being ripped off.

Walk here after Sagada Familia. This former hospital with its multiple decorative buildings is a delight to see. You can't go into any except the main one, but walk around the grounds and admire the colors and tiles and decorations.

Unique!. Hard to believe this was meant to be (and worked as) a hospital! Amazing place. It's a very short walk from Sagrada Familia (along the Avinguda de Gaudi) so you can see both. Shame that only two of the pavilions are accessible to visitors, together with the entry main building. Anyway, you would enjoy every step taken in this stunning, peaceful place! Not to be missed!

Beautiful surprise. We knew nothing about Sant Pau until waiting in the interminable line for the Picasso museum but what a treat. After Sagrada this was so quiet and peaceful -- and there is a superb creperie en route -- chorizo crepe -- who would have thought that was the way to heaven?

Must See In Tandem With Sagrada Familia. All my times here I've somehow over looked this Hospital. It's a hospital after all and what's interesting about that? Oh I was wrong, who designs a hospital like it came out of a fairytale. 16 fantasy colorful structures. It's not far from the Sagrada Familia, so walk to it, it's like hidden gem!!!

Facinating history, interesting architecture and colourful ceramics . This is an amazing and newly renovated piece of Barcelona 's history. The site is extensive with much to see and walk around. The buildings have been painstakingly restored to their original grandure, with detailed facades , vaulted ceilings, grand staircases and underground tunnels. Arguably the most impressive feature is the extensive use of ceramics from clinical plain white to decorative colors and patterns. The use of ceramics is part asthetic and part as a practical means to have kept what was a hospital clean and hygienic. Well worth the entrance fee a real gem. Even my teenage children were wowed with it (for an hour !).

One of Barcelonas stunning highlights,10-15 minutes walk from the Sagrada Familia. North of the SF, there's an old hospital built Modernista,and the only word I can use in regard is stunning: The architecture, the art on the walls and inside the complex - something not to missed. The place function, in some of its buildings, as an headquarters for the world health organization (or something such as), so don't wonder off the paths, since the guards, while nice, would not appreciate your sense of adventure.Inside, you can see a model of the whole complex, a movie that explains about its history, underground halls and passages, and you can enter some of the buildings to get an impression about hospitalization in the 19th century onwards.
Astonishing. this visit helps to understand Barcelona.The guide was very nice and gave a lot of explanations about the history but also the social and political environement

Incredible!. We booked a tour in English and were amazed at the incredible building.The facade of the main building was impressive enough,but we weren't expecting to see a group of stunning buildings,each named after the benefactor who raised the money to provide the Hospital for the poor.There is a convent where the nuns lived who provided free nursing care.We also had lunch in the little restaurant in the grounds.A young waitress was particularly helpful there.Sagrada Familia is easily viewed at the end of the avenue.Would really recommend visiting this Modernist masterpiece created by Lluis Domenech i Montaner.

spectacular - even in the rain. Whilst it is not feasible to enter many of the buildings on the site, this venue should not be missed. Even a visit on a dull, drizzly day can lift the spirits. It is a lovely oasis, not far from the Sagrada, with a calming feel just yards from the busy streets outside. As you enter you are reminded of its original purpose, & wonder what it might have been like to be a patient there. Pay attention to details: the friezes, the ceramics, the stained glass, the marble, the garden courtyards. In Sant Jordi there is a charming exhibition of the site's restoration & its history. If you're into Art Nouveau, you'll take loads of photos.

Should not be missed. Wonderful architecture and a lovely way to spend a day just wandering round and enjoying the area. Visit the cathedral and sit in the squares enjoying a wine or coffee. Plenty of history for everyone.

A must see Montaner Masterpiece. Our tour guide brought us to this recently restored historical landmark. My mother (a retired nurse) was the only one in our group who knew it existed. She studied Lluís Domènech i Montaner's hospital complex in nursing school. My husband and I didn't know much about it, but mom knew she had to see it. I'm so glad we took her advice. It was totally worth the entrance fee.There weren't many tourists around, which was actually quite nice. They must have all been inside the Sagrada Familia (another must see landmark). I totally get the Gaudi hype, but it reminds me too much of the Mona Lisa experience at the Louvre. There are so many other architects of that period that get ignored. It's nice to see works from other brilliant artists such as Montaner. It's amazing that an architect with no knowledge of the medical field was able to design such a well built complex. One that was still in use up until 2009. The buildings are very open and allow reflection of natural light. You can see how therapeutic it must have been for the patients to be able to see the beautifully landscaped courtyard from the windows. You'd never know that there were medical teams treating trauma patients in the tunnels beneath the complex. Just think about it as you're walking through the courtyard. I'd have to say that observing the exterior of the buildings, and the tour of the administrative building was the highlight for me. The ornate mosaic art, wood moldings, ironwork, stonework, and stained glass make it so attractive. A true Modernisme experience that shouldn't be missed.

A lovely and extraordinary place. A wonderful collection of art nouveau Spanish modernista buildings in a nine-square-block enclave, a city within the city that used to be a rambling hospital and is now a “campus of knowledge,” home to the Spanish headquarters of seven international agencies, among them WHO and the United Nations University. Six of the 12 magnificently decorated hospital buildings have been restored and are on view (the others are in progress), and you can inspect the ornate tunnels that linked them and the grand gardens, designed as part of the hospital’s restorative function. The place has only been open to the public since February, 2014, and clearly hasn’t been discovered yet: we see only a couple of dozen people in our three-hour visit, a great contrast to the milling chaos around Sagrada Familia, just one bus stop back. Statues, carvings, ornate brickwork, decorative murals--we snap away entranced, then lie on the grass for half an hour, peaceful and serene in the heart of the city. Fresh and scented air, young blossoms on the trees, the slowly moving sun picking out the different shades on the shining roof tiles—terracotta, yellow, blue, purple ... a significant addition to the schedule if you're even remotely interested in Barcelona’s architectural saga, but a lovely and extraordinary place for anyone to visit.
Amazing. Fantastic place to enjoy a view of the influence of Modernism in everyday life in Barcelona. This used to be a Hospital but what a Hospital!! Dont miss it

A Moderniste jewel. The Recinte Modernista--until recently the Hospital de Sant Pau et de la Santa Creu--is one of the finest works of Luis Dominech i Montaner, one of the greatest European architects of the early 20th century. Designed with the welfare of the patient of paramount importance, it was beautifully laid out with gardens as well as lovely buildings. Visitors to Barcelona are often press-ganged into seeing only buildings by Antonio Gaudi, and miss many wonderful alternatives such as this complex. The buildings are in the process of being restored after the Hospital was moved to a new precinct to the north; this restoration has entailed removing many additions to the original structures, as well as recreating the gardens; and is being lovingly and carefully done. Several buildings, including the magnificent Administration Building, are completely restored--and breathtakingly beautiful. The guided tour adds a great deal of information to what is available in booklets and signage. NOT to be missed!

An amazing city in the town. It used to be an hospital ; it is a place to visit, incredibly vast and artistically rich. The plan is not very ergonomic, but do not miss the Administrative building, which is a pure marvel. The booklet is efficiently informative and the video sequences to the point. This place is not yet widely known, so rush to it and you will have an oasis of peace and beauty.

The best kept secret in Barcelona. Having seen the line-ups at Parc Guell, la Sagrada Familia and Casa Batllo, we were were amazed at how few people were actually visiting this venue. It has only been open for a year or so, and is a bit off the beaten track, but for about a third of the cost of the main venues, this is the best kept secret in Barcelona. The buildings are beautiful, conveying a sense of tranquility and peace and the Administration Building is just stunning. It's just one metro stop beyond the Sagrada Familia - get there before the rest of the tourists do!!

An absolute gem... This newly opened (late 2014) is a masterpiece of Art Nouveau/Moderniste building in Barcelona. It is amazing to think it was a functioning hospital until 2009. The architecture, design, ceramic work and painting are as good, if not better, than the other well known and over visited sites. At 8 Euros entrance, no queuing and space to enjoy it must be seen before it is firmly on the tourist trail. At the moment I don't think groups or the Tourist Bus promotes it, but it wont be long...

Make sure you go. This was a very welcome interlude while we waited for the visit time at the Basiilica. It was very close and worth the effort. It is a peaceful place, great gardens and memorable in so many ways

An revolutionary idea for an hospital, awesome and probably still innovative. Maybe we've been a little been blended because we are medical students and would love to practice in a medical hospital like this but if you also love to wander around and look at diverse beautiful ceramics and architect structure you'll love this place as well.You can also just sit there under one of the orange trees, relax and enjoy the beautiful view and all that away from the tourist masses. If you wanna pay 8€ for that you're going to enjoy the former but probably still innovative hospital.They did a really nice job renovating the building and combining old and new elements.Unfortunately just 2 of the pavillons are open for visitors as some of the others are used by NGOs.

Great place. We liked this restored old modernistic hospital. The gardens were a delight, and of course looking at the modernistic pavillions. Unbelievable this was a hospital until a few years ago (you almost think it was a delight being brought there - but I doubt that is really true). This is a really a building you should not miss when you are in Barcelona

Do Yourself a Favor and Visit!. The hospital is an important example of the fantastic Modernisme Catalan art and architecture movement of the early 1900's. It was used until recently to make way for a modern hospital and the site and all its amazing buildings have been (and continue to be) renovated and opened for the public to enjoy as a place to visit, attend meetings, enjoy concerts and other events and to experience the best Modernisme art and architecture you can imagine. Tourists flock to the usual Gaudi buildings, the Sagrada Familia and other fine examples of the period, but I don't think many people are yet aware of the pleasure that awaits them at Sant Pau. This is a wonderful place to visit. Do make the time to do so.

An unexpected delight. We knew nothing about this city within the city, it's planning is fascinating and the history and compassion shown in the old hospital enlightening. Lluis Domenech i Montaner was the architect who practiced at the same time as Antonio Gaudi and their aesthetics have so much in common.
Sagrada Familia Review. Expect the unexpected from this marvelous unfinished architectural and engineering master piece. Please do not miss.

Don't miss this in Barcelona. A hospital ground that I would not mind spending my last years on earth at! Not that it is still in working order but a simply magnificent visit! Well organized for tourist to see and on buying a ticket you get a brochure that informs you well on buildings,gardens and how the hospitals got linked together years before. An architectural beauty and though here and there under construction,a must see to all,whether you are interested in medicine or not at all!

Should not be missed!. We walked up from La Sagrada to this hospital. It really is amazing. I couldn't believe how big it was and how stunning the individual buildings are. It's also incredibly good value. The cafe outside is also very good.

If you only have time for a short visit in Barcelona, don't miss it!. What an amazing place! You can not stop shooting photos.Although located 500m away of Sagrada Família Temple, most of visitors do not go there. This place was a hospital and it just finished restoration this year. The design (catalan modernista style) belongs the same architect who thought Palau de la Música Catalana.Visit http://www.santpaubarcelona.org to see timetable and to know prices (self-guided visit: €8)
INCREDIBLE. Theres no words!, Its a really old hospital that still works as a hospital in this magnificent architecture!

Beautiful, relaxed worth a visit. Even though this place doesn't get many mentions it is stunning, as you walk around the corner from the metro you can't believe it was a hospital until 2010. It's relaxed reasonable €6 and no long queue, helpful staff, good booklet with lots of information. We spent about 2 hours wondering around inside and out. Really deserves more advertising. Please visit as they are doing a lot of renovations which will just add to the beauty of the place.

Ultimate Modernism. What an amazing place! We discovered it quite by chance, as I happened to see a poster in the metro. It's a short and lovely walk from the Sagrada Familia up a pedestrianised street with lots of cafes and restaurants.It's hard to imagine that this was a working hospital up till around two years ago. The main building (the only one visible from the street) is fabulous, but it's what lies behind which is truly amazing. A grid of fantastic Modernist buildings, each one decorated differently and occupying lovely gardens with orange trees and palms. Only two of the buildings are accessible to visitors however, and many more are still being renovated. When it's all finished it will be truly amazing.All in all a fabulous place to visit - highly recommended.

A heritage building worth the architecture and decor. This is an old hospital having a heritage architecture and is worth visiting. It is a quiet place and you can find many artistes practicing their art in front of the main building. There is an entrance fees and an audio guide which is very helpful. A visit to this magnificent complex allows you to delve into history, art and the present day. The pavilions, set among gardens and connected by underground passages, are breathtakingly beautiful and a showcase for the applied arts, featuring sculptures, stained glass and mosaics. This institution has always been associated with charitable work, welfare and the latest discoveries in healthcare.

Beautiful but unfriendly. The buildings were beautiful but the staff at the ticketing and security are was quite rude. He tour was unnecessary as all of the information being recited was posted. The additional pictures shown on an iPad were not worth the time we were forced to follow the guide.

The garden city hospital. After having given up on the line into Sacrada Familia we headed up Gaudí Avenue to Sant Pau Recinte Modernista. What a beautiful and peaceful place to visit! I highly recommend a visit to anyone with an interest in the history of medicine as well as the history of architecture.

Masterpiece of arch L Domenech I Montaner. Hospital in art nouveau style not so far from la Sagrada FamiliaSame architect as Palau de la Musica CatalanaA quiete place compared to the Sagrada Familia,La Pedrera or Casa Battlo. More than worth a visit

Fantastic site recommended by our hotel and barely mentioned in guidebooks - totally worth a visit. We had an amazing few hours walking around this old hospital which has been partially restored and is now a sightseeing attraction and administration offices facility. Only €8 for a self-guided tour and leaflet/guide (guided tours in different languages also available for slightly more). There are also attendants/guides about to ask questions and direct you. I was visiting with a friend who is a nurse so we were stunned that such a large, well planned, spacious hospital facility had ever been built and operated with so much open space/gardens for patients to use during their stay and such beautiful buildings inside and out. The gardens are amazing to walk around and you can go into and look around 3/4 of the buildings that have already been restored. Stunning history, architecture, art, mosaics, sculptures on the building and open spaces. Hardly anyone seemed to be getting off of the tourist bus at this stop but its worth a visit. Look all over the buildings from roofs to walls to floors. There is an obsite cafe we didn't use, a great reasonable priced gift shop where we picked up a few souvenirs and presents and some great places to eat and drink nearby. We spotted a gorgeous looking bakery on a nearby street we planned to visit another day but didn't make it back to and had a lovely lunch in a cafe/restaurant opposite on the crossroads (right hand side of the fountains as you look towards the building. They had menus in multiple languages, were welcoming and happy to explain the menu to us as we hadnt prepared our Spanish prior to our weekend away. My friend had a ham salad €8 (I think) and I had a combination platter of slices of sauteed chicken, potato omelette, pan con tomate, garlic sauteed mushrooms and salad which I would highly recommend for possibly €12.

World heritage and former hospital. Learn more about the history of the city and this splendid Art Nouveau Site and the origins of the former hospital Sant Pau which was designed as a city within a city. Subway station San Pau, short walk from Sagrada Familia.
A favourite attraction. Was pleasantly surprised by the beauty, size and price of this attraction. It was also quieter than the other places we visited and so it was easier to appreciate and enjoy

Exceeded expectations. We signed up in advance for the English language tour, and were the only folks on it.The site, a former public (that means free, this is Europe) hospital, is enormous though it is in the middle of town (a few blocks front the Sagrada Familia).The architect, Domenich i Montaner, generally rated second to Gaudi, uses a heavily neo-neo style, with pastiches of Gothic, romanesque, Andalusian (Mudejar) and Renaissance styles. Though I ordinarily reject this sort of imitation, in this case it works splendidly. The spaces are magical, beautiful and healing (part of the idea). Definitely, not one to miss.

Not much of it is open. I can see why this place is highly rated - it's probably a great place to escape the summer crowds. But I don't think it's worth paying to get in in early spring, when Barcelona isn't very crowded.It's quite close to Sagrada Familia, so I do think it's worth having a look from the outside if you have time, and maybe going to the cafeteria.

Add to your to do list. Well worth a visit, a stones throw from Sagrada. Got free entry Easter Sunday, didn't know this in advance. Worth the 8 Euros entry. Stunning site, only a few buildings open at present as restoration continues.

A Hospital Visit Well Worth the Time. On the last full day of our visit to Barcelona, we headed to the Sagrada Familia. That building is, of course, fascinating and impressive- but we were satisfied with photographing all the angles of the exterior, still undergoing construction. The line-ups to enter were a bit discouraging, so we strolled up a charming diagonal avenue to another Modernista "attraction"- the Hospital de la Santa Creu. The health care project, begun in 1902, was the dream and design of Lluis Domenich I Montaner - a series of exquisite pavilions and gardens, linked by white-tiled underground passages. Entering, after paying the reasonable eight euro entrance fee, you can watch an explanatory video and then walk through the passages, accompanied by slides of doctors and patients projected on those tiles. Two main pavilions are open, stripped down to their original beauty of design, and the administrative building has upper halls that are exquisite in their tiling and windows. The original design envisioned 145 square metres of indoor and garden space per patient- and the beauty of the space brings better emotional health even to the casual visitor. The place is well worth a visit- and it may pique a new interest in modern health care philosophy back in your own country!

Hard to believe it was a hospital, it is so lovely.. They really knew how to build back then. What a great concept... That beautiful surroundings, art, open spaces and nature help promote healing. We need more of that thinking in our modern times. The admission price was reasonable, €8. We needed to ask them to run the introductory video in English, and they did. The grounds are beautiful and the details are stunning. I highly recommend spending some time here. The gift shop has nice selections, too. Don't miss going up to the second level of the administration building. The mosaics are just fantastic!

Stunning, peaceful and amazing. Who could believe this was a main hospital up to a few years ago. sound boring but don't miss it before the main tour groups add it to their agenda. Even to just admire the amazing front of the building, its ornate clock steeple and mosaics without paying any admission is worth it, especially as it is only a few minutes wqlk from the Sagrada Familia Basilica. It is certainly worth its admission fee that helps towards further restoration of the unique buildings. It is a series of ornate pavilions (that were built as wards) in a peaceful garden setting. There are many colours and shapes of roof tiles and wall tiles outside and stunning ceilings and wall tiles and finishes inside. It is more like a stately home than a hospital for the poor of Barcelona around a hundred years ago.For me it was my favourite part of our holiday.

I would have given 5 but for........ Commenced in 1901 this then ultra- modern hospital was built it would seem without too tight a budget in the Art Nouveay style. The original plan was for a very large site to be developed but in the end the size was more modest and some of the Pavilions (ward blocks) were not in the Art Nouveau style. Nevertheless what there is is stunning. The whole concept of light airy wards, gardens for the patients to enjoy and lovely surroundings the help the sick person feel better was a far cry from some cramped inner city hospitals of that time. The underground tunnels joining the blocks meant that services such as meals and laundry could be transported without heed to outside weather conditions. The hospital was used until 2009 and to keep up with modern healthcare advances many alterations and additions to the buildings had had to be made until the whole original construction was buried beneath making it unrecognisable. When it was decided to save and restore the whole site including replanting the gardens the planners took a very bold step and unflinchingly removed all later additions. Although not everything is yet returned to its previous pristine state a good deal is now visible so that a visit is well worthwhile. All modern services such as water, heating and lighting have been placed under the flooring and many of the buildings have been sensitively modernised for current day use by important bodies such as UNESCO and WHO in keeping with the sites health and social origins. It must have been and continue to be a hugely expensive project to carry out this work and it is to be hoped that tourism and other auspicious bodies using the building will help to fund its continuation and completion. The wonderful tiling and wood and stained glass and brick and stonework are exuberant and colourful and the gardens very pleasant areas to linger in. There are a lot of explanations about the sites origins with pictures and drawings and information about the architect and artists. There is also a good deal about the renovation work but as former nurses we would have loved to know more about how the site functioned as a hospital. Where was the pharmacy? How did the meals get up from tunnels into the wards as no ramps were evident. Maybe a guided tour would have told us these things but although the staff were perfectly pleasant and friendly they did not know very much about the building and although we tried several times we couldn't find anyone who knew very much. I realise this is very much a work in progress but I am sure like me there will be visitors hungry for more information. If I had felt more satisfied about getting answers to my queries I would easily have given five points. I also thought the entrance charge very reasonable.

Unexpected delight. You absolutely must visit here. As you approach the building walking up from the Sagrada Familia and see this beautiful building nothing prepares you for the delights that wait behind it. The entry price at 8 euros is cheap by comparison to the other attractions in Barcelona , it would be worth double the price
Worth your time!. We did not plan to go there, found this place by accident and had some doubts whether it is worth our time. But the place is very nice, I would really recommend it.

Even from the outside this building is impressive.. Well worth a visit. As far as we could see you view the building from the outside, which is most impressive. Like many structures in Barcelona it is unique. A welcome relief from bland architectureto be found in so many cities.

Great Visit. We took the English tour and our guide was just fine. We went into the open hospital patient building, saw the grounds and then into the main administration building where there are so many wonders. This place is relatively new to open and there isn't a lot about it in guide books, but it is well worth visiting if you enjoy Art Nouveau design. We went to Sagrada Familia in the morning and then to here (just one Metro stop away) with a late lunch nearby.

Interesting morning out! A gem.. We spent a couple of interesting hours wandering freely around here. Children go free, €8 for adults. Lockers for big bags. Wow! Quite amazing, not only how this was once a hospital but that it has survived to its current beautiful state. Don't miss the introduction film at the start (on a loop of Spanish, Catalan and English).
Truly amazing. What a fantastic monument at Barcelona. The ticket has a reasonable price and you won't be disappointed. Montaner was a great architect and made a fantastic job.
Unbelievably beautiful. Unbelievably beautiful, you would not think to look at it that it was a hospital, fine architecture and open spaces.

An Art Nouveau masterpiece.. We headed up here, having never heard of it before but we had seen posters on the underground and we had been turned away at the Sagrada Familia. We were not disappointed. This is a UNESCO world heritage site and is a former art nouveau hospital which is slowly being restored. Amazing. Where does Barcelona find these gems from? It only opened in 2014, so unlike some of the other attractions you do not have to queue all day to see it.

Worth a visit. This is a beautiful building and worth a visit. When we went, only 4 buildings were open yet the admission price was the same. I'm glad that i went and can understand why it is a world heritage site. They are doing an excellent job at restoring the building sympathetically.
Perfect location. We loved the warren of tiny streets, surrounded by stone buildings. It was easy to get to many sights from here. Would recommend staying in Barri Gotic if you visit Barcelona.
very good. very nice. don't look like a hospital. i liked it. especially the center of it, with the clock. [ i don't know if they use it like a hospital ]

A jaw-dropping experience. I visited this place on my 6th day in Barcelona, I had seen plenty of modernist architecture around and still I thought this modernist complex was jaw-dropping. Just a short walk from La Sagrada Familia and with a reasonable admission charge (5.60€ for under 29s), we opted for the self-guided tour as we were on a budget. The introductory video and the booklet you get when buying your tickets are a nice guide to the tour. After seeing the introductory video, we started the tour walking through the tunnels that connect the buildings. First we visited one of the non-restored buildings which houses an art exhibition at the moment. Here you can see how the restoration is still a work in progress in the complex and it has the potential to be an exciting project. Then we visited another building where inside restoration work was in progress. After we saw some of the great rooms restored within the main Administrative building and we end the visit seeing the exhibition displayed on the smallest building which takes you along the restoration project and the history of the modernist complex. I really enjoyed the visit to the modernist complex, it is a must see hidden gem.

Peaceful. I'd have been very pleased to be in this hospital; it's beautiful and peaceful. Doesn't take long to see, but a real gem. Get a coffee from Chocolate Box cafe on the way back to the Sagrada - best coffee we had; only 2 Euros fro coffee and croissant.
This is a must see. I loved this treasure, and the tourist buses don't seem to stop here. Amazing architecture and detail. Hard to believe it's over 100 years old.

A hidden gem! . As the wait was long to get into familia sagrada, I decided to walk towards the former hospital, the views back towards familia are alone worth the walk. The entrance fee was cheap and it looked good. Place is well kept and artwork is delievered. Pretty buildings!
An Old Hospital. That's was my Building University on 70's. Better than Gaudi's buildings. Unforgettable if you visit Barcelona.

Amazing. Just go.. Everyone knows Gaudi but for my money Montaner designed more approachable buildings you might actually want to live in--or in this case, have been treated in.
Sign up for a guided tour--lasts an hour-- and then you can wander around as you like. a real oasis in the heart of Barcelona, full of beauty and creativity.

Must See! A hidden gem!. From what I could tell, the throngs of tour busses miss this little treasure, and we were so glad we went there. We had two hours to kill before seeing the Sagrada Familia. So we walked Carrer Gaudi and went inside. Stunning modernista "city" that would be THE ONE attraction to see in most cities in the world. But in Barcelona, there is so much to see, this place doesn't get the ink. So it's fairly quiet, which was the perfect way to enjoy it. One of the highlights of our trip.

Extraordinary site. This former hospital site exceeded all our expectations. We booked a tour in English online so no queuing (a big relief in Barcelona). The guide was excellent and the group quite small. There is little information around the site so a self guided tour might be challenging. The restoration of the site is ongoing but it is clearly a gem and the vision of the original architect and main donor was amazing. The Modernista decorative detail is as good as anything we have seen, especially in the exteriors and in the interior of the administrative building. It is, apart from the interior of Sagrada Familia, easily the best place to visit in Barcelona from a visual point of view. There are not many visitors yet so the atmosphere is quiet and peaceful which is a huge plus over just about everywhere else in the city.

art nouveau site. my hotel was right opposite this site which covers 15 acres. it is a beautiful art nouveau building built in early part of the centery as a hospital and still used upto 2009 when the new hospital opened behind it. the guided tours are good and in different languages.lots of tiling inside & out, turrets and cupolas. well worth a visit especially if you love art nouveau
have to go. not a really tourist place but the architect was amazing!!! the hospital is kept originally and has a lot of art. this was one of the best suggestion of our hostel!

Must do. This was a big surprise. I read that it was a good place to see but I thik it's a must do. Very good price for what you see. I was there on a rainy day, I think if the sun would have been out I would have seat in the court yard and never left.

A little visited attraction but worth it. This was around the corner from where we had an apartment. I had read about it from other travellers and was glad I did not miss this. Although you can only visit a few buildings, it was worth the visit to see the architecture and some of the history.
Worthwhile visiting. really enjoyed our visit. Very impressive architecture and design. Mosaics very good. Staff pleasant and helpful. Not crowded.

Splendor of art nouveau. I read about this place and have also seen pictures but seeing it for real is a real treat. Once you enter, you get the "fever" and want to see it in every angle and take the best picture from the most encompassing point of view. You start enjoying the dream that must have pushed the arhitect in drawing this city inside the city.

Another amazing Modernista Structure. We only viewed the outside of this old hospital. Fascinating beautiful architecture. Didn't venture inside due to the cost but also thought it would probably be a disappointment after the Basilica.

A unique piece of modern constructional history. An early example of Art Noveau architecture, this most unusal hospital was used right up to 2009, and is now a world heritage site. Art Noveau isn't exactly my thing, but it is well worth a look

Wish all hospitals looked liked this one. This hospital complex was built between 1901 and 1930, designed by the Catalan modernist architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. Amazing architecture for a hospital, nearly Disneylandish.. Tip 1: combine with Sagrada Familia, since it is 15 minutes walking distance. Tip 2: it is free the first Sunday each month ;-)

Catalan Modernisme at Its Best. Just up the street from the hordes of tourists at Sagrada Familia, this is the largest Art Nouveau/Modernista site in the world. Same architect as Palau de Musica. Fantastic use of tiles and brick design inside and out. Pavilions encircle a garden area, and the interior of the Administration building is amazing. Some buildings are still in use as part of the hospital or for non-profits, conferences, art exhibits and concerts. We went on a drizzly Saturday and there were very few people there, only one other Spanish group tour.

Monumental and beautiful. Entry was free on Tuesday and I visited. Only a very small part was open as there was a congress on.It is a really amazing place, beautiful, relaxing and I can imagine how a patient would have felt there if not too sick.I asked and was told that it was still used as a hospital until 2009. The grounds and building are really amazing. It is well worth a visit and the architecture is just amazing. I would go back to see the place again and hopefully I could visit more of it.Don't miss this if in Barcelona. There were not too many people there.
Hospital?. Think someone told me that it is a former hospital. Very nice yard, architecture, orange trees inside... take a look

An architectural delight. What a surprise. This is not on most lists of things to visit but it gives a sense of how wonderful the creative spirit in Barcelona has been over the decades. Book a tour on line in advance. One of the highlights of our very busy stay in Barcelona.

Spectacular. Not on the cliche Barcelona tour list, but if you like architecture and would like to absorb a sense of the amazing creative spirit that Barcelona has had over the decades, this is a must. Excellent guided tour.

Amazing Hospital. This is a beautiful old hospital complex that is currently still being restored. Beautiful grounds, the tile work is incredible. Worth seeing since you can knock this out in 1.5 hours.
Sant Pau Hospital. A wonder of modernista architecture. Now open for all visitors since december 2014. Therefore not often mentioned in the guides. Few visitors, a must for lovers of this style.

How can a hospital be so beautiful?. Can you imagine a hospital that looked like this? It's hard too imagine any hospital looking attractive, and actually wanting to see it, but this is one you shouldn't miss. The surroundings, the structure, everything is beautiful.

So peaceful and beautiful. What a gem this place was! We happened upon it when walking back from Sangrada Familia. The beautiful buildings were originally the hospital. I have nowhere seen such magnificent hospital buildings. The grounds are beautiful too, and such an oasis of peace in busy Barcelona. Some of the buildings are being restored, but a good part of the complex is available for visiting. The architecture is breathtaking. Highly recommended.

A Special and totally different experience. Not in many of the top tens but definetly worth a visit,as it is unique and draw dropping once inside.The outside facade is special but it is the internal courtyard of many modernistic buildings that makes this place special.Take the time to give it a try,not Gaudi but equally as brilliant.

World Heritage Site - Don't Miss It. Just a ten minute walk from the Sagrada Familia is this fabulous architectural jewel. You will truly feel like you are in a dreamscape; it's Modernista style with Gothic touches and a fascinating backstory. The last guided tour in English was at 1:00 on the day we visited, so check in advance. Our guide, Monserrat, was one reason we had such a great time. The whole tour takes about an hour. Absolutely one of the surprise highlights of Barcelona!

ONE OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL BUILDING IN BARCELONA, UNBELIEVABLE ITS A HOSPITAL!. Because its a hospital building, I first avoid this building. I went past this building two times by the hop on hop off tour bus. Because of the external beauty, finally I decided to pop in and have a look. Tickets costs 14 euros with a guide, small group of people taken inside and explore the marvellous building. (Without guide 8 euros, but better take guided tour, it's really worth to explore this building). Inside every angle beautifully crafted. Well designed, amazing stained glass panels, really I can't beleive this is a hospital building! May be not mentioned as a hospital, most people will visit here! A hidden gem!!

More to Barcelona than just Gaudi. Gaudi may have died in this hospital but trust me once you visit this place you realise that it is special for a lot more than just this. A true unexpected treasure that will give tons of pleasure to anyone who loves modernist architecture. No crowds at all and so much practical beauty to admire. Hard to believe it was once a hospital. Please visit, well worth it

Do not miss the architectural delight!. We stayed close to the Hospital St Pau on a recent visit to Barcelona and felt we needed to see this complex. We paid the additional cost for the guided tour and are so happy that we did. Our tour lasted approximately 1 hour but the information provided by our guide was so interesting and made the experience so much more enjoyable. The architecture is stunning and the concept behind the design is fascinating. The recent history of these buildings is also fascinating - it is sad, however, to see how the "renovations" have changed the original design and concept. While this location is outside of the touristy area of Barcelona down by the water, it is well worth the time to visit. Actually, not far from the Sagrada Familia, one could easily combine the 2 attractions into one day, stopping for lunch at one of the many restaurants on the street which connects the 2 locations.
Amazing. This Place is not visited that much but believe me: you can sorround yourself! The details, the architeture, the history is incredibly nice! Go if you are NEAT by!

Art Nouveau gem. After it was open after restoration in 2014 the place is a must visit sight for all interested in modernist architecture. It is quite close to Sagrada Familia so you just need to walk by Paseo A.Gaudi to visit this great work by luís Domènech i Montaner.It is an amazing combination of decorative modernist architecture blended with functionality totally covering needs of the hospital of its time.

An small astonishing architecture village which was a Hospital. It is difficult to believe that that small walled village was a Hospital until few years ago. Simply we (the Barcelonians) were to worried when visiting a Hospital to value "what a Hospital" we had. A must in the city!

I was hoping to see more. I finally went to see this modernist monument (Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau in Catalan) which was originally a hospital designed by famous architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. From the outside it's the construction is amazing very much similar to other famous buildings in Barcelona. I was upset to hear many of the pavilions were not open to the public so the walkthrough was fast. The last main entrance building is the best to see inside, and of course the history behind the origins dating back to the 1400s. I recommend to see after the Sagrada Familia, because it's on the same area very close to each other.

Wow. Went here after visiting the house of LLeo i Morera by the same architect. We were just blown away by this site. Visit before it gets too busy as not many people know about it yet. We went on a Sunday morning before catching our flight home from Barcelona. So we didn't have time to do a guided tour but I wish we had. The scale of this hospital is immense and only so much is open as yet, but it's obviously a vast renovation project in progress. It was wonderful to wander and read the guide but I think we would have got so much more from a tour. It's an amazing fusion of architecture, art, science and religion. Almost overwhelming to take in at points. The most interesting place I have visited in Barcelona.

The Largest Art Nouveau Complex in the world. Conceived as a Hospital, it is also the largest Art Nouveau site in the world. The architect Lluis Domenech conceived it from old greek perspective of healing the soul through beauty, thus healing in return the body. It is conveniently located, with 2 metro stops nearby both from the Blue Line: Hospital Sant Pau and Sagrada Familia metro stop. Taken into account the recent restoration of the pavilions and the extensive art work in murals, stained glass and skilful art craft in all the complex, It is a must see if you'd like to see a different conception of art & health and have aesthetical enjoyment. Also, if you visit Sagrada Familia Church, Hospital Sant Pau is just 4 blocks away from it. You can take Paseo Gaudi, a pedestrian street full of local cafés, restaurants and shops where you can rest while enjoying the mediterranean way of living and then proceed to Hospital Sant Pau with your batteries recharged. Hospital Sant Pau entrance fee was 8€, which I find a fair price given the beauty and the effort that takes to keep a site like that while still being an active health center.

A very interesting and beautiful site. So much history here and some beautiful buildings inside and out. Take a guided tour. Very close to Sagrada Familia and an essential part of Barcelona history. Very photographable. We thoroughly enjoyed.

Don't miss this beautiful unesco heritage site. I wasn't keen to visit an "old" hospital. So I was in for a pleasant surprise when I visited this one. This hospital is a UNESCO word heritage site built with red bricks and richly decorated with ceramic tiles in nature's warm and cheerful colours. Great work from architect Lluis Domenech i Montaner of a hospital-garden concept for the patient’s enjoyment and well being. This hospital has a lush garden with many orange trees and other plants. It was a beautiful day to walk in the garden, with the sun shining on a winter’s day and we were basking in the sun enjoying the crisp air and admiring the hospital architecture in the background. The Administration pavilion with beautiful staircase and the pink-purplish coloured vaults was the highlight for me.

MoneyMoney. Lovely placeBeautiful but you need to placeİf you want to enter.we didnt go even though we knew it was a nice place they wanted money fromUs to enter. After aWhile you can say enough i wontPay. :)

finally got in to hospital. we have tried for a few years to get in to this site, and finally we where in newly opened and most of the pavillions have been renovated, colourfull, and fresh, you can enter one or two with information notices telling the history, as you go through corridor from main enterance to get into groundsthey place projected images of old film of patients and other things on the tiled walls of corridor at first it looks spooky, but then you realise its looks good in the surrounds nice idea.
