free museum. Was there on free admission day. Great place. Very pretty grounds. Very large. Was greeted by people dressed for the time period.

Lovely surprise. This wasn't in our list of places to visit but was recommended by our hotel and glad we made our way there. Too bad we only had an hour and couldn't spend more time to enjoy the serenity, architecture, history and story behind it. Most of the buildings are closed off but it was nice enough to be standing outside it, picturing a scene not too far back in history. Entrance was not expensive (compared to the popular Gaudi places), definitely worth the visit (walking distance from Sagrada Familia).

beautiful escape in the heart of barcelona. So the average traveler will totally over look this site....a real shame given just how magical and amazing these hospital grounds are. I seriously ... for a moment ... wish I were sick with tuberculosis here. Between the beautiful spaces, the glorious ceramic tile, sculpture, and gardens, Sandy Perry is literally a heavenly place to convalesce. Few of the pavilions are still used for their intended purpose but the site remains a marvel and tribute to making the infirm heal humanly, and surrounded by beauty. If you are at all interested in early modernism e, this site cannot be missed. It's like the Gamble house, la pedrera, and Barcelona's music hall rolled into one space.
An architectural wonder. A short walk from La Sagrida Familia, this hospital complex is worth the admission price to marvel at the interior spaces.

Great Place to Capture the Golden Hour. Catalan architecture and history - a great combination for photographers, especially when looking to capture the afternoon light. Not all areas are accessible for visitors - this historical site is currently renovated with European Union funding.

well worth a visit. Often overlooked for top ten in Barcelona but it is worth it.
Modest entrance charge. Amazing restoration of old hospital buildings. It would have been a pleasure to be a patient here!

Well Worth a Visit !. I have been to the city at least once a year for the last 8 years, so I had seen all the "top" sights and was not expecting such a spectacular visit! It has only been open after renovation for a relatively short time, but the vast site with so many stunning old buildings that were hospital wards in the days when this area was outside the city walls, is really worth a visit. The English speaking guide was entertaining and very informative, not just about the site, but about the history and other Barcelona-related topics. You will not see anything like this site anywhere else in the world, it really is not to be missed.There is a fair amount of walking, much of it outside between the buildings.

Lovely Surprise. On our recent trip to Spain to visit my husband's family, his cousin told us they wanted to take us to a place 5 minutes from their home that had "Modern Art" as translated form Catalan to English for me by my Hubby. I groaned inside, because I HATE modern art... I am a history buff and I LOVE old things. I decided not to complain, to be open minded, and to experience something with my husband's family that they were excited about showing us. Boy am I glad I did! This place was amazing! We took a tour in Catalan, and my hubby translated the pertinent info to me, but I was so busy snapping photos, that he let me wander off to ooh and aah to my hearts content. These photos are ones I snapped with my iphone to post on social media. The buildings are so gorgeous. Everything was meticulously restored. I love the idea behind this place... Built in the early 20th century by a man who said it had to be free to all people. The thought behind the lovely spaces was that in order to promote better healing, people needed a beautiful environment no matter their economic status. Do yourself a favor and go check this place out. The staff is very friendly, and they do tours in many languages. There was no line like the 5 hour wait at Sagrade Familia. It is straight down the street from there and the cathedral can be seen from the hospital.

Wonderful and staff really friendly. I had not been since it has been renovated and converted. Well worth the walk up from Sagrada Familia and the 9 Euro entrance fee. Staff very friendly and happy to answer any questions. Throughly recommend

Beautiful Architecture, Interesting History. In a city full of marvelous architecture, Sant Pau may not be as prominent as it would be elsewhere. However, the magnificently restored buildings and beautiful campus make a visit here absolutely delightful. It is almost impossible to take a bad photo! The staff is friendly and helpful. They even have a nice café in which historical photos bring one back to the time the hospital was in operation.
Hidden Gem. Very nice, and especially appealing to students of architecture and urban planning. A vision for the creation of beautiful healing spaces that has been lost to cheap modern approaches.

One of those places you've got to see if in Barcelona.. If you are visiting Basilica of the Sagrada Familia, do include a trip to this place as it gives you a different take on the Art Nouveu by a different Architect. It also is more relaxing as lesser tourist visit this place but the main building is just as beautiful as other attractions in Barcelona. They also have a guided tour which I think is better since they could explain the history and works done on this place. Gives you a better understanding of the artist and his works.
Hidden architectural gem. One of the most amazing complex of buildings I have ever seen. Not as well known as the other sites but it should rank up there with the best.

Modernism in perspective. Christmas in Barcelona is an experience quite apart, it does not exactly feel like Christmas. Sant Pau is a place where it does feel like Christmas, and it is really beautiful. Barcelona modernism has a face of its own, and Sant Pau is definitely an important part of it,

Barcelona Essentials: THIS & Sagrada Familia. If you only have a day or even just a few hours in Barcelona, go to Sagrada Familia and then walk straight up Avinguda de Gaudi to see Sant Pau Recinte Modernista. As an atheist health professional, this place struck even more of a chord with me than Sagrada Familia. It is hard to believe this entire hospital complex was built to such an astounding standard of architecture and mosaic interior decoration, inside and out...just wow, wow, WOW. The magnitude of this project in the early 1900's is mind-boggling, very sad to think that the architect Lluis Domenech Muntaner did not live to see the opening of this hospital (4 years after his death.) Really, you must see this - even if you think you are not the biggest fan of art, architecture or healthcare. Like the Sagrada Familia, do not miss it! This will be one of the highlights of all my European travels that I will remember for many years!We took a guided tour and it was very well worth it, with a self-guided tour you will still be able to see all the elements of the hospital complex but having a guide full of passion for the place who is able to tell you all about the facility and its history really made the experience for us. We booked onto the English tour online before we went but it did not appear that it was essential - we could have turned up at 12pm or 1pm and purchased tickets there.

Art Nouveau Hospital - A Gem. This is a short walk from the Sagrada Familia, it's a beautiful early 20th Century hospital complex. If you not prepared to queue for 2 hours then wait till 17:00 to go into the SF, and you like early 20th century architecture, then you'll love this. Originally a much bigger site was planned. The Architect, Lluís Domènech i Montaner, is a contemporary of Gaudi, and responsible also for the Casa Lleo Morera, which is also worth a visit.I was taken by the harmony of the bricks, the beautiful ceramic decoration of the hall in the main building. My overwhelming thought was, if I had been sick and taken here, then I would have been soothed and would have a will to get better!

A Good Attraction Even for 'Non-Artsy' People. Our group of 5 (4 adults and 1 young child) visited this location as we stayed nearby. It was a relief from the crowd at nearby Sagrada Familia. Coupled with the good weather, the hospital grounds were peaceful and beautiful even for 'non-art' fans like us. It was interesting to see UN and WHO housed there. Do not miss the stunning interior of the main building! We also caught the Christmas light display (cast onto the building) at night. One of the highlights of the trip.(+) Not as crowded as other attractions(+) A lot of outdoor running space for children (+) Beautiful buildings and landscaping(+) Pristine toilets*Do check opening times and dates as it was closed the first time we walked over

Something Completely Different. For years this was a real life hospital. But it was different from almost every other. It had a garden for the patients to make them feel better. It had color everywhere.It had uplifting murals everywhere. It had stone whimsey (stone frogs anyone?) and so on and on. this huge place has just finished a total renovation following the hospital's removal to a more modern facility. So important is this site that it was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site recently. It was built in Catalonia's unique take on Art Nouveau (France)/Jugenstil (Austria)/Arts and Crafts (England) to create something magical. I almost wanted to get sick just to be here longer! Almost. There is an incredible Hall (why a hall in a hospital?) with the balcony balustrade crafted in gothic letters asking God in Catalan to "help and support the donors and patients of this Holy House..." I was there for well over an hour, which might be a longevity record for me. Highly recommended.

This was a hospital?!. At first, I thought the entrance price was a bit steep, but my wife made me pay anyway. So glad she did! These buildings and the philosophy behind the site is wonderful. Have you every woken up in A&E and thought "this is fantastic!" ?

A landmark that is also a working hospital. I would happily skip Gaudi's church and visit this vast complex, which is still a working hospital. They do provide English tours several times a day, lasts about an hour, good source of background information. It is amazing to see how ahead of time the founders and the designers of the hospital were - building a place where patients could rest in a garden setting. And what a set of buildings they are - air ventilated, floor heated, glass walled, in short a 21st century concept architecture with 19th century style.Make sure to tell the taxi driver Sant Pau Recinte Modernista, not Sant Pau Hospital, otherwise you end up in the modern hospital wing and have to walk diagonally back.

Beautiful Art Nuveau Architecture. Went there right after La Sagrada Familia. It wasn't as stunning as Familia but more peaceful and beautiful. I loved the colorful mozaics and pretty buildings. You can only enter three of the buildings (out of more than twenty) and can't see a lot of the hospital area (due to the ongoing restoration process) but I guess that's why it's way cheaper than other sights in Barcelona; it only costs six euros. The staff were very helpful and friendly. There are also good great exhibits detailing the amazing restoration of this complex, which was a unique and interesting bit of information you don't usually see much of.

Montaner should be a name to conjure with. Hospital Sant Pau is one of the more amazing sights of Barcelona. Only a few minutes walk up Avinguda de Gaudi from La Sagrada Familia, Montaner's spectacular modernista complex is enough to make you forget all about Sr. Gaudi. Well, that might be a slight exaggeration, but I have probably spent more happy hours in and around this beauty, and used up more gigabytes of memory photographing it than I have any other place in the world. I only wish the Palau de la Música Catalana were easier to shoot, but it is hemmed in by other buildings.Sant Pau is not.

A surprising and spectacular place. This was a pleasant surprise. The history as a hospital is intriguing and the buildings are spectacular. It is not what I normally think of when hearing about Barcelona, but it was well worth the visit.

Praise the architect. Until I went to this place, I'm ashamed to say, Mr. Lluís Domènech i Montaner was a perfect stranger to me. When I left the place (and even before I saw his crown jewel, the Palau de la Música Catalana) I was already an unconditional fan of this extraordinary architect.I would never have guessed that this was a Hospital and could hardly believe it when I was informed that the pavilions that you can see when you walk outside on the inner courtyard are only about 1/4 of the total number of pavilions that were built. This was a massive, one of a kind hospital.The architecture, combining old and new, the decorative elements, combining classical and modern, the colors, the light, the open spaces, the gardens, it all comes together to form this peaceful, beautiful and healing place.(P.S. let me also tell you that this site was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1997)
Global Meetings Leadership Summit. An incredible venue for a global meeting followed by tapas and wine. The audience came from far and wide and Barcelona showed off one of it's stunning venues...

excellent venue. only one thing, which i can say, pity that I didn't have a camera with me and my cell phone is rubbish! venue is freshly renovated and has marvelous interiors! great place to visit and especially when there is some event is taking place!

A hidden gem!. In the hotel magazine there was a feature on Sant Pau and it looked architecturally stunning, so my girlfriend and I decided to go along. From Sagrada Familia it is a 15 minute stroll, right up Avinguda de Gaudi. Entry was cheap at €6. This is a fantastic opportunity to see some authentic Catalan Art and architecture, whilst also appreciating the stunning view of La Sagrada Familia at your disposal from the first floor of the main building. Definitely worth a trip. Would only take an hour and is a great additional walk from Sagrada Familia.

Confusion reigns here. Be aware that there are two quite different Hospital de la Santa Creu in Barcelona and both are former hospitals and current tourist attraction. And this set of photos and reviews mixes them up.The old hospital dates from the 15th century and is in the El Raval quarter quite close to the Ramblas. It is here that Gaudi died, but it ceased being a hospital in the 1920s. It now houses the library of Catalonia and a cloister garden. Most of the photos at the head of this set of reviews (the ones that look medieaval) and at least one review is of this place.The old hospital was replaced by a hospital in modernist style by Lluís Domènech i Montaner. This is located close-ish to the Segrada Familiar and several kms from the old hospital. The address of the Trip Advisor attraction matches this place, as do many (but not all) reviews and a couple of the photos.Not sure how to bring this mix-up to the attention of Trip Advisor, hence this review.

Just Opened Feb 2014 after 4 year Restoration. This turn-of-the-Century hospital for the poor and indigent has been beautifully restored within the last the last 4 years. Declared an UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1997, it was officially opened just at the end of February 2014.A few short blocks from Basilica de la Sagrada Familia, it is well worth the walk. Designed by Antoni Gaudi's contemporary, Lluis Domenech i Montaner, it is Art Nouveau Modernista as its best! Designed as a City within a City, with multiple Pavilions each treating a specific malady, the campus was designed with contiguous parks and green space separating each of the Pavilions. The tile work, mosaics, and roofs are particularly striking. While striking a distant theme, they are each a unique work of art.Highly recommended!

A sweet find of Modernist art. Taking the self tour of the hospital buildings and grounds was a real treat and a great find. The day before I had gone to the Palau de la musica Catalunya and really loved the architecture by Luis Domenech I Montener. I heard the hospital complex had been recently opened after a massive renovation. What a great site. Even though it was raining the day I went, I lingered outside to admire the details on the buildings and on the grounds. Such a peaceful and happy setting. Once inside the administration building, the mosaics and other tile work are amazing. This was a highlight of my trip and put a smile on my face.If you only have time for one, I would choose this over the Palau de la Musica because it costs 8euro versus 18euro for the Palau.
Spectacular Building. We had a corporate function there. Staff were great and the building is spectacular. There was a direct view of the Sagrada Familia from the room.
Amazing and still not very frequented. Despite of being next to the Sagrada Familia, tourism has not yet massively arrived to this spectacular complex. Without a doubt it's now a top 5 in Barcelona.

Beautiful and fascinating new place to visit in Barcelona. Came here for the first time yesterday. Believe it has only been open since February 2014. Very impressive restoration of the old hospital buildings and the grounds beautifully landscaped. Only a stone's throw from the Sagrada Familia which as usual had masses of visitors milling around and long queues to visit, but here it was so quiet and peaceful and not at all busy. I'm sure that will all change once it becomes better known but at the moment a lovely chilled out place to visit.

A Gem of a place.. A recently renovated Modernist collection of buildings set in a large garden, which used to be a hospital, What a place to be ill in!!!. It is stunning, and as yet fairly unknown of the Barcelona Modernist circuit, but is so worth a visit.

Beautiful and heaven of tranquility. It's a beautiful site, as many other sites in Barcelona but this one is very quiet, calm so a good break from the hectic city. Ideal to do in the middle of the day because you feel completely recourced afterwards.

Only checked the outside. We only checked the outside due to our lack of time. Outside looked beautiful, and on our next visit we will check the inside for sure, on walking distance of sagrada familia. Not that touristic, so if you want to avoid the big crowd this is a nice place to go. With a beautiful old hospital side.

Unexpected jewel in Barcelona's crown. Chanced upon this fantastic site. Certainly proved to be a very interesting and very peaceful way to spend a couple of hours, although would have liked to have been able to view a few more interiors. Architecture fascinating, very different to that of our dilapidated local hospital!

Just stunning.... If you work in healthcare, have an interest in buildings/restoration or just enjoy good architecture and photo opportunities this is for you. This former hospital which shut in the 1990's is a collection of buildings joined by underground tunnels for transporting patients to the appropriate ward. The tiling done for hygiene (NHS hospital designers could learn from this!) as well as decor is absolutely jaw dropping. We didn't do the tour but we did stop to watch the short introductory film at the beginning which is on a loop and is repeated in English as this set the scene for us. Great value and so very enjoyable. If you happen to have a wet day I would recommend this as a good deal is under cover.
a hidden gem. We visited the Santa Creu hospital at the end of October 2014 and really loved it. It is a beautiful, quiet and peaceful place with little visitors.
Great Pakistani & Indian Restaurants. For Asians this is haven for Pakistani & Indian food. Must visit Adil Tandoori restaurant & Bollywood

!!!! GO!!!. Holy s*** were my exact words as I turned the corner and saw the amazingly impressive front entry. And it got better from there. It's hard to describe the combination of beauty, function and, for it's time, modernity of the complex. Everywhere you turn is another great view to admire. If you have any interest in the Moderniste movement (and even if you don't) GO SEE IT!

Fantastic Modernista site, don't miss this!. This former hospital doesn't get the recognition it deserves, probably because it has only been restored and properly opened to visitors since February. It's another of Domènech i Montaner's creations (of Palau de la Musica Catalana fame) and in my opinion although different is just as wonderful. We took the guided tour which was considerably cheaper than tours at other sites, you were also given a booklet to keep. This is a UNESCO World Heritage site and the restoration has cost 100 million Euros and taken four years, there's a really interesting exhibition on the restoration in the 'Sant Jordi Pavilion', just before the exit. The authorities built a new hospital in the grounds to the rear of the old hospital and also called it Hospital Sant Pau, which causes confusion with the Metro, best to get off at Sant Pau Dos de Maig (L5 Blue) and walk up just 1 block. There's also a lovely cafe in the grounds.

Art Nouvaeu at its Best. Think about the past. They built a hospital - very modern at times, based on the best available knowledge - which is a pearl of art! A city inside a city. Now it is possible only to look inside one of the buildings but still this is an attraction worthy to go. A tip: buy a ticket to Sagrada Familia between 12.00 and 14.00, then take a lunch on the way from Sagrada to Sant Pau. It is a short, nice walk. Spend about half an hour there.

Unusual to visit a hospital but......... Such an interesting place with an interesting history. A lovely walk there from Sagrada Familia along the Av de Gaudi (many cafes en route!). Only disappointment was that we were hoping to see more of the building interiors. Good exhibition on the refurbishment works. Recommend a peaceful couple of hours here.

Great architecture, quiet atmosphere. Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau was indeed very peaceful place. Buildings blocked even nearby traffic sounds, and there weren't many tourists there. Place has also other functions than being a tourist site, so you won't be able to see everywhere. Also restoration seems to be still in progress. Much cheaper than most of the nice looking places.

Lovely Complex. I swung by this complex and saw the chapel turned art gallery (waste of time) and then went next door to see the main buildings. The area where they give tours was closed sadly, but I popped into the public library to see some of the architecture. It was a grand building to be a hospital...

Sorry no picture but go and see for yourself!. This was a real antidote to the crowds at Sagrada Famiia. What a beautiful and functional place .
It was so peaceful my partner fell asleep in the sun. The artistry and craftwork is so special.
I may be lowering the tone a bit but there are bathrooms very where you look !
Great atmosphere. Condensed history in these narrow streets that ooze culture amidst a colourful past. Lose yourself for a day........

Great site to visit. We we're walking down the road to visit the Sagrada Familia when we see this beautiful site.First we take some pictures outside and we saw you can visit the whole site. For 8 € it's defenitly worth to do. Very beautiful the inside and the rooftops with the ceramique in different colors.It's not compleet redosored already but you can see how they are doing it;

A Must See. This amazing sight is less than a ten minute walk from the Sagrada Familia but most visitors to Barcelona never visit.This is a spectacular series of Modernismo buildings that are just spectacular

A STEP BACK IN MEDICAL CARE IN BARCELONA. This lovely well preserved old hospital and surrounding buildings is a must see for the visitor to historic Barcelona .It has a long distinguished history and captures the medical care provided in the early 19 th century. Take the guided tour for a more in dept visit and you wont be dissapointed

Fantastic architecture...oasis of calm!. After seeing the queues outside the Sagrada we decided to find another attraction and picked the Hospital as it is close by. It was amazing...many attractions are very expensive (20 euros or more sometimes) but the hospital charges 8 euros for a self guide tour using a well illustrated leaflet. It was not busy so you have the chance to enjoy the buildings without hordes of people. You cannot enter all the buildings but the outsides are impressive by themselves. It also has an Art NOuveau café. The story of the restoration of the site is astounding and very informative...it's a gem.

A very interesting place to visit. Our tour guide in the Bari Gotic mentioned this place and we decided to visit it when our trip to Sagrada Familia was derailed by the 2 hour wait. It was a short walk and we were not disappointed. The guided tours in English are excellent and we learned a great deal about health care years ago.

great restoration of unique site. unique site of former hospital being restored to former Nouveau glory. this is a large site and about half of the dozen or so buildings have been restored. we did not take the tour and spent about 90 mins on site. 8 euros maybe not cheap but we felt was great value given the quality and detail of restoration, in fact we were blown away by the scale of the complex hidden behind impressive main building. if you are a fan of art nouveau and/or architecture then this is a must visit site. not too busy on the morning we visited (Monday when many other sites closed) and although we staying close by it is only a short walk up (at top of Av de Gaudi) from the Sagrada Familia and close to metro Sant Pau/Dos de Maig.

Not to be missed. This place is incredible, so beautiful and also such an amazing story. It was fascinating to see the restoration work that was in progress, some of the buildings are really only partway done but you can peek at them, then compare to the polished finished parts as a comparison.
Fabulous!. Only recently opened to the public and well worth a visit. Beautiful location, stunning architecture and a great cafe/restaurant.

Great work and great result. It looked like a walk in a misterious garden. The buildings decorated with different materials were dreamy plants. Even natural orange trees looked as a part of decoration. The organisation of space is very specific. It attracts attention at ceramic tiles and precious mozaics.

no words. All the comments below are true, this is a true masterpiece. I was i awe, and i only saw the outside part, because it was already closed for visitors. Totally on my list to visit next time i have the chance.

Wonderful architecture. This was right by where we were staying so on a hot and sunny afternoon we strolled across. Entrance fee is 8 euros with reductions for over 65's. This is a UNESCO world heritage site and has only been opened since February 2014 but it is so well worth a visit. The architecture, tiling gardens statues and clock tower are stunning- hard to believe it was once a hospital. Not everything is open to visitors yet- it is a work in progress. At night the clock tower and buildings are lit up and it looks amazing.

WOW! An Unknown Secret Masterpiece~!. Okay, everyone one finally knows about Antoni Gaudi! But what many don't know is that Gaudi lived during a time when other master "modernist" architects were also producing amazing masterpieces throughout the City of Barcelona. Hospital Sant Pau by the architect Lluis Domenech i Montaner heads that list. The former hospital is located near the Sagrada Familia Basilica, and there are 26 pavilions in which were once used for specific medical illnesses. The pavilions are connected by fabulous underground tunnels and up on the surface, the grounds -- which are like a mini-City within a city also have beautiful gardens. Today the pavilions are being restored one-by-one and they house exhibits, as well as the offices of a broad range of nonprofit organizations. Also on the property is a restaurant.It's seriously a hidden amazement! Be in on the secret and go!!

A stunning gem. This is a little-known, must-see architectural delight. This hospital that closed nine years ago, is being refurbished and was recently opened as a UNESCO site. The architecture by Domènech.i.Montaner, who also did the Palao de Musica, is stunning. The mosaics are incredible. Put them together and it is pure delight. Everywhere you look you see beauty and then you read that everything was designed with a purpose. Even the technology in the informational areas is really interesting. For example, as you walk down the underground passageway that connects all the buildings, you actually see moving projections of how this area had been used. This is an incredible site to visit and it's only blocks away from Sagrada Familia.
A seemingly little known treasure amongst tourists. A gem of architecture. Well worth a visit a short walk from Sagrada Familia. Still in the process of being renovated .

More then Gaudi. On a walking distance from de Sagrada Familia, we came across this beautiful site by accident. It's really a quiet and beautiful space, in the middle of a very busy area. It's nicely restaurated and shows perfectely that modernistic Barcelona has a lot more to offer than Gaudi.

Buildings look very nice from the outside.. We came here because of a recommendation. It's 8 euros without guide to go in and under 30 years old get 30% discount. The outside of the buildings look great and knowing that this was a hospital makes it even more impressive. The downside is that there are only two pavilions open. One is a operation room in semi original condition and the other is a temporary exhibition with bonsai trees. Most of the buildings can't be seen because they house the blood bank or WHO office etc. We where not really sure what the owners/management want with this really beautiful site. Make it a tourist hotspot or a commercial site but not both.Even the staff inside of the bonsai botanical garden seemed kind of confused what to do. Would like to come back once they have restored everything and are ready for tourists.

Visit Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau !. The hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau is a short distance from Sagrada Familia. It was designed by the Architect Domènech i Montaner so if you have seen his Palau de la Musica Catalana you know what to expect . Not one but a whole series of buildings richly decorated with mosaics, coloured tiles, statues; absolutely fantastic plus friendly guides to give you all the information you need.

Beautiful architecture. Great place to visit, while you are in Barcelona, the most beautiful of all the other popular tourist attractions I had visited there. I'd recommend the guided tour, I've enjoyed the extra info and the tips that were given by the guide.

Worth a visit to this World Heritage site!. My wife and I visited this former hospital complex built from 1902 to 1930 designed by the same architect who designed the Palau de la Música Catalana, both UNESCO World Heritage sites. Restoration took several years, and it opened for guided and self-guided tours in Feb. 2014. One sees one of the tunnels that connected the buildings, one large pavilion that housed 44 patients (partially restored), a small pavilion that serves as a small museum, the administration building with a massive meeting room, and the grounds. Many of the other pavilions are used by non-profit organizations and cannot be visited. Beautiful tile work throughout that was used for cleanliness. The self-guided tour includes a small booklet with informative descriptions. We spent 2 hours here on a pleasant, non-crowded visit.

Interesting spot not far from sagrada familia. We loved this sight because it wasn't crowded like many of the sights in Barcelona . We had time to kill between our scheduled visit to sagrada familia. It was a 15 minute walk. We didn't take the guided tour, which we regret.It is a beautiful and interesting attraction

Beautifull modernist buildings. This place is certainly worth a visit. The buildings are marvelous, the park beautifull and the history interesting. It is a world heritage site and for good reason. It is within a short walking distance from Sagrada Familia, so if you are in the neighbourhood reserve an nour or two for this architectural wonder as well.

A hidden gem. Most of the people go to see La Sagrada Familia and might skip this place or just take a picture outside. This is an incredible modernist hospital that is stunning. The guided tour is the best to understand all the details. The architecture and history inside, plus the richness makes of this place probably one of the best in Barcelona. Hurry up before the rest of the tourists find out!
A real jewel.. This was a real find. Absolutely stunning architecture and gardens. One of the loveliest sites we visited in Barcelona.
dont miss. Another example of art nouveau architecture. Well worth the subway ride. My favorite site in Barcelona as it was very unique to the turn of the century barcelona style.

A beautiful place. I walked past/studied many of the marvellous art nouveau buildings in Barcelona, and decided to take the metro to this old hospital. I was not sure whether to go in or not, but the very friendly guides outside assured me it was well worth it, and so it was! Modest admission fee, an oasis of calm inside, no guided tour needed, just wander round and enjoy the brilliant buildings which have been lovingly restored. I am sure that this place will attract many visitors as people become more aware of it- only opened this year- so go now whilst it is still quiet!
Well worth the visit. Everything about this place was beautiful. The only thing we didn't like was the Japanese Garden. Well worth the euros.

A Great Place to Visit. The Sant Pau Art Nouveau Site was formerly known as the Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau. It is a Modernist masterpiece by the architect Lluis Domenech i Montaner and was finished in 1902. The hospital is located near the Sagrada Familia Basilica, and there are 26 pavilions in a Neo-Mudejar style around the spacious grounds. The pavilions are linked by underground tunnels and are surrounded by gardens that give an atmosphere of peace and quiet. The entrance pavilion is known as the Administration Building and has a tower and a clock. Domenech built the entrance building and 12 of the pavilions. Pere Domenech i Roura was his son and he built the rest of the pavilions and the Convalescence House. The old Hospital of the Santa Creu was founded in Ciutat Vella in 1401 and was the basis for the present hospital, which is Europe's second oldest and used continuously to the present day. Pau Gil was a Barcelona-born banker who was living in Paris, and in 1902 he donated a large amount of money to the hospital to expand it to the present site. The new hospital decided to add the saint's name of its benefactor, Sant Pau, to the name of the hospital to honor him.One can wander around the grounds. The large gardens with aromatic and medicinal vegetation were supposed to help patients recover from their illnesses. The pavilions are connected by a network of two km of underground tunnels. A new hospital has been built on the premises and the older buildings will be used for cultural purposes. The site was named a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1997. Six of the 12 Art Nouveau pavilions have been restored during the last 5 years and this is now the most important Art Nouveau complex in Europe. Its architectural and cultural value have acquired an international dimension. The renovated complex was inaugurated in February, 2014. Many international institutions have settled in the hospital premises. Among the most significant spaces restored are the Administration pavilion, with its old Lluís Domènech i Montaner hall and its new conference rooms and auditoriums.

Exterior views free and interesting. Didn't take the tour inside based on other reviews, but enjoyed wandering around the grounds and photographing this former hospital. Great murals on the building and interesting decoration/building styles.

An Art Nouveau Paradise. A huge site that appears to be ignored on the Barcelona "must see" list. If you like art nouveau than make sure you visit here. No queues. Take a guided tour if possible to learn the history behind what was, until recently, a fully working hospital.

A beautiful escape within a busy city. Perhaps it is because it jsut reopened but when i went there there was hardly anybody else and it was only 5Euro! It was a close walk from the over priced and over busy Sagrada Familia and i enjoyed it so much! !
beautiful to see from outside. admission is cheap comparing to those "casa" by Gaudi. but not much to see inside.go only if u have cleared all the major sightseeing site.

Awesome. This is a UNESCO World heritage site, recently restored and only opened to the public in February 2014. It was designed by Dommenech y Marteny, Gaudi's professor of architecture, at the beginning of the 20th century to provide first class medical facilities for the impoverished people of Barcelona. No expense was spared in its construction as can be seen from the sumptuous renovation. The main hall in the Administrative Pavilion is absolutely stunning. I recommend taking a guided tour. Gaudi's Sagrada Familia is just down the road so if you want you can compare and contrast these two iconic examples of Modernista design.

A Unique Architectural Site. A short 15-minute walk from the Sagrada Familia, Sant Pau it is another great example of the catalan style of modern architecture of the early 1900's. Although there was not a lot to see inside when we toured the site (June 2014), it was well worth the visit: the buildings are stunning and the style of architecture, reminiscent of the Palau de la Música Catalana, is unequalled.

Modernisme at its best. If you like to see more of the Modernisme movement and were Gaudi starting getting his ideas and genious from, you have to go to Santa Creu i Sant Pau Hospital!It is just amazing how simetry, colour and architecture blend together and create such beautiful places.Also, cheap tickets when comparing with Casa Batlo, La Pedrera!

Superb. Love the new restored Sant Pau.. If you visit Sagrada Familia, you cannot miss this jewel of art! And if you want to get a beer and some pintxos, there is a nice restaurant at the entrance. Metro "L5 Sant Pau-Dos de Maig" . Buses 45, 20, h10, 47,19

Beautiful buildings and setting. We took the unguided tour and wandered around the buildings ourselves. What an amazing hospital and stunning architecture, I love this about Barcelona they are so brave with design and have been for so long. The exhibitions showing the restoration work are really interesting and well presented. Fine weather helps as much of this is outside. Well worth a visit.

The most beautiful architecture of Barcelona. This was an active hospital until 2009. Built by 'the other' famous architect Lluis Domenech i Montaner (architect of Palau de la Musica). You start your visit inside the main building, then you take the tunnel to the courtyard. I don't know how to describe the beauty of this place, but let me tell you that after my guided tour I sat on a bench in the courtyard for at least half an hour overwhelmed by the beauty of this former hospital.Also, it looks like not many tourists have found the way to Sant Pau hospital. On the day of my visit it was calm and peaceful. Probably they're all visiting Sagrada Familia, only 750m away.Tip1: visit on a sunny day (and enjoy the colours)Tip2: take the guided tour. It is well worth the money.

A jewel of a hospital. Probably you'll think "this catalans are crazy, what an excentricity of hospital", but you must analyze the way the complex is built, and you will realize it was very well thought, and according to the best knowledge of the time. Independent pavillions assuring maximum sunlight and fresh air exposure, interconnected by service tunnels through which workers could service them without mixing with patients and visits, assuring maximum efficiency (for the time). Ok, they went a little bit nuts with the decoration, an ostentation for the benefactors of the time that payed for it... but then think first that being ill, you'll feel better in a beautiful environment than in a boring, ugly one, and that thanks to that, we can now enjoy this true jewel. I recommend that after visiting the Sant Pau Hospital, go to check the hospital it replaced, present day National Library Hospital de la Santa Creu, and compare, so you will understand the hughe leap forward the modernist hospital was. On the opposite, the recently built complex that now houses the hospital, looks sad and ugly, more like a cuarter of a mid XXth century penitentiary. A step backwards maybe?
Architecural wonder. Great buildings, design elements. Another proof of Spanish architectural genius beyond Gaudi. Reasonably priced for the self guided tour and we didn't experience any lines.

The most beautiful hospital I have ever seen !. Don't miss this wonderful place, the history of the hospital is very interesting, the pavillions, the medicinal plants garden and the hidden tunnels... The architecture is beautiful and the hospital is well-preserved. Have a look at all these details ! Even the tiles are wonderful...

Don't miss it if you like art and architecture. This is a World heritage Site since 2009. It is fabulous.I took a guided tour (EURO 14 / August 2014) (it is EURO 8 for a self guided tour) and the guide was amazing.Allow a good hour and a half, two hours, as the details and the place is just amazing.

Beautiful Architecture. A hidden gem within the city, easily accessed via public transport or one of the tourist buses that circle the city. Visited in a hot day and the site is like an oasis. Full of citrus trees and lavender, the aroma is amazing. The buildings are beautiful, art nouveau designed, well maintained and cared for. A must visit if you're looking for something instead of Gaudi.

Visit on a sunny day . The interior and the exterior of the hospital is spectacular. The hospital is not only the building you saw at the entrance, but also a few more buildings behind it! The fascade of each buildings shimmers under the sunshine and the interior of the building is superb with the sculpture and mosaic. Walking distance from sagrada familiar and it is the top #2 in my Barcelona list

One of my favorites in BCN. Please on your stay in BCN, go to Sant Pau. I was there when it was just opening and I dint know what to expect, I was told it was an old hospital and I wasn't very excited. When I got there, it surprised me completely. When you travel so much, you dont get surprise often, and this place was awesome, different than what you see in Barcelona and amazingly beautiful.

Time filler waiting for Sagrada Familia--WOW!!. What a beautiful grounds and concept! It was well worth the short walk from Gaudi's church, partly for the buildings, but mostly for the display building about the restoration process. Best thing though was the food at the Cafe Modernista on the grounds. The "Bread-Olive oil-Chocolate" dessert was the most memorable thing we ate in our two week trip, and that is saying a lot!

A hidden gem. The hotel staff recommended this hidden gem and we are so glad they did.
It has an amazing history, wonderful architecture, has been beautifully restored and is a quiet oasis in a bustling city.
As it was the 1st Sunday in the month our visit was free so no guided tours but still a joy to see.

An amazing experience!. Giving up on the grotesque que at Sagrada Familia we went to Hospital de Sant Pau. And are We glad We did!! The architechture is beautiful in it self but the story is incredible interesting also. Be sure to pay the extra euros for a guided Tour. We had a sweet and knowledgable guide - Julia - and she made it all the more interesting!

Don't Miss. Amazing architecture and beautiful hospital. A bit pricey considering that most of the buidlings are not restored or, if restored, not open to visitors. They need to make more of the facility open to visitors.

Incredibly beautiful Art Neaveau buildings. Incredible these buildings were used as a hospital until 2010. Can be found at the other end of Gaudi Avenue to the teeming Sagrada Familia. Very few visitors as not as well known but just lovely and well worth wandering up the Avenue for.

Sensationally Designed Hospital. This is a bit off the beaten path, but the tour busses stop near here (and no one gets off!). The Hospital de Sant Pau is a former hospital that was built with design in mind. It was designed to be a beautiful, functional building. If only all hospitals were like that! There are beautiful mosaics high and low and you just walk around marveling at the thought of this actually being a hospital at one time. The hospital is in the process of being renovated. While we were there an event was taking place so we weren't able to get the full effect, but the architecture is simply magnificent. This was actually my favorite "tourist stop" in the entire city. It is so much quieter than the Sagrada Familia and Parc Guell and you can really take your time and appreciate the beauty of the hospital.

Mora than extraordinary. One of the pupils of Gaudi was in charge of the design of a huge hospital with pavilions for each different specialty. Its a wonderful place full of details that make you wonder how could they be soo good in so many things at the same time. This place has been remodelled and the visit is worth the trip! Close to the Sagrada Familia, it made me feel I found "the place" where architecture is the absolute king.

Favorite site in Barcelona!. In a city where all the tourists sites are crowded, this one was a breath of fresh air. The former hospital is more like a resort because of the way it was designed. It consists of 11 stunning building, 4 of which we could enter. Others are still under renovation.This was a working hospital until 2009, and then underwent renovation to return it to its original splendor. It was only re-opened as a UNESCO site in February 2014. Thus, it has yet to be discovered by most tourists. We were practically alone as we browsed the amazing architecture, extensive mosaics, and luxuriously decorated interior of the main building.Worth every cent of the 8 Euro fee.
Hidden Gem, Really. Just go visit. Though you can only enter a couple buildings, this is so worth it. So so so beautiful. Turned out being one of our favorite place.

Surprisingly unknown. Sant Pau turned out to be the unexpected highlight of our holiday. It's only a few minutes' walk from the heaving Sagrada Família, and yet there was almost no one here when we visited.Sant Pau is still a working hospital, but the original Modernista buildings at the front have been converted into a museum, and what an amazing sight they are. The hospital is several buildings - four blocks' worth in all - and they are all amongst the most stunning architecture I've ever seen. Easily a rival for some of Gaudí's work.Standing in the courtyard looking round and trying to imagine this was all built for medical purposes simply took my breath away.

tranquil attraction. We only visited here as we had a long wait before we could get into the Sagrada Familia and it was a lucky accident. The buildings that are accessible are so beautiful. As someone else remarked it is not one of the favourite stops so you can wander around without hordes around you. Well worth a visit.

A glimpse into medical philosophy. More than a "tourist site", this visit connects the historic charity hospital in the Gothic city center with modernist architecture and early 19th century public health philosophy ... This is a health care CAMPUS. I wish I had had time to spend wandering the grounds after our tour, and I confess wondering at times whether the tour was really worth it, but in the end I decided that the recommendation is definitely to take a tour, ask questions, pay attention to the A-V introduction and the model of the entire complex -- and then really think about free, universal, public health care from both the mental and physical health perspective. As an American tired of seeing hand-drawn signs about spaghetti-supper benefits to help families pay their medical bills, this place and its history had a profound effect on me.

Go visit.. . Visited the perdrara and heard about the hospital on the tour.. Recently opened following it's renovation.. Whilst some access is restricted the grounds, pavilion and administration building are exceptional.. Difficult to convey how unique the site is a city within a city and yet each building designed and built with an incredible attention to detail... A must see..

Our fav place in Barca- hidden gem!. We loved the Hospital Sant Pau.It was recommended by somebody to us and when we visited it, we were blown away.Firstly, its off the tourist trail so it was almost empty- hardly 15-20 people around, so we could enjoy it in peace.Secondly- once we walked into the main courtyard and looked around at all the building spread out- we were astounded- had never seen such pretty examples of Moderism in all directions.Every dome, every facade was breathtaking. We walked around the entire place , clicking pictures and soaking in the ambience. the fact that it was quiet and peaceful such added to the fun of it.We also entered the 2 pavilions that were open for display and appreciated the intricate interior work done and the tiles and the paintings.Time just flew by in here. We also spent some time jsut sitting around in the open, looking here and there and soaking up the Sun.What a hidden gem!
A hidden pearl of Barcelona. It's an absolutly "must see" place. Very beautiful, only one metro station from Sagrada Familia, it is surely worth the time you spend on visiting it.

Over priced. Following trip advisor reviews we visited this site8 euros ( without guide) and only two pavilions open - one in semi original condition ( which was interesting to see) and the other was a temporary exhibition detailing all the completed interiors of the other buildings that we were NOT able to view- while the exteriors were very impressive it was annoying to be told about the restored interiors of pavilions that were not accessible to the public.Nice setting however Overpriced for what we could view- would have expected to see inside some of the restored pavilions for 8 euros - could not recommend

Barcelona celebrates: Finally able to visit Sant Pau !!!!!. Truly unique expierience ,the most beautiful hospital and one of catalan modernism masterpieces.I reccommend a guided visit as it is a way to truly appreciate all the small details but also a nice walk in the permises gives a wonderful opportunity to visit this truly amazing hospital by Lluis Domenech i Muntaner,beeing a hospital for the city residents (now the other part of the permises)makes this a very local atraccion hardly known by visitors to the city and as the renovations have been completed recently it is now a very popular sight for locals to visit and see the work completed ( truly a wonderful job done !)If you are visiting Holy family church a nice 10 min walk up to this hospital is worth your time and if you dont go in even the main entrance is a sight in itself. Overall a sight for the ones who look for a local expierience and discover hidden gems in the city with so much to offer.Go and enjoy!

Hidden gem. The building is hardly mentioned in tourist guides, and the only reason we ended up visiting it was because it was at the end of the street from our hotel. Renovations on the hospital have just been completed, which means that you will get to admire the site in its full glory. Many tourists visiting Barcelona may not even know that it's open, which means that you can simply walk in and buy a ticket to tour the site either independently or with the a guide speaking the language of your choice, with absolutely NO queues at all! This is a rare enough opportunity in a city as popular as Barcelona, so why not take advantage of it?Add to that the fact that an admission ticket is only 8 Euro, and that, if you're under 29 years old (bring some form of ID with you), you even get a discount for the already affordable price (coming up at only around 6 Euro).This is a restored hospital, with architecture so exquisite that you will hardly believe that the place was meant to heal, instead of entertain. There are holograms in the hallway, to remind visitors of the origins of the place, as well as an exhibit in one of the buildings that was once filled with patient beds.The side dedicated to the administration of the hospital is truly grandiose, with an elaborate staircase and ornate ceilings and statues - and I honestly feel like it could pass for an opera hall or an art museum any day.The lack of crowds meant that we got to enjoy the premises at our own pace, getting to take as many pictures as we wanted and admire the architecture, as well as the absolutely beautiful gardens, to our heart's desire.Take a seat on a bench outside and relax while watching the orange trees adding color to the beautiful gingerbread-like houses, and let the smell of lavender wash over you, as you listen to birds chirping above. It's a wonderful break from all the busy well known sites in the city, and is very easy to get to. All you have to do is get off at the Sant Pau/Dos de Maig metro station OR walk up the boulevard from the famous Sagrada Familia.Whatever you do, make sure to take advantage of the beauty and tranquility of Sant Pau Recinte Modernista, before word gets out!

Beautiful and tranquil place. Imagine being a patient in this hospital... operational from 1930 through late 1990's. Now restored to its original structure, it's beautiful. Very unique design for a hospital, lots of attention to every architectural and landscape detail. Lavender, orange trees, flowers. Arches, ribbed ceilings, murals, statues, mosaics. Tunnels with sky lights, and in fact natural light in literally every building and room. Cost $E8 without a guide, worth a leisurely 60-90 minutes. The film at the beginning circulates in Catalan, then Spanish, then English. We left the kids at home (age 10, 12) they would have been numb with boredom.

Well worth visiting. We booked a walk with an English speaking guide to make the most of our visit to the Hospital de la Santa Creu I Sant Pau. This is a most beautiful group of buildings designed by Lluis Domenech I Montaner in classic Catalan Art Noveau style. Wonderfully restored by UNESCO it is definitely well worth visiting. Our guide was very informative but even without a guided tour there is plenty of information available about the history of the buildings and the restoration work if you just want to wander around by yourself. A really special place that will soon be one of the major tourist attractions in this great city.

Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau. To all visitors of the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona would recommend them to walk the 500 meters between this temple and another fantastic work of modernist architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner, the newly rehabilitated Hospital de la Santa Creu I Sant Pau. Although my opinion is not very objective because I have trained as a physician in this hospital grounds, I'm sure the visit will not leave indifferent.

Found by Walking Away from Sagrada. A beautiful and amazing view outside, we didn't go inside just look and appreciate the beauty of it, just stay and admired also the locals, by looking at them, me and my wife talked about their persistence to be away and independent from Spain, well, we loved these beautiful people with little ones enjoying the good weather, those old ones sitting on the bench that we had the chance to talk and ask where Catalunya Plaza is with our limited Catalan Language, we were very fortunate to be with them, a very proud nation with such great knowledge and ability to create this kind of rate architecture. If you'll see Sagrada don't forget to see this place too.
should be in the top 5!. Our lovely host told us of this beautiful, tranquil place, a definate must see, if all hospitals looked like this you wouldn't mind going!

Another beautiful creation of Lluís Domènech i Montaner. I was lucky to get there after a restoration - all the historic pavilions look like they were just finished by Domènech i Montaner))) There is an exibition related to the all the huge work that was made by the restorating team during the last years.

Another must visit in BCN. if i can visit 3 places in BCN, this will be one of them that I will visit. this place just finished renovation and it amazing, the design was done the same architect as palau de la musica catalana. Eventhrough they havent finish on all building but it is still amazing. My partner was so in love with this place, she just couldnt stop taking photo. there is a small exhibition on how the building was use during the hospital time. we didnt plan to visit this place but I saw it from Sagrada,so we decided to check out what is the place and it was amazing finds.

Must see for anyone (and architects !), splendid renovation. The architect who built this hospital more than a century ago had understood the necessity to talk to users and understand their needs before drawing and building. The result is a hospital incredibly modern both in its concept and its details. To understand this aspect and go further than the appearance, the guided tour (around 1.5 hour) is a must although the English is perfectible. Check the timetable on internet as there are not that many tours per day. It is also possible to walk around the whole site independently, only a few areas are reserved for guided tours.The renovation took a long time as it included demolition of whole floors and various medical installations but it is a true aesthetical and historical success (world heritage site)The nearest metro station is Sant Pau/dos de Maig (not hospital de Sant Pau). Sagrada familia is within walking distance. A few small and cheap but decent restaurants can be found in a radius of 200m from the entrance. There is a snack (not tested) on the site just near the entrance.A must in Barcelona whoever you are, a double-must if you study architecture to learn how to understand users needs !

You have to visit this!. It's an amazing place in Barcelona and shouln't be missed! It was not on my list and accidentaly found it on my way to Sagrada Familia. One of my favorite places in this beautiful city.

Must see. This place is simply amazing - the architecture, the fantastic colours, the concept of the design, all of which was still in use until a couple of years ago. We paid extra for a guided tour however I wouldn't suggest it. Do not miss, you can even walk to it from Sagrada Familia

Note the tour and opening hours. Unfortunately I did not plan accordingly and did not have the chance to visit the inside, although looking at all of the photos, makes me wish I did. However, I did enjoy looking at this amazing complex from the outside. Even a brief view from the outside makes you appreciate and yearn to see what this gem is like inside. This is definitely a place that I am adding to my next trip to BCN. If you appreciate art, this site is definitely recommended.

Beautiful place but also worth learning all the historic and architectonic details. Great renovation job. Originally built with the money donated by a banker (Pau Gil), it was a project designed to provide dignified health services for Barcelona's citizens at the beginning of the 20th century. Hopefully after the renovation the buildings will be functional and not just a place to go take pictures.

Not To Be Missed. This is a complex of buildings, designed by Lluís Domènech i Montaner, who also designed the Palau e la Música Catalana. It was a functioning hospital until 2009, when it closed after the new Sant Pau Hospital opened around the corner. It was closed for refurbishing and has just reopened to the public. And oh what a treat it is!Hard to fully describe the experience you will have when you visit. Every turn brings you to a new "omg moment", both inside and out. The level of detail and beauty in these buildings is breathtaking. Make it a "must see" if you are visiting Barcelona.Tip: It is free right now and the line to get in can be pretty long. But by lunchtime (around 1:00) is virtually disappears. So go in the afternoon to avoid waiting to get in.

Amazing renovations!. Following a local´s advice, we went to see the newly renovated Hospital de Sant Pau. We were amazed by the facade, awestruck by the decorations inside and I really can´t find words to describe our feelings about the garden/square. So beautiful, peaceful...
Added bonus are the views of Sagrada Familia.

Renovations reveal a real gem!. A new treat to visit, with a relaxing garden to chill out in and admire the views. Also with a vista of the Sagrada Familia, & it was free. (Advertised at 8 Euro). What more could you ask for?

amazing modernista architecture. We had rented an apartment on Avenguda de Gaudi in order to visit the Sagrada Familia, but we were overwhelmed by the much less known Hospital de Sant Pau, Domenich-Montaner's answer to Gaudi's Temple. Not to miss for modernista lovers!

We walked into something fantastic!. We were just walking and bumped into this very interesting gated complex. Google Maps said it was a hospital but it looked more like an old town. When trying to walk through we found the ticket booth to purchase tickets €10 at the time of this review.It in fact is a hospital but so art and architecturally rich, that no one would have guessed.The tour was great and the guide was really informative. Some parts of the site are closed due to restoration efforts but what you will see is amazing. It would in my opinion a must see in Barcelona.

Under reconstruction. Though surrounded by trucks, workmen and all the paraphenalia of major refurbishment, it is still possible to see the beauty that lies within. Just viewing the roofs of the various buildings is a pleasure. Sadly, once restored to its former glory, it will be home to various bearocracies.There may be tours available, but check the times.When you visit, don't confuse it with the hospital (for sick people) nearby.

A real gem. This is just brilliant! Last time I was in Barcelona this was a functioning hospital so you could wander around the grounds but not go into the buildings. It is now being renovated as a UN building and during the works guided tours are available which take you into the pavilions - one of which will be renovated for tourists to visit! But it's brilliant as it is and as I didn't know tours were available is was a great addition to the visit!!!

Marvelous Architecture. A fabulous building complex designed by the Catalan modernist architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. The hospital is currently under a massive restoration. The buildings are surrounded by a fence. So I could not have the chance to admire it in its complete beauty. Fortunately, the beautiful architectures could still be observed from a distance. You can go through the Sant Rafael block and the courtyard by participating a guided tour (6 euro). However, still could not get into the other buildings. Don’t miss this marvelous attraction when the restoration completed.

Beautiful buildings, but difficult to see during renovations. Gorgeous, but you have to look over the fences to see most if it. Well worth walking around and through to get glimpses where you can. Should be stunning when conpleted and open to the public.

another great creation. the outside covers a large area, i guarantee you will never see as grand a hospital as this. unfortunately at this present time much restoration work is going on inside,so not possible too see inside.most people miss this on their visit too Barcelona but even so this is still,one not to miss for its beauty.

Don't miss the Hospital Sant Pau in Barcelona, Spain. The Hospital Sant Pau is a feast for the eyes - a must see in Barcelona, Spain. The site is under construction at present, but you are welcome to go on a guided-tour (hard hat included) daily (in English) at 10 11, 12N, and 1PM. It takes about an hour and a half to go through the Sant Raphael building, including the basement. The other buildings may only be viewed from the outside at this time. Don't miss this piece of history. The tile, mosaics, and carvings are amazing.

A UNESCO World Heritage site. Still under construction - expect they will complete in 2014.
You must take the tour and wear safety gear. It is a nice hour visit to an architectural gem. About $8 each.

Raw diamond. The site is under construction, that is an advantage - you are wearing a hat and a vest. Pictures are awesome, the objects are like raw diamonds. Buildings outside are marvelous. The details, mosaics,roofs are breath taking. Church - even with paintings cover, was worth a visit. The tour was short but we were able to see the Hospital and with a little imagination and pictures spread all over the tour, you can grasp the wonder of the world.I think patients in a new hospital beside would prefer to be located in this one (after reconstruction).

If you love architecture, you don't want to miss this.... While I did miss the morning tours that are offered, I walked entirely around this complex of several buildings (great views), and a little inside it too (under construction). The buildings are stunning! To think of the architectural detail that they put into this hospital (post-Mudajar style) is mind-boggling.

wait for the construction to be finished. We had looked forward to seeing inside the hospital, so were disappointed that the "guided tour" only visited the church, which we could've done if we'd attended a service, and an empty shell of a building which had lost its modernist detailing : here the guide just talked about a sequence of photos and not the buildings themselves. Several of the group on the tour left in frustration. We saw much more wandering around outside on our own afterwards, even though parts of the site were fenced off due to building work. We will visit again when we can genuinely see the interiors.

Under restoration!. This hospital is close to Sagrada Familia and well worth a visit but at the moment, access is very restricted as the place is basically a building site while the complex is being restored. You can still pay for a guided tour which we didn't do on this visit, but would recommend you wait until the work is complete.Even so, the exterior is impressive and I plan to visit properly on my next visit to Barcelona. Surprisingly, it's actually a working hospital.

Beautyfull. The former Hospital, now a part of the narcelona University, is undergoing a major renovation, so you can see only part of the buildings. But the part that can be seen is marvallous. When you finish looking, walk through the lovely Gaudi Evenue which brings you straight to the Sagrada Familya Cathedral.

Hidden Gem. At the moment the site is under a cloud of restoration, however if you are willing to over look this and wander around then you will see what I think is some of the most amazing architecture in Barcelona. Tiled roofs, parapets and mosaics. This is a decadently designed hospital. It will be a wonderful site once all the restoration is finished.
Building structure. The hospital is a beautiful building, but I advice you not to visit this place. At this moment it is a construction site and you can't see the building.

Worth seeing, but.... ...note, that there's some reconstruction going on in front of the main building, so no sense in taking photos there. Av. de Gaudi is a good place to take photos of the Hospital (the distance is hiding the machines). Colourful roofs of other buildings near the main one look nice.

BE CAREFUL BECAUSE IT'S EASY TO BE SNATCHED HERE ESPECIALLY NO SUNDAY! Stay always go group or with other people.. It's a site in construction, nice but it's not so good for going to visit because there's dust everywhere. After this I hadn't a good visit because going around I couldn't understand where to go and what to see and when looking at an info cartel a man asked me for a map and I opened the bag for taking the map and two men came saying "policia policia documenta" and controlled my bag taking all my money!!! Stay always with other people and be VERY CAREFUL!

A building site in April 2013- avoid!!. Went out of our way to visit on the way back from Park Guell today. You need to enter from the side nearest the sea but frankly whilst there are some interesting buildings the whole area is a building site and you cannot walk through it as the main area is closed off by fencing. The tours were later and whilst visiting the site is free there are far better places to spend your time visiting than this.

Great architectural treasure. The buildings that make up the original hospital are beautiful. Yes, the site is currently under construction. You can walk around on your own if you like but I suggest you pay the reduced tour rate of 6 euros which will get you into at least two buildings and the chapel. If you are really lucky, Daniel de Vena will be your tour guide. The others in my party and I were so happy that Daniel didn't just give us standard bullet points about the site. He sprinkled his presentation with history, philosphy, economics, a little irony and some humor. The tour is supposed to last for 75 minutes but we spent nearly 1 1/4 hour with Daniel.
Worth to see. This is a very good example of the modernist architecture, one of the masterpieces of Muntaner, do not miss it!

Great arhitecture!. Was a great trip even if it is still in construction. Vizit it if you are found about arhitecture! You will se around 10 beautifull buildings, no need to enter , you can only walk arround.

Currently a Building Site!. Ignore all of the guide books, these are out of date! Currently the beautiful building is a building site of noisy diggers, dust and rubble. Apparently daily tours are still taking place, but hard helmets, boots etc have to be worn. Reminded me of visiting a new build housing estate to view a half built property whilst building goes on around.
A great hospital. This is one greatest hospitals for me. It's architecture is amazing and the service is also excellent.

Hospital de Sant Pau. A wonderful place with superb architecture where all the decorations left me brathless. There is something to see at every corner, and the entrance is unforgettable. Quiet gardens and no entrance fees!

hidden gem. literary. yes, it is under construction. yes, there are no crowds. yes, it is closed off with fences. and yes-they give tours! whatever you think you see from the outside, is just a tip of an iceberg. the complex is comprised of about 20-22 buildings-triage building, operating rooms, church, doctors quarters, hospital quarters, kitchen buildings, boys and girls wards and the tunnels. yes, all the buildings are connected by underground tunnels and you can visit them during guided tours. they provide you with a hard hat and bright vest for that, which i found very cool.the architecture is amazing, no money was spared to build the hospital thanks to a rich benefactor. so much detail, color, lines-you need the tour guide to clear it up for you. like-the kitchen building has a facade of an 18century church, that was moved here stone by stone to save it after demolishing. the complex should be finished in a few years, unesco is taking over it to open a university. visit it-its the only place in barcelona that does not have tourist crowds.

a UNESCO world heritage site. The hospital is one of the UNESCO world heritage sites in Barcelona. It looks fabulous. Worth to go and have a look. Very close to metro station. Once you step out of the station, you can see it. Also, the city background is good too. You can see the tip of Torre Agbar. Public enjoy free access to the ground.

under construction. it probably was and will be amazing again but right now it is a construction sight - they do give guided tours at certain hours but i did not have a chance to go back - well worth a walk around because the building has amazing features

Interesting but under renovation. Street level view of interesting architecture but under renovation as art center from hospital. Looks to be another Addition to Barcelona arts scene within sight and walk from LA sagrada familia.

Simply beautiful.. This is a beautiful site to walk in.
It's almost impossible to comprehend that such a beautiful site is an actual hospital.
It has a church-like architecture and walking through its numerous buildings was a real joy.
Don't let the renovations make you miss this beautiful site - an hour is all you need.

Waste of time!. It was being renovated so we couldn't even enter the grounds!
Thankfully not a far walk from the cathedral!
Nice building....whag we could see of it!

A jewel in arquitecture in Barcelona sssssh!. This wonderfully ornate Hospital was designed by the Catalan modernist architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner. If you get fed up of being in a line for the more famous Sagrada Familia Church, then pop up Gaudi Avenue and take a wander around the gardens and building. There are guides to help through the wonderland that Domenech i Montaner has created, but keep it a secret so others can enjoy the peace and tranquility too!

Boring. We went there on the way to Sagrada Famila. There was nothing much to see. It was very quiet and no one around. It was like a construction site and the buildings didn't look any different to any other buildings on the street. There is a guided tour but we didn't bother as it just looked very uninteresting.

Beautiful buildings; informative, but somewhat rushed tour. We learned about the Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau here on Trip Advisor and were pleased that we were able to include a tour during our recent trip to Barcelona.  As noted by others, the hospital, designed by Domènech i Montaner in the early 1900s and since replaced by an adjacent, more modern (and, IMHO, quite ugly) hospital complex, is currently undergoing renovation to become a research and educational facility.  What a remarkable and beautiful hospital it once was!  Our tour with an English-speaking guide took us through the grounds and into several buildings in varying stages of renovation.  We saw wards with beautiful mosaic tiles and huge windows to allow natural light and views of gardens and much more.  So much attention was paid to designing an environment conducive to recovery (but once recovered, why would one want to leave?).  There are museum-style exhibits in several areas.  Our guide sometimes stopped to point out a photograph at one of them, but there was no time to look at any further--perhaps they are for the next phase of the renovation?  Prior to our tour, we watched a short video in the small visitors center.  It provides an excellent overview of the modernista movement and specifically focused on Domènech i Montaner.  There are also a couple of exhibits on the walls of the center.A few points about logistics:  1)  Our guide spoke rapidly and  was sometimes difficult to understand.  Although she took questions, she seemed in a rush.  We were on the last tour of the day, and indeed, she may have been rushing as the staff seemed eager to lock the gates and go home when we were done.  Perhaps this was an atypical experience, but it may be best to avoid the last tour of the day.  2) At the visitor center, we purchased the Ruta del Modernisme guidebook (€12), which came with discount coupons for many Barcelona sites; we also purchased a second set of coupons for €5.  The coupons for the hospital saved us half off the €10 per adult admission price, and we saved on admission fees elsewhere on subsequent days; plus, the guidebook is excellent.  I recommend this purchase if you’ll be visiting several of the covered sites (or just want the guidebook).  However, do check the coupons before leaving the counter as they are good for one year and are supposed to be stamped with the expiration date; ours were instead stamped with the purchase date!  We were fortunate that the Modernisme Centre at Placa Catalunya kindly remedied the problem for us the next day.  3)  A few benches and a water vending machine are somewhat hidden just outside the center, up the hill--we discovered them only as we were leaving, but would have welcomed waiting for our tour in this spot.  There are bathrooms inside the visitors center.  4) Other reviewers have mentioned wandering through the grounds on their own.  While we were there, some folks asked at the visitors center about doing this and were told they could not, but they tried anyway; the guard at the inner gate turned them away.  Others seemed to be confused about the tour times.  I suspect that the tour/visit situation may be dynamic depending on the stage of the renovation.  It’s best to double check the tour times before heading there.  However, even if you miss the tour, you can look into the complex from outside the gate and see many of the beautifully tiled buildings and get a small taste of Domènech i Montaner’s amazing creation inside.

under restoration. Currently under restoration, I expect it to look superb once they finish it. Even now it looks great. It's huge, with multiple pavilions, brick made, with huge windows, ceramic roof and with wonderful decor to be spotted on the inside. And it's worth a look in the university also.It's on my vist list next time I go back to Barcelona.

Waste of time. Go to this only if you have plenty of time in Barcelona, otherwise it takes up too much time for very little to see of interest. You can get a good view of the main buiding from in front of the gates. You don't need to go on a tour. It is a building site and you basically see the ruins of a hospital and historical photograps. Go in a few years when there is something to look at. We were annoyed with the person at the tourist info centre at Placa de Catalunya who raved about this place and said how wonderful it was

Wonderful restoration in progress. Having wandered around the building in March and been mesmerised I was delighted to join a tour of some of the buildings and hear the history of the complex. The pavillions are beautiful and very impressive. I shall return on my next visit to Barcelona to see the progress. The money from the tours goes directly to the renovations so it is in a very good cause. The English tours are at 10, 11 and 12. The hospital has it's own metro station.The added bonus is that you can catch the 97 bus directly to Parc Guell from outside the hospital.

A fantastic renovation in progress. Yes, this is currently a building site but part of the appeal is seeing the architecture in the process of renovation.The English guided tour takes an hour and the beauty of the buildings together with the wonderful vision of Domenech gives a superb insight. Well worth the trip

A feast for the eyes. Often overlooked jewel in the crown of modernist Barcelona is the model hospital of Sant Pau. If the queue for the Sagrada familia gets too long this is a good contingency, or have a heart attack and really enjoy the service and art.
