Nothing that special. You can visit it in order to admire a more artistic hospital, but according to me, walking from the hospital towards Parc Guell is much more interesting!!

Great Architecture. The hospital was a bit out of the way and I thought it was a bit strange to make the trek, but it was worth it. The hospital compound is made up of several buildings and the architecture was amazing. Unfortunately, we arrived just after the last tour departed and couldn't go inside. So, check the tour times if you plan on going.

Beware. None of the tourist information places or tour buses mentioned the fact the place was a building site so we were very disappointed when we arrived expecting to be wowed by the building and to loiter on the gardens. Having trekked there we did take the tour, the spanish girls English was absolutely fine and the place was fascinating- we liked the historical perspective alongside the restoration one. We also liked the church next door. if you only have a short time in the city take this off your list but if you have time to linger it's interesting and the view walking down to Sagrada Familia from here is a good one.
under renovation. the site is under complate renovation but at certain times you can take a tour, hard hat provided . Suggest check the web for the time of the tour in your language. Interesting .

Waste of time. I totally don't understand all the positive reviews, we found it to be a total waste of time. We took the English guided tours, guide was English challenged, tried her best, but we were not impressed. Even with a good guide, I'm not sure it's worth the time.

I tried to enter but couldn't. I really wanted to visit this place as it was very close to my hotel. The was a lot of construction work being carried out, and I couldn't find how to enter, but I believe this would have been a great visit.

diferent. The first time I went there, I actually thought it was a museum or something other than a hospital, till I saw ambulances arriving, hehehe. It´s a beautiful building and you shouldn´t miss it.
Only saw outside, but beautiful. We did our own self tour outside the grounds. We had our dog and it isn't dog friendly to go onto the grounds. Magnificent architecture.
Like. very beautiful place but unfortunately closed.we could only admire it from the outside.gates were closed :(

Don't miss this Unesco heritage site - a hidden gem. This was one of the highlights of our trip and a great alternative to Gaudi. As the architect was also from the Modernisme movement this tour helped us to understand it's key concepts. We took the English tour.Although you can wander round the building for free there is no information and many areas are sectioned off due to the building works.Donned in builders vests and hard hats (the whole site is being renovated) we were taken all over the building - over the pavillions, into side rooms, in the corridors which went under the building, in the doctor's operating areas and into a ward. What made this tour so interesting was the thought that went into the design and the innovation for it's time. Patients mental health was as important as their physical health, hence an emphasis on light and their well being. The aesthetics were also part of the healing process. We were awed at the beautiful tiles, which were a nod to the Catalan history. The last room we visited, one of the wards, made my jaw drop - it was covered, from floor to ceiling, with exquisite tiles. It was also fascinating to learn how the building has been used over time and to see the different levels the ceilings were put in at later dates and how they are being removed to renovate it back to it's original design. I would highly recommend seeing this building and prioritising a visit before it is fully renovated so you can learn about it's history as it is being restored. We found the entrance for the guided tour a little difficult to find. When you come out of the metro turn right, you will see the new hospital, which is built behind the old hospital. Continue on this road to the end, which is parallel with the new hospital, then turn left and follow the steep road down, at the bottom of the road turn left. You will then fiind the entrance, as you go in there is a mobile building which is the tourist entrance, and has toilets and a waiting area. There are a few cafes and bakeries opposite the road if you arrive early. If I haven't persuaded you enough to take the tour bear in mind all the proceeds go to renovating the building and if you are over 65 it is free.

Short walk from La Sagrada. I saw this from the guide book and it looked to be a short walk from La Sagrada Familia - and it was. I did not purchase or take the guided tour, but spent some time dodging the construction areas to see this impressive site on my own. It was very nice and interesting, and can definitely be self-guided walking through the accessible areas on your own. I snapped a lot of really cool photos. I ended up walking up to Park Guell from here and it was a long walk, but still very direct.

Don't miss it. Our guide Daniel was just a wealth of information about modernist architecture, and he had such passion for the subject! The hospital's forwards thinking design as well as the very interesting guide made this one of my most favorite things to see in Barcelona. The tour lasted about 1 1/2 hours and the hard hat/vest were added bonuses. Bus 92 from the end of the tour takes you directly to Park Guell in about 20 minutes (you can use your subway pass on the bus).
Worth a visit.. Can't wait to return to see completed work. Excellent value for money with guided tour. Buy the Modernisme route guide book and save on further attractions.

Fabulous Tour with Informative Guide. We took this tour on August 15, 2012. The guide was fantastic. He knew all about the history of the hospital as well as modernist architecture and the modernist movement. There is a short portion of the tour in a renovated building, but the rest of it is all through the hospital grounds which is in the process of renovation. We found it difficult to be certain about tour information before we went, so here's the current information--the tourist office is open from 9:30-1:30pm. Tours in English are at 10am, 11am, 12noon, and 1pm; 10 euro each. I'll include a photo of the hours and tours in other languages.If you are going to Park Guell afterward, you can catch a bus right outside the entrance to Sant Pau--the 92 bus stops at the parking lot at Park Guell and takes 15-20 minutes from the hospital.

Don't think twice. Must see, it's very close to sagrada familia so u have no excuse but to go check itIt's very charming, hugeYou will need some time to check it all, go inside (u can do that)since now they are renovating it

Impressive arhitecture !. The Hospital was closed on Mondays and I only could admire it from the outside. I was so impressed by its arhitecture. Amazing ! Please note that Gaudi died here a few days after he was hit by a tramway.The Hospital is near subway that will facilitate your visit.

A treat for architects, designers, and cultural historians. Hospital Sant Pau is undergoing a major architectural restoration, and is being converted to use as a cultural center. They offer hourly tours for 10E per person. Highly recommended if you an architecture lover, which I hope everyone is who visits Barcelona!

Wish our hospital had such atmosphere!. We were looking for the Sagrada Familia and got lost, whoops, lots of walking. But our sidetracking enabled us to stmbke upon the hospital which hadnt been on our planned sites to see. That said, if you have to go to the hospital it should look like this one. Interesting, artistic, majestic even. It may not be medically efficient or up to our current standards of sterility & institutional conformity but it amazes. Take an hour and have a look. It's no longer a working hospital.

One of the highlights of my trip to Barcelona. I had a lot of favorites during my trip to Barcelona this past February but my two highlights were the Palau de Musica and the Hospital de Sant Pau. Of course both were designed by the same architect, Lluis Domenech i Montaner, a Catalan art nouveau modernist. The hospital is undergoing a renovatioin so you have to wear a hard hat and safety vest during the tour. There are a number of buildings in the compound and each one is a beautiful piece of architecture. There are underground tunnels that connect the buildings. The tile work is impressive and colorful. Rather than being a drab hospital, this place was a strikingly different place to be sick in because it uplifts you with the colors and design features. It will be interesting to see the finished product when the renovation is completed.

Nice counter point to all the Gaudi. If you are really interested in the architecture of Barca then you must accept that there where other good moderniste type architects!Sant Pau is impressive as a collection of beautiful bulidings. Additionally interesting by the fact it was a functioning hospital until relatively recently, amd also the philanthropy and social history of the area. Is being renovated so you only get to see parts, but the tour is interesting and to be fair if you visit you need to do the tour else it is a very limited experience. Hourly tours in english from about 10-2 (might be on the half hour, just check). We went on metro and walked afterwards down towards Sagrada. Get off at Sant Pau / Dos de Maig (L2) not Guinardo / Hospital de Sant Pau (L4) as the latter takes you to the new hosiptal and you have to wander round the block to the information centre that sell the tickets.You can get a small discout with a barcelona card or the like, otherwise 10 euros each.

Hart hattour will amaze you. Every hour you can join a guided tour through the former buildings of the hospital. The buidlings are being renovated for other (sustainable) purposes. The guides a well informed about the architecture of the Modernista. You will get a good impression about how the hospital was functioning in former times. The tour cost € 20 and last an hour. English tours every hour until 13.00 hours. Website: http://www.santpau.es/default.asp?Language=en
Wonderful. Beautiful buildings only a short walk from Sagrada Familia.

A bit different, very interesting. The Hospital Sant Pau is still very much a building site (hard hats and hi-vis waistcoats issued on arrival) as they are converting the area to a UN University due to open in the next couple of years, but don't let this put you off. They offer hourly guided tours in the morning and we were the only two people there so we were able to walk around very much at our own pace, ask the guide any questions we needed to and learn plenty about the building. If you like your sites a bit quieter then this is perfect.
hospital de Sant Pau. beautiful gothic building. It's a functioning hospital. Def would feel like death is coming for me, if I had to go to this hospital.

Beautiful building complex, don't miss!!!. I had a great guided tour of the premises, the tour guide was very knowledgeable and nice, helping to understand the circumstances and the times when the site was built. A little out of the way but most definitely worth it!

Lluis Domenech i Montaner's sprawling Hospital. Of all the great buildings in Barcelona, I would say this is one of my favourites. It lies just up the road from La Sagrada Familia, & is no less monumentally eccentric. Actually it's many buildings - part Gothic cathedral, part Teutonic fortress, part sultan's palace, its roofline is a riot of spires, beehive water towers & gaudily tiled domes, & its flanks are decorated with heraldic symbols & heroic-scale frescoes of the hospital's benefactors. Since June 2009, the ambulances have pulled up in front of a new hospital that's been tacked on at the back, & the majestic old buildings are slowly being transformed into a museum & cultural centre. I highly recommend stopping by the hospital. It's about a block from the Hospital de Sant Pau metro stop.

Amazing Hospital. This is an amazing collection of buildings that Barcelona is doing it's best to preserve and update in order to keep them alive and in use. There is extensive renovation going on so do take the 'hard hat' tour to see the inner workings of the site. You'll get to access the underground tunnel system and wander around in ways that the non-paying tourists will never see. (Some tours are conducted in English - see the schedule for details.)It's hard to believe the site has been there for so long given the imaginative thought process that went into it's construction. The innovations that were put in place at the time are really wonderful. Focusing not just on the physical health - but also the mental well being of their patients. Truly ahead of it's time.At the end of the tour you'll be invited to have a look at the language center and walk around the site. Don't take a miss on that. When you enter the language building you'll be greeted with some of the most amazing Spanish tile work - in a stairwell! It's really beautiful.
Best looking hospital I've ever seen!. Loved the detailing on the domes. Definetly worth a look if you have time.

one of the most beautifulk modesnist buildings. It is a huge set of buildings, that use to be an hospitla and now is in renovation. Is one of the most beautiful palces in BArcelona. You can also see(and walk form there to) the sagrada familia, and if to have a drinkyou want go to "la hispano suiza" where you can see some nice old cars.
Great contrast.. The old and the new part. Both awesome! Beautiful walk.

Beautiful complex of 24 buildings in Moderniste style. We got off the Metro at the Sagrada Familia stop, then walked up Avenue Gaudi to the Hospital. It's a 15-20 minute walk that leads directly to the main entrance. The historic buildings are currently being restored so the office is housed in a temporary structure. After a long hike through the property, we found a security guard who directed us to the office where the tickets are sold and tours originate. Ask for directions to the tours at every possible point, as there is no signage, and the estate is very large.The tour was very interesting. The guide led us through hard hat areas that used to house the patients, and various departments. The exteriors are beautiful and in good condition. The story of the hospital brings it to life, so the tour is definitely worth taking. We were happy to have located the office and were able to take the English tour!

Vist here before La sagrada familia. We had a hard time finding where to go in. We took the metro walked up the hill and turned right. You need to turn left and look for the break in the fence to the left after the chapel. There is a small white trailer which house the tour desk. If you go more towards the right you will find the new hospital which looks very similar to the old part except for a lack of decoration. The architecture and work put into the old hospital is absolutely amazing. Our guide was wonderful and talked about the fact that the idea of this hospital for the poor was to fight against industrialism and bring in nature to heal. Thus a motif of flowers, animals, gardens, etc. use of colors...the ideas that many hospitals are now going back to nowadays! We only had three people on our english tour so it was very personalized. We got to see inside the chapel briefly and even that was designed with much thought-blue tiles to help give a feeling of clam and peace.
Beautiful work. nice view, day and night but that is it, you can enjoy the work and view, maybe some photography, can't see any more there

Fascinating place. Currently in the midst of a major renovation, most of the buildings were closed although we could have gone on an escorted tour with hard hats for 10 euros each. We decided to go for a wander on our own and spent an hour or so in the grounds of the hospital which must have been quitre a place in its heyday. It's not modernist in the English-speaking sense of the word but more akin to Art Nouveau. Worth a visit.

Fascinating and stunning set of buildings. On our last trip to Barcelona we followed much of the " Modernisme Route" and visited some of the buildings we had not already seen.I had not heard of the Hospital before, but reading about it in the Modernisme Route guidebook, I was keen to visit it. We took the metro to it, but you come out on the other side of the complex by the modern hospital and have to walk all around to get to the entrance. It was built to look out towards the sea, so to approach it from the Sagrada Familia up the Avinguda de Gaudi would have been better.At the moment it is a building site but there is still plenty to see. The tour begins in a Portakabin and there is a good video presentation you can watch while waiting. The guide was brilliant - very enthusiastic and informative. You are able to visit different buildings and walk along some of the underground passages.The Hospital is a complex of streets gardens and buildings and designed so that infectious patients could recover in pleasant surroundings in a self-sufficient environment. It is considered one of the best Art Nouveau complexes in the world.

A monument to a time gone by. Until just a couple of years ago, the modernist buildings were still in use as a hospital. The buildings are lovely even though they have the gothic, slightly dark air of the 18th-19th century, but patients enjoyed being there as they wards were small buildings that allowed them garden views and even going outdoors. Now the hospital itself has moved to a new modern building located behind the old one, that depsite its advances is more cold and less friendly to both patients and workers (this said by nusrses themselves). Visiting the old hospital is a must for anyone intrested in Catalonian architectural style of the late 18th and early 19th centruies. Domènech i Montaner -the architect- may be less known than Gaudi; he is less eccentric but also very creative and gifted.
Vale la pena visitarlo aunque no se esté enfermo. Los hospitales no suelen ser precisamente lugares con encanto. Éste lo es. Llevar cámara fotográfica.

Once you find it, it is wonderful!. My friend and I went to visit but wound up at the working hospital by mistake. There were no signs to the historic hospital. We met another couple who were also looking for it and they joined us on our quest. Once we got there it was wonderful. We had a guided tour and were taken through the tunnels which connected each building. It is really worth seeing if you can find it!

If you like modernisme architecture, don’t you dare miss Sant Pau Hospital. For just 10 euros, I got to wear a bright blue hardhat and orange safety vest during an extensive tour of some of the 18 buildings at Sant Pau Hospital designed by Lluis Domenech Montaner who was also responsible for the brilliant Music Palace. We had an English speaking guide who really seemed to enjoy sharing her information and insight about this designated UNESCO World Heritage Site. The buildings are being restored and although it is an active construction site, it actually felt like we were walking about a ghost town by ourselves. The tour includes not just the exteriors but interiors and down into the tunnels which connect the buildings. I could have spent hours here just looking and sighing at the beauty. The hour plus tour was a highlight of my time in Barcelona and I highly recommend it. However, it is not handicap accessible and sturdy walking shoes is a plus. What was on my feet? Hiking boots. And what was on mind as I saw the buildings? “Wow !”

Amazing architetural hospital complex. This hospital was built by the Catalan modernist architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner; work started in 1901 and finished by 1930. Each wing (more like building) has its own architectural design and they are connected by underground tunnels; also, each wing was named after a patron saint. Taxi drivers usually mistake it as a small town or village as they drive their passengers through the complex with gardens at every turn. There's a church built for the patients and locals who live around the hospital complex, the Saint Paul's church is a small scale replica of Santa Maria del Mar church in the old Born neighborhood. The idea for building such a complex was originated back in 14th century to unite all small hospitals and medical researches to one huge facility. The old Hospital de Sant Pau of 14th/15th century is still standing today in the Gothic neighborhood downtown Barcelona, though it serves an art center and library. It is quite a shame that they move everything to the new Hospital of Saint Pau built right behind it and recently inaugurated. The old one is being restored and prepared to turn into a culture center and museum.

Lluis Domenech i Montaner Was a Great Architect. Domenech i Montaner is not as famous as Gaudi, but he was also a great architect. He created many of the pavilions at the Hospital de la Santa Creu I Sant Pau in a Modernist fashion. All of the pavilions are elegant. His son Pere Domenech I Roura also worked on the pavilions. The hospital is quite tranquil and is like a park because the grounds are large and you can walk among the pavilions and gardens. I think that if I were sick, this is the hospital I would like to be in. The hospital is within walking distance of the Sagrada Familia Church.

Amazing complex of monderisme buildings by Lluis Domenech i Montaner. Domenech i Montaner was practicing architecture at about the same time as Gaudi. His buildings are often very ornate, in a Spanish-Moorish-Catalan way. His Palau de la Musica Catalana is one of the most beautiful buildings I've ever seem (be sure to take the 1-hour guided tour of the inside, and try to take in an evening concert). But this hospital complex is also quite amazing...many buildings done in that design vernacular, with wonderful site-planning (a "garden city"). Take the cheap guided tour to get inside the tunnels and one building. All is under rehabilitation, to shore up the buildings prior to the site becoming the location of a multi-national Mediterranean institute for health, peace and the environment (many years of work to be done), so not every building is open, but whatever is open is worth seeking. It's great that Barcelona is preserving its architectural heritage!

Go. Although the facade was covered due to construction, and nearly all the grounds had been dug up again due to construction, this place is great, very calm atmosphere, we actually had lunch there, on a small concrete bench...

don't miss Santa Creu hospital while in Barcelona. Santa Creu hospital is a made up of a spectacular collection of old buildings. It is on the hill just up the road from Gaudi's Sagrada Familia and it is easy to walk to or take the bus or metro from the Plaza Catalunya. The hospital is a world heritage sight and certainly worth seeing if you have any interest in old buildings and architecture. There was quite abit of reconstruction being conducted when we were there (September 2010) but you can still access most of the grounds.
A must seen place!. Directly from Sagrada Family you should go through Gaudi avenue and in few minutes will reach this amazing place! Totaly impressive!!!

A must for anyone interested in history and architecture. The Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau is an awesome example of Catalan modernisme designed by Montaner. It is now a UNESCO protected site. The buildings are stunning inside and out and it's still functioning too! There are very cheap tours of the facilities that you can get tickets for right at the site. The tour takes to rooms not open to the public and shares a lot of interesting history about the hospital, its design, the neigborhood and how it was effected by the building of the hospital and how the medical field in Barcelona. It's definitely worth a visit!

It's an UNESCO heritage site, that says it all. looks more like a church than a functional hospital, in any direction.the mosiacs, the fountains, the crosses...although visitors are not turned away, do aware that it is still running and don't get in the way of the staff.The Sagrada Familia can be seen directly from the church, and is a 5 minute walk away.

Impressive. Of all the great buildings in Barcelona, I would say this is my favorite. Actually it's many buildings. I highly recommend stopping by the hospital. It's about a block from the subway stop.
